It had taken about two years for her to integrate it as a muscle memory, to remember that it was always there and always ready for her to utilize when she needed it most. Once she had, a lot of conflicts found resolutions that didn't involved her flared emotions.

Watching Stevie grow... It was beautiful, art almost. It was watching a story unfold right in front of their eyes.

Agatha and Rio had not only blossomed and flourished in their roles as her parents, but they themselves had grown in other aspects, too. Being Stevie's moms was rewarding in its own right, but another reward also came in the form of their relationship with one another, how they were continuously building and strengthening and fortifying the life they wanted.

In two years, they had endured their fair share of tribulations; Agatha had faced a scandal created by a disgruntled student that had nearly ruined her career -- but with some assistance from students that did appreciate her and had also been willing to provide proof, the allegations against her were shown to be entirely false -- and had also put the smallest ding in her relationship. It was one she had since been able to smooth out, one that hadn't needed that much effort.

Rio had wrecked the car and because she was okay, Agatha had given her endless guff about it. It hadn't been her fault; hydroplaning on the freeway wasn't something that could easily be avoided and Agatha had been sure to remind her wife of such every time she got upset about it. Rio had been okay, that was what had been most important.

In regards to Stevie, the biggest battle had been the winter before when she had slipped on the ice and landed on her elbow, effectively breaking her humerus. When they got her in to be looked at, Rio had walked away from the attending at the time with the news that the break was strange and compacted due to a cyst that had gone unnoticed as it had sat along the bone, weakening it for the previous few years.

During that time, Stevie had cried a lot. A lot.

It had been a fresh heartbreak every single time. It was hard to see her in pain, to hear the anguish in those wails because there was nothing anyone could do about it. Rio tended to her to the best of her abilities, which far exceeded Agatha's own. Stevie had fallen asleep most of those nights in their bed, exhausting herself with tears until her medicine helped ease her into sleep.

Agatha knew all too well the heartbreak that came with the responsibility of being a parent. It was that feeling that started as the tiniest crack, right in the bottom of the heart. It deepened a bit more as time wore on and Stevie endured more. Every meltdown, every tear, every shouting match that was mostly one sided on Stevie's part, they spread those fissures of hurt and sorrow.

But then... Then, every kiss Stevie would place on Agatha's forehead at bedtime and every kiss she would place to Rio's cheek when she got home from work began to reverse the process, healing those cracks. Every night that Stevie fell asleep across their laps, or in between them in bed, it soothed any ache or irritation.

It was as Sir Newton once said.

Every action had an equal and opposite reaction.

They were in motion, always, never derailing from the tracks that carried them through the different facets of their lives.

For Agatha and Rio together, one track was toward maintaining motherhood and another was in the direction of what it meant to keep their love prevalent in their marriage. Keeping it alive was never a concern, but making sure it was shown was something they both put effort into.

Individually, Agatha's track was to teach, to dedicate her career to helping people grow into better versions of themselves.

Rio's, as it always would be, was to heal. Her track kept her moving toward becoming the most compassionate person she could manage, every single day.

For Stevie, she had a couple of tracks herself. She was always moving forward in her existence as a Vidal, as their daughter. Now, she was learning what it meant to be a friend. She was learning what it took to be a teammate. She was charging forward on these tracks, now, and it was both fascinating and incredible to watch.

The Vidal women, forever in motion.

Right then, Stevie's motion was forceful and full of purpose as she stormed toward the closet near the front door, already having put her batting helmet on her head even though she didn't need it until they got to the cages. She was a kid, she did ridiculous but funny kid shit like that and Agatha ate it up each and every time.

When she had tried to put her socks on over her pants, Agatha had insisted that it wasn't practice or a game yet and they were just going to the batting cages. This had earned the smallest bit of lip, but Agatha had wordlessly ended the conversation with a very pointed stare down her nose at the rebellious little girl.

Stevie had rolled her eyes. That was Stevie's favorite thing to do when she lost an argument. And honestly? Agatha and Rio let her have it.

She didn't call them names (at least that they were aware of), didn't say too many unnecessarily hurtful things, and she had never raised a hand toward them in her anger. Had she perhaps thrown a pillow or a couple of stuffed animals? Yes, but she had made the conscious choice of selecting those items, items that wouldn't actually cause damage but still felt good to throw in the middle of those big emotions.

Nothing was ever going to be smooth sailing, that was just a fact of life no matter what it pertained to. There were going to be obstacles, but something Agatha had learned from Rio was that the obstacles were nowhere near as important as the actions taken to overcome them. It was almost a mantra for her, at that point:

Yes, here is the problem. Now, how do we fix it, or at least make it more manageable?

What a way to have come for a woman who had done nothing but run from herself the majority of her life.

Now, Agatha would use that experience to guide her child. Now, she would find a way to show Stevie that she didn't have to run to manage the wild and cruel way the world could sometimes be.

If it caught her a stray eye roll along the way?

Casualty of war, she supposed.

Agatha hoisted the bag over her shoulder as she approached the space where Stevie was flinging the closet door open, surely expecting to have to dive inside in search for her prize, but as she leaned forward with gusto, she halted herself mid-motion, immediately catching sight of the purple Rawlings bat, propped up against her bag on the right side.

Stevie's posture slackened and she pressed forward, much slower this time, grabbing hold of the bat to remove it before she shut the door in her wake. As she turned on her heel and held it up, the little smile on her lips was both sheepish and guilty.

"Found it."

Agatha's grin was wide, touching both of her eyes.

"As I knew you would," she affirmed warmly with a sure nod. "Now get your jacket on, mama's going to meet us there."

The drive to the batting cages wasn't a long one, and for a Sunday afternoon nearing the end of March, the city appeared to be on the more docile side in terms of traffic and obvious pedestrian shenanigans. It was still enough time for Agatha to start thinking.

Stevie hummed softly in her place in the back row of seats -- and additional feature they had decided upon when replacing the previous car that Rio had accidentally totaled -- and Agatha knew where she was going like the back of her hand, but that thinking she had started was going to carry her away if she let it.

She was thinking about Rio. She was thinking about something Rio had said to her those months ago when the accusations against her had first been brought to her attention. It was in those first moments of impact, those moments where the shock was taking hold and little else made sense.

She was thinking about the way Rio had looked her straight in the face and asked only one thing of her:

"Please mean it when you look me in the eye and tell me it isn't true."

Agatha hated admitting that she still thought about that moment, and even more over, she hated admitting how frequently she still found herself in that memory.

Even in the face of being wounded, Rio had not acted irrationally. She had clearly been hurt by the mere notion, but she had given Agatha the ability to defend herself. She had given Agatha the chance to tell the truth. The loudest thing about it was that she had asked her to look her in the eyes when telling that truth so she could know for herself that Agatha meant it.

It had been enough that Rio had believed her, but it hadn't been enough to keep things from slipping the slightest, if only for a few days. Agatha had fought in those few days to remind Rio of every single reason such an accusation would never be true, to remind her that their marriage and their family was all Agatha would ever need to be happy with her life. It was the favorite meals made, the gentle massages, and pouring of affection that helped settle Rio back into reality, their reality.

But Agatha still thought about when Rio had made that request.

She thought about all the ways she could make sure it never happened again. Realistically, that wasn't a possibility, but she still longed for the day it was. She never wanted to have to face another instance in her life where there was any reason in the world for her wife to doubt her like that.

Right then, she was thinking about how nothing she would ever choose to do in her life would ever warrant having to face that again, and how that had to be good enough.

"Mom, you missed the turn," Stevie called from the back seat, just over the dull thudding of her heels as they kicked at the floor beneath her.

"Shit," Agatha hissed, exhaling a frustrated sigh. "You're right, baby, I did. I wasn't paying attention."

"That's a dollar in the swear jar," Stevie informed her knowingly, punctuating it with a giggle. "I'm sure we'll make it before mama turns one hundred."

"Hey, you!" Agatha shot back, glancing over her shoulder to throw a manufactured scowl in her daughter's direction. "I always get us were we need to go, don't I?"

"Well, yeah. Just... late."

Never before had Agatha ever once considered the idea that she would like getting heckled by a nine-year-old. Then, she realized, she only liked it because it was her nine-year-old.

"Then I suppose it's a good thing I keep giving you examples of what not to do so you learn from my mistakes!" Agatha chirped in return, though her laughter broke up her last few words, joined by the sound of Stevie's laughter as well from the back seat.

With only a couple of minutes added to their trip, Agatha pulled into a random spot in the lot and placed the car into park. Before she cut the engine, Stevie was already unbuckled and contorting her body to stretch over the back of the seat so she could scoop her helmet and bat from the storage area.

As if on cue, Agatha's phone dinged from its place in her grasp. She tore her eyes from the sight of Stevie in the mirror and dropped them to the screen in her hand.

It was a text from Rio.

Of course it was.

"Did you get lost?"

Agatha actually laughed. As Stevie plopped back into the seat, a curious expression crossed her features, as if to ask Agatha's reflection what was so funny.

"Mama asked me if we got lost," she admitted, laughing again. "You may be onto something with that whole being late thing. Now c'mon, let's not leave her waiting any longer."

Agatha typed back a quick response that they were heading inside and stowed her phone in her pocket as she slid out of the car. After gathering the bag she had packed to keep Stevie fueled for the little while they would be there, she met Stevie around the other side of the car, looking ever-so-adorable with the way she had put her helmet back on and had propped the bat on her shoulder.

There were a lot of them, but that right there was a moment where Agatha felt so full of unfiltered love for her daughter that she barely knew how to comprehend it. In the four years that they had known her, she had grown so much into this vivacious, spunky, wild little girl and each and every day, she taught Agatha very important lessons.

Stevie taught Agatha that forgiveness should apply to herself as well as those she loved.

Stevie taught Agatha that honesty was always the best policy.

Stevie taught Agatha that she needed to talk to herself the way she talked to Stevie and Rio, with that same understanding and compassion.

Stevie also taught Agatha that if you get hit with a shopping cart in Fortnite, it will rocket you off into the distance.

Every lesson was just as important as the one before it because they were all vital in their own ways. The ironic part was that they were things Agatha and Rio had been instilling Stevie since she had come into their lives. They were things they had been so busy trying to teach her that they forgot those standards could apply to their own lives as well.

Aside from the Fortnite one. That was just important to know for high-stakes matches when they were being silly.

"Let's go, slugger," Agatha offered, reaching down to lightly rub Stevie's back as they began their voyage across the parking lot.

Agatha pulled the door open, allowing Stevie in ahead of her. Her eyes lifted and swept the premises, locating Rio on the left hand side of the space perched on a bench. She looked so good in that Bruins sweatshirt with the sleeves pushed up over her forearms, leaned forward with her elbows on her thighs. The way her head was tipped back caused her hair to fall out of her face, leaving it on display in every bit of its beauty.

What Agatha realized at about her forth step in that direction was that the reason Rio's head was tilted like that was because there was someone else there, someone talking to her. It was another woman, a bit short -- no taller than 5'2" if Agatha had to guess -- with long and curly light brown hair. Agatha could only see the smallest sliver of her profile, not enough to see an expression, but there was something about her posture that soured the pit of Agatha's stomach.

She was so lax, one hand appearing hooked on her side from how her arm was laid across her midsection while the other waved around in the air as she spoke. If Agatha hadn't known better, she almost could have sworn the other woman was flirting.

With Agatha's wife.

There was a brief heat that started to flare directly centered in Agatha's chest, one that was burning quite bright. She wasn't jealous; no, Agatha trusted Rio far too much in that regard, especially with that months old memory having recently played through her mind. What was pissing her off was that as a family, they had been to that establishment several times. Agatha had noticed her before, but never like this. It had only ever been in the casual way that she clearly worked there, but was never someone they interacted with much. This woman had surely seen the three of them, and her first introduction was to a solo Rio with her standing there like that?

Absolutely not.

Before that anger could burn her up, though, Rio's gaze flickered and she caught sight of the two of them heading toward her. In an instant, she was on her feet and raising a hand as if to dismiss the conversation. Agatha read this for what it was: Rio had been cornered and now she had her out. She wasn't trying to hide, wasn't trying to get out of an introduction to be sneaky or callous. No, Rio wanted out of that interaction just as badly as Agatha wanted her out of it.

The woman started to say something again, but Rio wasn't paying attention. She had already started to step away, toward Agatha and Stevie as they approached, a genuine and relieved smile brightly filling her face.

"Hi, my loves," Rio greeted, happily taking the kiss Agatha leaned in to plant on her lips. Like second nature, she turned toward Stevie who had already wrapped her arms around Rio's hips, the side of her head pressing against Rio's ribs.  "I think you grew another inch, you beanstalk."

"You say that every day!" Stevie returned delightedly with an airy giggle.

During this interaction, Agatha's eyes had lifted, watching with laser precision as the woman that had been talking to her wife walked away to return to whatever the fuck else it was she was supposed to actually be doing aside from flirting with customers.

"What if it's true every day?!" Rio returned, her own laughter full and bright.

"Mama, science won't let me grow that fast!"

Agatha's gaze shifted back to Rio, to that look on her face as she looked down at Stevie, hand on the crown of her helmet.

It was that. That right there.

That was the reason any emotions Agatha was having about the interaction she had witnessed had nothing to do with Rio. This was all Rio needed in her life, all she cared for at the end of the day. What they had was special and while not without its hiccups, the three of them were so good together. Rio had spent years proving again and again that Agatha and Stevie were her life. She had friends, she spent evenings out with them on her own sometimes. There were other times when Rio had to do things like conferences and seminars that took her away for days. No matter what it was, Rio always came back, because what was waiting for her was all she wanted.

Rio's head lifted and their eyes met. While the expression on Agatha's face had previously been stern and rigid, it smoothed the moment that contact was made.

"Making new friends?" Agatha asked her, and while it could have been pointed and interrogatory, there was instead a softness to her words and tone.

"More like trying to avoid them but she followed me after I got the chalk. She was talking but I was trying to text you and ignore her but she didn't stop. When you told me you were on your way in, I pretended to listen for the next minute." The longer Rio spoke, the more Agatha's smile seemed to grow. Rio was not a dense human being and she surely knew what the woman had been doing, but Rio simply didn't care.

Rio just wanted to wait for her wife and child in peace.

Agatha had half a mind to say something, but she thought better of it. It would do no good to cause a scene and would instead probably end up with them not being allowed to come back, and that was something Agatha would not do to her daughter, no matter how much it annoyed her.

"I love you," Agatha told her, taking another quick kiss before parting so they could make their way to the designated cage that Rio had paid for.

"I love you too."

She didn't have to say it, but Agatha was always thankful when she did.

While Rio and Stevie went inside to get prepared, Agatha took her designated spot on the bench directly behind that specific cage and pulled out her book -- which happened to be the same one Rio had bought her years ago, one that she tried to do a bi-yearly re-read of -- so that she could occupy herself while Rio helped Stevie work on her stance and cuts.

It really was a sight, the two of them with their helmets on, Stevie bearing her gloves covered in chalk as she wielded that bat like a weapon. She looked so determined and Rio looked so damn dedicated.

There were times when she would raise her eyes from her book to see Rio, hunched over with her arms running along Stevie's substantially shorter ones, would guide Stevie through a swing. She would watch as Rio stepped back to observe as Stevie put it into practice, and then cheer her on when she sent the ball soaring.

It was all Agatha could have ever wanted.

After about forty-five minutes, she had placed her book on the bench and pulled out the bag of cut strawberries she had stowed in the knapsack, popping one leisurely into her mouth as she watched on in interest. Sometimes, Stevie would get so riled when she missed that she would kick her bat, whimpering a moment later that she hurt her toe. It made Agatha chuckle each and every time.

She sat like that, occasionally tossing a strawberry into her mouth, comfortable and content for a little while longer. She was aware that they would probably be wrapping up soon, but she wanted to make a quick trip to the ladies' room before they departed.

After packing up the remaining strawberries and stowing her book, Agatha got to her feet and walked over to the cage, catching Rio's attention as Stevie waited for the ball to be launched. They met at the gate and Agatha informed her she would be right back to which Rio assured her they would likely be packing up when she returned.

Like a couple of idiots, they shared a chaste kiss through a hole in the fence and Agatha departed to alleviate herself. When she appeared back in the main area, her gaze drifted over to where Rio and Stevie were packing up Stevie's gloves in her ball bag and Rio was putting a few things into the knapsack. Rio was talking though, but not to Stevie.

She was talking to that woman again, reaching up to hand the chalk over.

Immediately, Agatha's temper flared.

They could have taken the fucking chalk back to the desk themselves. There was absolutely no reason that this woman should have felt compelled to approach her wife for the second time that day after weeks of her never having interacted with any of them prior.

The moment Rio saw Agatha from across the room, she got to her feet again. This time, the woman looked over to follow her gaze. The very second she met Agatha's gaze, Agatha could swear even from that distance that she saw the woman smirk. That little flare was quickly growing into a bonfire in Agatha's middle. Before she got just over halfway, the woman said something else to Rio and then walked away, not daring to look in Agatha's direction.

Within feet, Agatha heard Stevie's acute observation.

"She's really annoying, mama. You coulda taken the chalk up there like we always do."

That whipping flame in Agatha's chest dulled the slightest bit. Stevie had her back without even knowing it.

Rio's response softened her even further.

"I know, baby. But it's okay because she doesn't matter. You and mom matter."

"Oh, is that so?" Agatha posed, sidling up next to Rio, quickly snapping her head over to place a quick kiss to Rio's cheek.

"It is," Rio answered, her cheeks pushing up, pink and flushed with the effort of their last hour or so.

"I think that calls for tacos and sorbet for dinner then, hm?" Agatha suggested and Stevie lit up at the mention.

"Tacos! I want tacos! And we can go to the heladería next door?!" she questioned, her voice hiked with her excitement.

"Of course we can," came Agatha's easy response. Her tone was warm, but she was already miles ahead of this interaction. "Why don't you and mama head to the car and I'll be out in just a moment and we'll go right over and grab food, okay?"

"Agatha --" Rio started, but Agatha waved a hand to cut her off.

"I just have something to address before we leave. I'll be quick! Now, shoo!" she urged with a laugh, waving the same hand to indicate the door.

"Agatha, you really --"

"Rio, please. It's fine, I promise. I'll be as fast as I can!" She was trying to be reassuring, but she could tell just by the way Rio was giving her that look, the one that said she knew exactly what was about to happen, that she should just concede and exit with them, but Agatha simply couldn't. She had something to say and she wanted to make sure it got said.

"Come on, mama! Tacos!" Stevie pressed, none the wiser as she took hold of Rio's hand and began pulling her toward the door. Rio's focus stayed on Agatha, an entirely helpless look scribbled on her face as her head turned as far around as it could before she had to choice but to look forward to pay attention to where Stevie was dragging her.

As if carried by hurricane-force winds, Agatha marched directly over to where that woman was positioned behind the counter, leaning over it as she scribbled something down on a clipboard. When she noticed Agatha approaching, she straightened up part way and painted on the fakest smile Agatha was sure she had ever seen in her life.

"Can I help you?" she asked, that feigned professionalism thick in her tone.

"Yeah, actually you can!" Agatha chirped back facetiously, a wicked sneer curling her lips. "I've been coming here with my wife and daughter for... I don't know, let's just ballpark it at a month. At least twice a week sometimes three. You've seen us around right?"

The woman looked confused, her brow pinching slightly. "Yes...?" she managed after a too-long pause that Agatha didn't like.

"Great!" Agatha clipped, clapping her hands together in front of her chest. "So, I'm going to give you the benefit of the doubt and assume that you have at least some observation skills and have spotted that very obvious wedding band on her finger. Which leads me to believe that you've comprehended the fact that she is married and that we have a daughter. Which, you know, considering we never come in here unless we're all three together... I'd like to think that was enough of a sign."

The woman must have sensed where this was going because she tried to cut Agatha off.

"Ma'am --"

"No! No words. You listen." Agatha leaned forward, but kept her hands pulled back and tucked to her sides. Her volume dropped; she didn't want to risk this being overheard. That sinister leer was still on her face as it stopped next to the other woman's, her voice low and full of venom so that it could sink right into her ear. "If we come back here again and I see you flirting with my wife one more time, I promise you that I will have her cover our daughter's eyes while I drag you out into the parking lot by your hair and beat your ass."

Agatha righted her posture and gave her shoulders a shake, fixing her hair before she met the woman eye-to-eye again.

"Am I understood?"

That smirk from earlier was nowhere to be found . Instead, the woman seemed to masticate on sandpaper for a moment before she gave a weak nod. She could have called her manager over, could have had Agatha bodily removed from the premises, but she just blinked, stunned.

Maybe she had mistaken Agatha for someone who wouldn't make a statement, but that was an idiotic move on her part.

Agatha may not have been jealous, but she was fiercely protective of her family.

"And to add, just so you know how lucky to consider yourself right now... Flirting with her in front of our daughter? You rightfully earned at least one shiner with that shit. Learn shame and self-control because I mean it. If it happens again, you will regret it."

With that, Agatha turned on her heel and marched toward the front doors, a little stunned to see Rio and Stevie still standing there, waiting.

The look on Rio's face was almost unidentifiable, at first. The closer Agatha got and the more she could see the look in her wife's eyes, she could tell that it was a mix between adjunct horror and being completely turned on that Agatha had just partaken in a very intense but quick interaction in her honor.

"What was that?" Rio asked, but Agatha blew by her and pushed the door open, swinging around so that she could hold it for the two of them to exit.

"Agatha," Rio tried again as she made her way out. Agatha let go of the door and moved forward, scooping Rio's hand into her own as they began to walk to the car.

"It was nothing!" she insisted, though she knew that wasn't going to work.

"You made that lady very white," Stevie observed in a giggle.

"I just made sure she knew that mama is a very happily married woman, that's all!" Agatha's tone was too vibrant for what had just transpired, but she could tell by the way Rio squeezed her hand that she was thankful for it, even if she would give her hell about it in the weeks to come.

They made it to the car and Agatha opened Stevie's door for her as Rio put her equipment and their helmets in the back of the Denali. Agatha shut Stevie in and went toward the back to cross back over to the driver's side just as Rio secured the hatch.

Rio was quick as she made a play for Agatha's sides, swinging her to her left enough that Rio could pin her back to the metal and glass of the hatch. Before Agatha's surprised squeal was even finished, Rio was kissing her. It was heavy, it was passionate, it was thankful. It was everything Agatha loved about Rio.

When their lips parted, Rio's dark honey eyes opened into Agatha's and Agatha could feel her grin coming from a mile out.

"What was that for?" she cooed at her wife, tilting her head just enough to swipe their lips together again.

"For being so feral over me that I didn't even need to hear what you said to her to know that you put the fear of the gods in her. And you did it because you knew she was making me uncomfortable. And because I just love you."

Agatha's grin just brightened with each word that fell from Rio's lips. By the time she was done speaking, Agatha's hands landed on her chest and gripped gently at the sweatshirt, pulling her close so they could kiss again, though she knew to keep it brief when Stevie waiting in the car.

"I just love you too, baby. And for the record, I'm not above fighting anyone for you. So we're clear."

Rio laughed, rolling her eyes.

"I married you fully aware of that very fact. Don't think I'll be forgetting it any time soon."

 

Chapter 28: One Shot - Hide You in My Treasure Chest

Three Years Later.

"Where the fuck -- ?"

The soft sounds of pillows and the comforter hitting the floor were almost mute as Agatha Vidal grunted and groaned, nearly tearing apart the entire bed for her phone. No matter what she threw aside, nothing revealed the location. She could have sworn that she had tossed it there when she had gotten home just before she had jumped in the shower.

Yet, with just the fitted sheet left on the bed, it was nowhere to be found. In her search, the corner of that sheet up by where Rio laid her head every night had come dislodged. With a sigh of irritation, Agatha stalked over to fix it. As she rounded the corner, there her phone lay, on the floor face-down.

How the hell had that happened?

She scooped it up and checked the time; It was 2:13pm. That meant that she had three hours to run her errands before Rio got home.

Agatha's errand list was as such:

- Pick up the bouquets of roses she'd ordered at Sunny's.
- Stop by the market for a bottle of Blanton's Special Select.
- Pick Stevie up from school.
- Take Stevie to Julia's for her sleepover with Julia's nephew, Ronin.
- Stop by Harvard Bookstore and grab a hard copy of 'She Is The Poem' that she'd requested a couple of weeks prior when she'd read it on her Kindle.
- Make it back in time to change and get ready for the reservation Agatha had made for herself and Rio at Fox & The Knife.

It was quite the list. It was also quite the occasion.

It was March 23rd.

It was Agatha and Rio's fifth wedding anniversary.

Rio thought she was going to come home and they were going to order pizza and watch movies, maybe play Overcooked, which was the most recent favorite in the house. It was mostly Rio and Stevie while Agatha read assignments or played old Nintendo games on Stevie's Switch while Stevie played on her Playstation. Donkey Kong had been the hit choice as of late, but that was because she could split her attention when she was playing it.

Although watching the sheer chaos of Stevie and Rio trying to keep a kitchen running was an ever-comical delight, Agatha had other plans.

Those plans were a night alone, a book of poetry that she had ulterior motives for buying, a very expensive and very nice dinner, as well as a bottle of bourbon and far too many flowers than Rio could possibly ever need. The box of spare petals Agatha had already back were hidden in her nightstand, waiting for that night in particular.

She'd already devised a plan for that; once Rio was dressed and ready, she would claim she forgot something and run back upstairs to 'grab it' in enough time to scatter the petals for when they returned home after dinner.

Agatha had spent the last five years, for three-hundred-sixty-five days a year -- and one that was three-hundred-sixty-six -- falling in love with her wife more and more each and every day.

Sure, there were times when she cussed Rio up and down when she grabbed the wrong set of keys off the hook before she left for work. There were times when she woke up to the smell of something burning to discover that Rio had been cooking and got distracted with talking to Stevie and destroyed the meal she had been preparing. There had even been times when Rio had made a bad decision that had upset Agatha to a point where she'd needed to sit in her office for a few hours with the door shut to try and process.

In turn, Agatha knew that it made Rio really upset the few times that she had asked her to pick something up or complete a task and Agatha did not comply, no matter what the reason was. The first few times, Rio had been forgiving but as it grew into a pattern, she eventually expressed to Agatha that it made her feel like Agatha was not caring enough to actively listen. As a result, Agatha had put forth more effort into making notes and doing other things that would assist her in remembering.

There was something else that had been happening with a little more frequency over the last year or so.

When anything went missing in the house, there was a 24% chance that Agatha had put it in the refrigerator. Now, 24% wasn't exactly the highest percentage, but the key word in relation to this literally mindless occurrence was anything.

The first time it happened, it was the car keys. Then, later that week, Rio had opened the door to see a pair of scissors laying on the shelf next to the eggs. Days later, when she had found Stevie's sleeping medication in the refrigerator door shelving after nearly tearing apart the entire house in search of it, Rio had decided to approach Agatha about it.

"Should I be worried?" Rio had asked, trying to keep her concern sheathed initially.

"What? Of course not, I'm fine," Agatha insisted as she blew about the kitchen, grabbing dishes and silver for the dinner they were preparing to sit down for.

"Agatha..." Rio tried to press, but Agatha had not stopped moving. "Is... Have you noticed anything else? Confusion, disorientation, or --"

"Rio," Agatha cut in as she set the plates on the dining room table and her feet stayed planted. So I absentmindedly put things in the wrong place. Who doesn't, right?"

Her memory was sharp and her cognition had never otherwise faltered, but it had annoyed Agatha to no end that Rio had been insistent she, at the very least, get checked out. That had been a series of appointments that were grumbled over and griped about, but in the end they had soothed Rio's uneasiness.

Raising Stevie was a gift, through and through. She was so smart, so determined. Her heart was made of nothing more than gold when it came to the people she loved or cared about. She had made friends, liked to go places to hang out with them -- with Rio or Agatha hovering nearby -- and invite them over. Kids really liked coming to the Vidal house because it had the 'sick room with the flowers.' 

Stevie's best friend, though, was Ronin. He was Julia's nephew and he was the sweetest kid; he and Stevie would just sit in silence with a movie on while he put together a several-hundred-piece jigsaw puzzle throughout the duration. Stevie didn't care that he didn't speak much, or that he got upset when things were misplaced. 

The first time he had shouted in his stress, though, Agatha had listened as Stevie explained to her how the situation had made her feel on their drive home.

"It upset me," she had divulged, playing with her fingers in her lap. "But... Ronin was more upset. And if he feels better to yell, then I guess that's okay."

"He just feels things a little differently sometimes, kind of like you do," Agatha explained, gaze flickering up to the mirror to watch her daughter as she considered and processed that idea.

"Kind of like when mama bought me that scratchy sweater on accident and I could hear the dryer even though we were in the game room and then the kettle whistled and I started crying?" Stevie rattled off and Agatha had nodded in response.

Stevie got it, just maybe not in the technical breakdown. That was what made her friendship with Ronin work. Once she had made that correlation, she treated Ronin the way she wanted to be treated in those situations and as a result, he found comfort in her presence.

Some conversations were harder than others, and there was some frustration and misunderstanding, but every conversation they had always ended with a resolution.

Very few nights had Agatha fallen asleep in their bed alone, and those only came about when Rio needed to occasionally travel for conferences. The same was true in turn when Agatha packed to head to a seminar or a conference of her own. 

Every night away ended the same: A video chat that always closed with the most sincere 'I love you' that could ever be spoken into existence.

Just like every other night.

For five years, there had been so many memories, so many laughs, so many tears, so many dollars in the swear jar. For five years, the Vidals had built the life the wanted to be living, inconveniences and hiccups be damned.

All of that, Agatha felt, deserved a truly thoughtful and inspired celebration.

That was what she was going to give Rio, because it was what Rio deserved.

It was excessive, sure, but Agatha didn't care. This one was just a little more special.

It was one of three like it; flat, pressed steel all the way around but marked with an engraving. Etched into the metal were two hands, linked at the pinky. "The beating of wings brings with it the gusts of yearning. The gracing of feathers drag the weights of anvils through each ventricle. Dilation and constriction in rapid succession lend little gravity in terms of clarity. Each whip of a wing seeks elevation, enlightenment. A better view offers more to behold, a vantage point not before witnessed. Suspension at those heights for brief moments before release does not prepare for the thrill of the fall."

Rio was remarkable in every way.

And she was Agatha's.

"Agatha, you did not book us a table at that exorbitantly priced place," Rio deadpanned, her expression falling flat.

"Oh stop it," Agatha returned, face puckering slightly to show her defiance. "You know you love the Mafaldini Alla Funghi more than you'll admit to. The toasted farro gets you every single time."

"It's also thirty dollars a plate." Her voice still had a slight edge but Agatha knew she'd already won and Rio was resisting just because she could.

"The black one with the red stitching. And that crimson blouse that goes so well with it." The answer was quick, as if Agatha had already known she would be asked such a question.

"Ooh, red tonight?" 

"Yep. Red tonight." That was it, just a punctual answer with a daring grin that canvassed Agatha's face.

"As you wish, my love." Rio's own grin was bordering on rotten, her mischief so bright in those dark honey eyes. She leaned in, taking one last kiss before she stepped back, watching Agatha with those teeth bared as she made her way clear to the doorway before she disappeared inside, finally turning around to tend to the task she had been given.

She pulled it out and unzipped it, revealing the rich scarlet dress that lay inside. It was most assuredly formal, but it was also undeniably sexy. It was form fitting around the waist in a way that enabled the incredibly deep neckline -- which actually came to a point only a few inches above her navel -- to work as well as it did. 

Not only that, but it allowed for the tiniest curve of the insides of her breasts to show. Agatha knew that it was a look that was going to turn heads, but it was why she had requested that Rio wear that specific suit. They were visibly going to be a pair in more than just their obvious affection for one another. When people looked at Agatha in that dress, they were going to see her hand in Rio's as they floated through any given space.

Still stark naked and apparently thoroughly stunned, Rio was just staring. 

"Agatha..." she attempted, but her mouth closed as she tried to swallow whatever feeling had been sitting in her throat. "Where the fuck did you get that dress and why have you never worn it before today?"

Saying that Rio was enchanted right then would have been a massive understatement. She was completely stricken with her awe and Agatha could hear it in her voice.

Grinning, Agatha tossed her hair back over her shoulder, allowing for a better view of the way her collarbones were on display. "When I took Stevie to be fitted for the dress she asked for when she went to the softball dinner, I saw it. I went in a week later and was fitted for it, had it altered and... I guess I've just been waiting for the right time to bring it out." 

The shrug Agatha had to offer tried to radiate an air of indifference, but she knew what she had done. It showed in that toothy smile that wouldn't fade as she watched her wife, still stupefied to immobility, the hunger clear in those dark eyes.

"Rio." Agatha tutted her tongue, turning to slide on a couple of rings. "If you do not dress yourself soon, we are going to be late for dinner."

Rio's response came quicker than Agatha had been expecting.

"And if I say fuck dinner?" she challenged. Agatha head whipped in her direction, eyes both narrowing and flashing.

"Absolutely not. Not even if it is to fuck me." Agatha's lip jutted out in her pout. "Can I please just have this?"

She could see it as the understanding settled in over Rio. Yes, the gestures and the flowers and the gifts were nice, but she was realizing that Agatha wanted the world to see them, too. Sure, they could hide away in their home and get lost in one another as they so loved to do, but Agatha liked going out with Rio, being seen with her. 

Agatha even liked it when they ran into people they new, or people that recognized Rio from the hospital. She liked when they already knew who she was, even if only through all of the things Rio had told them about her.

Sometimes, it was just nice to go out and exist in the world for a night. It was nice to share a fancy meal while they talked about the mundane of day to day life. It was comforting to look across a table into the most beautiful eyes Agatha knew she would ever see and know that they were the same ones she'd get to see the next morning when she woke up.

So, that was what they did. It took a little more goading to get Rio to put her clothes on, but once she had, Agatha had been the one debating if dinner was really as pressing as she had made it out to be. Ultimately, she had decided it was and they had set out to leave. 

Just before she put on her peacoat, she stilled and glanced toward the stairs. 

"I forgot something, I'll be right back!" she announced, not giving Rio time to question her before her heels were clicking over the hardwood floor and up the stairs. 

Just as she had planned, she removed the glass case filled with rose petals and sprinkled them across the bed and on the floor around it. She knew it was silly, and that showed clearly in the way she couldn't keep from snickering at herself as she completed her work. To cover herself, she grabbed an extra ring and shoved it onto her pinky so that she could claim she actually had forgotten something.

They had chosen to take a ride share to the restaurant, enabling them both the ability to indulge in a drink or two over dinner, which they did. In fact, when Rio had requested the 2019 Sangiovese, Agatha's eyes had buldged so badly that she could have sworn they were going to fall out.

The grin Rio wore in response was full of mischief. 

"If you get to buy me flowers and poetry and wear that dress, I get to buy us a two-hundred dollar bottle of wine." 

A thought Agatha never wanted to stop having for as long as she lived crossed her mind.

Damn her.

"You know what?" Agatha said, leaning back in her deat a bit, regarding her wife with manufactured scrutiny. "Touche, I will give you this one."

"Alas!" Rio chimed delightedly, that grin only brightening. "Victory is finally mine!"

"So you think," Agatha returned, her eyes glimmering with her teasing. "I get to take you home. So who's the real winner?"

Their banter had gone on, a steady back and forth of hilarious flirting and sly jokes until their meals had arrived. Agatha herself had developed a decent buzz from the wine, one that offered the warmest haze through her blue eyed perspective. 

Rio had always been soft, but the longer the night wore on, the softer her edges became when Agatha looked at her. She was so gentle, so caring in ways that Agatha had never known possible before Rio had come into her life, and now she sometimes felt as though she was undeserving. It was often a fleeting thought, but she could sometimes spiral into questioning what on earth she'd done to garner such a full and bountiful life.

Agatha was aware that all she had to do was ask Rio and Rio would not hesitate to tell her.

Perhaps that right there was reason enough.

They had finished their meals and called for another car, only moderately buzzed as they exited the restaurant. The food had seemed to balance out the wine, but Agatha took no issue with it. In fact, she preferred it for what she was hoping to accomplish that night.

Agatha had a plan. She wasn't sure if Rio was going to like that plan because of just how much they had grown, both individually and as a married couple, but there was intent behind it.

Rio's skills at unlocking the front door in any kind of an inebriated state had honed quite nicely in the time they had been together and even though Agatha had enough time to wrap her arms around Rio's middle, pressing her cheek to the back of her shoulder, it didn't last long. Rio gave her arm a light squeeze to ask for release and Agatha complied so they could head inside.

The wax burner had been left on accidentally while they were gone, but Agatha found herself thankful for the smells of warm sugar and vanilla that met them once they entered. The moment her coat was hung and she shut the door, she slid up to Rio, half behind her and half beside her, a hand landing on her bicep. Agatha leaned forward and placed her lips to Rio's cheek, moving just enough to make a soft suggestion in her ear.

"Why don't you go upstairs? I'll meet you in a minute." She pressed another kiss to Rio's cheek and pulled away, taking her shoes off before she paced to the kitchen. Her lips curled as she watched, out of the corner of her eye, as Rio did as she was told, though she had been staring in Agatha's general direction until the very moment she was out of sight.

Agatha gathered the things she had collected from the market, including the bourbon, glasses, and the box of truffles. Once satisfied, she remembered to turn off the wax burner and made her way up to join her awaiting wife who had undoubtedly discovered the bed covered in rose petals. As Agatha got closer, she could smell that Rio had lit a couple of candles.

When she appeared in the doorway, Rio had turned off every light except the small one on the desk. Every other light source was in the candles that were placed around the room, a warm orange glow covering the walls.

Directly in the center, at the foot of the bed, Rio sat with her feet planted on the floor, a dreamy smile on her face that only grew when she noticed Agatha enter.

"Quite the haul you have there, my love," Rio observed and Agatha offered nothing more than a little shrug in return, pacing to her night stand so that she could pour their drinks. However, before she uncapped the bottle, Rio shifted slightly behind her. "I... Actually, I'm okay on the alcohol. The wine was nice, but... I just want to enjoy the rest of our night like this. If you want one, that's of course okay, but I'm good for the evening."

"Would you like a truffle, my love? They're you're favorite, the sea salt and caramel ones."

Chapter 29: One Shot - Love is What Gets You to Sing

"Hellooooooo? Anyone home or do I have to carry all of these groceries in on my own?!"

Agatha's call came from the base of the curling staircase that led up to the two other floors of the home she shared with her wife and child, her arms filled with sacks that held her market bounty.

From the top level, a squeal and joint laughter sounded and echoed down to her ears like the sweetest song. It was her favorite, the one she could listen to over and over without tiring of it.

Life would never be perfect, but the snapshots of it like that one, for Agatha Vidal, were as perfect as perfect could be.

It was the memories she had acquired, even in the last year. Stevie had turned eleven that January, an occasion that had been fitting of a birthday party at the nearby roller rink filled with her friends and teammates from both softball and volleyball. They had plenty of photos from the celebration, but some of Agatha's favorite moments were locked away in her mind.

There was one, taken from where she sat rink-side at a booth with hard, rigid seats that never would have been comfortable if sat in the way they were designed. Instead, she had been perched at the end of the bench, watching the chaos happening mere feet away. Her eyes zeroed in on the sight of Stevie whipping over the polished surface on her skates, several feet ahead of Rio who was clearly trying to catch up. 

Then, in another, Stevie had swiped her finger through the icing of her cake, catching Rio on the nose with it. The laughter that had filled the entire space around them had almost been surreal, something ripped out of a dream.

The best one, though, had been after everyone had left and Agatha and Rio were finishing the duty of cleaning everything up. Stevie threw a couple of plates in the trash just as Rio carried some of the gifts out to the car. When she turned around, Agatha was headed for the same bin, but the look on Stevie's face gave her pause. Her approach was cautious and she reached around her daughter to discard the trash, but once she was done, Stevie had simply surged forward and locked her in a tight embrace around her middle. 

Stevie hadn't been able to say it, but Agatha knew.

For Agatha and Rio, they were just raising their daughter, a little girl they had loved since the moment they met her.

For Stevie, she was living out the infinite dreams she'd had as a child, before her life had changed for the better.

In March, she and Rio had celebrated six years of marriage. That had its own memories, ones of the trip to Maine the three of them had taken, ones of crabbing -- with little yield -- and walking on the shore as the bitter and cold wind whipped up off the ocean. There were memories of the cabin they stayed in, the nights of movies and popcorn and bonding.

Sure, it might have been their wedding anniversary, but when Rio had pitched the getaway, she had voiced that their anniversary was what it was because of Stevie and that was something Agatha knew she couldn't argue.

Before she reached the bottom, Agatha had relocated to set the bags in her arms on the counter. She was wearing grey overalls bought specially for such an occasion and they were completely ruined by too many splotches of paint to count. Even her face showed the effort she and Rio had been putting forth in her bedroom.

"Mama asked if you got the orange stuff to wash our hands with!" Stevie informed her to which Agatha simply chuckled.

"Yes, of course. Can't have you dirty and paint-covered hooligans crawling into bed tonight," Agatha returned, laughing softly again. "It's in the back with the other groceries."

"Okay!" Stevie called behind her as she took off toward the front door.

"Artistic and efficient," Agatha mused in a light teasing as she, too, began to stow things in their proper places.

"That's me!" Stevie chirped before a bright bout of giggles spilled out of her.

Within a few minutes, the pair of them had put everything away and plated a light snack of celery and apples with a small dish of peanut butter in the middle to take up to Rio who was surely still hard at work when it came to painting the new mural.

As suspected, when they returned to Stevie's room, Rio was on the ladder, arm stretched up with a paintbrush in her hand, blue at the end as she swiped it over the wall. In her mouth, secured between her teeth was a smaller brush, one with white paint coating its bristles. 

"Well, look at my artists so hard at work. You've gotten quite a bit done since I left," Agatha observed, gliding over to place herself in the rocker that had been moved to the far corner with the rest of the furniture so that it was less likely to get splotched with paint by accident. She swiped a piece of apple through some of the peanut butter and surveyed the work that Rio and Stevie had accomplished so far.

"I need to go to Proline near North End by 2 to pick up some clear coat but it shouldn't take me long," she voiced, glancing over her shoulder at Agatha who was munching happily on her apple slice.

"That's what you think," Agatha mused with a snort before popping the last bit of the slice into her mouth.

"What do you mean?" Rio questioned back, actually stepping down from her place on the ladder as if she might need to leave sooner depending on what Agatha had to say.

"Well the entire area around the commons is closed down this weekend for that festival thing," Agatha replied, her nonchalance almost close to indifference. "The parade that starts at 3 or whatever."

"Festival -- Wait! Pride?! Shit, Pride is this weekend?!"

While Agatha seemed rather nonplussed over such a reaction, Stevie seemed a bit startled at Rio's sudden exuberance. 

"What's Pride?" Stevie asked, as if she were feeling left out of the exchange.

"It's a very large headache for anyone traveling around North End this weekend," Agatha mused, taking a bite of a new apple slice.

"Oh, stop it," Rio admonished, dropping the brush into its pan. She turned her attention to Stevie, her features smoothing into a warm smile. "It's a celebration of the ability to love anyone and everyone. It's where people like me and momma and your friend Josie's dads can go and just celebrate what it means to love and care about each other. They have a big parade where local businesses and companies have floats where they throw candy or trinkets." Rio's smile was growing the longer she was watching the light dawn on her daughter, the excitement creeping in. "The ones I went to in Columbus were probably my favorites."

"Can we go?!" Stevie asked, her tone hiked with how eager she suddenly was.

"It's hot," Agatha whined through a mouthful of apple.

"Oh, come on," Rio chided, pinning Agatha with a skeptical gaze. "You wanted to run an entire marathon last summer --"

"But I didn't! Because I knew it was going to be too hot!"

"Agatha, everyone in this room knows it's because you tore your meniscus trying to beat Stevie in DDR." "It's just a lot of people in a moderately sized space," Agatha responded, setting the plate in her hand down on her lap but she had not looked away from her wife.

"Okay, and... What's the real reason you don't want to go?" she pressed a little harder, convinced that there was more to it than Agatha was willing to let on to.

"It can be, and while I haven't been to one here since before we met, I do have a friend that lives in a fourth story apartment along the parade route. So..." Rio paused, lips worrying together in thought for a brief second. "If it's the crowd you're worried about, I can almost bet she'd let us come over and watch from her balcony."

"Hey," she cooed softly, a hand landing on Agatha's knee. "Can you talk to me?"

"It's just... silly," Agatha tried to dismiss, as if Rio was not going to expect her to qualify it with any elaboration. Her eyes lifted and saw the pressing, the request for more though it was not uttered aloud. "I just mean... Gah, I don't know what I mean."
