"It's just... It feels like a target, I guess... There are enough people in this world that detest the fact that people like us even exist. It seems silly to just... collectively gather. Easy pickings." Agatha had always been a cynic, but being so hackled about this of all things seemed to be hurting Rio in some way.

"You are not the first person to feel like that and you will not be the last. But... Don't you think that's what people who think that way... don't you think that's what they want?" Rio's voice was calm, it was even, but it held weight in its deliverance. "That's what this is all about, about defying the hate and thriving in spite of it. You are proud of us and our family in all other aspects... So it's okay to let other people see it, too. And... It's a chance to see just how much support we have in this city we call home."

Ah, when in doubt, tell Rio Vidal all the worries in the world.

Why?

Because she always seemed to have an answer.

Agatha's lips pursed in thought, but it was really more of a way to staunch the emotion that wanted to bubble up inside of her. It would serve little purpose to get emotional about this, but that moment was a very blatant reminder of why she loved Rio and why she would always love Rio.

"Has anyone ever told you that you have a way with words?" Agatha questioned, nervous blue eyes lifting from the plate in her lap to appreciate her wife there before her.

"A time or two. It's usually some flippant woman with messy hair and crazy bright blue eyes. Though this time the typical pout seems to be missing," Rio offered, lifting herself up from her squat, but only to bend at the waist so she could grace Agatha's lips with a gentle kiss. "I know you worry, my love, but don't worry so much that it keeps you from living."

Ah, the sage wisdom that Rio pulled from the roots she had planted in reality. She'd always had a unique way of perceiving things, and she'd always had and uncanny ability to point them out in a way that got under Agatha's skin.

"Has anyone ever told you that you should consider being a poet?" Agatha teased, tipping her chin just enough that she could steal another quick lip lock.

"I'll stick to the visual arts. My wife's a little better with words." That curl of Rio's lips was so familiar and ever so comforting.

"Sometimes," Agatha conceded with a small shrug. Her attention flickered to the plate for just a moment and then back to Rio who had returned to full height. "Alright, call your friend and see if we can watch from there. In the meantime, I'll consider the idea of going to the Commons. Is that fair?"

Rio's only reaction was a wide and sweeping grin that immediately touched both eyes, the thrill of having won this battle clearly coursing through it. It was very obviously something that had meaning for her, something that was dear to her heart in the times she had experienced it in her past. 

"You know," Agatha began, getting to her feet as she cradled the plate in her palm, "I highly doubt it will be anything like the ones you went to in med school."

At this, Rio let go of a hearty, full-belly laugh.

"I certainly hope it's not. We will not be going to any Nina West shows and I will not be in spandex dancing on tables."

Agatha's eyebrows shot up in surprise, a tickled smirk tugging on her lips. "Daddy Rio in spandex? Ah, something else to add to the 'someday' list."

"Don't push your luck," Rio grumbled, poking an extended finger deliberately between a couple of Agatha's ribs as she stepped forward for a kiss that Agatha returned happily.

"Alright, alright. I'm still pocketing it," Agatha returned as Rio pulled away and turned to head toward the door. "I'm going to go pack us a bag while you and Stevie are showering. Reconvene in the dining room when you're done?"

"Of course. Grab a couple of extra bottles of water, if you can. Y'know... Since it's so 'hot.'" 

With that, Rio disappeared into the hallway and Agatha was left, planted in Stevie's half-finished bedroom with a plate of unnecessary snacks and a stupid grin lighting up her face. It shouldn't have felt like victory to lose and argument, and perhaps she still wasn't entirely sold on the comfortability of attending the outing, but damn it if Rio didn't know the right thing to say almost every single time.

Even the gentle prodding didn't bother Agatha, mostly because she knew that Rio was right. The heat had been nothing more than an excuse to hid her discomfort at the idea. Agatha was not a woman who wore shame in most facets of her life, but she'd assuredly had her reserves due to lived life experience. Maybe even more than that was that Agatha had never really had anyone worth bursting that bubble for.

Now, she had her wife and daughter who both seemed utterly tickled by the idea of celebrating love.

How on earth could Agatha ever say no to that?

She had followed Rio's path into the bedroom, the smallest smile finding her at the sound of the shower running and Rio singing her own rendition of 'It's All Coming Back to Me' by Celine Dion. Sometimes, Agatha could not help but feel like despite the silliness of it all, there was something so impossibly wholesome about the life they had built. It was mornings painting murals and afternoons watching parades and showers with 90's ballads belted into the air.

It was everything Agatha had never thought she could have before she met Rio.

After changing into something more suitable for being out in the summer heat -- a lilac tank top and pair of black bike shorts -- Agatha had pulled her hair up, securing it in a wild ponytail that ended somewhere just below the middle of her back. When she turned to set about gathering them things they would need for the day, Stevie appeared in the doorway, clean and dressed in a white t-shirt with a tiny little rainbow flags printed onto it as well as a pair of purple shorts that were just a few shades different than Agatha's tank top.

It was as if she had known what Agatha's answer was going to end up being even before Agatha had made her own mind up.

"We match!" Stevie nearly sang, her joy apparent in every inch of her face.

"I suppose we do! Do you want me to braid your hair today or just wear it up like mine? It's going to be hot enough that either way, it should be up." With such a revelation, even though she had already known, Stevie completely lit up.

"We get to go?!" she squealed, bounding further inside the room in Agatha's direction to collide into her with a tight hug around her middle. It was sort of funny; Stevie had yet to approach puberty and she was already growing like a weed, head already even with Agatha's chest.

"We're going to go to mama's friends place to watch the parade and then we will go from there. After I get your hair up, do you want to come help me pack some snacks?" Her chin dropped as she beheld her daughter, those grey eyes so bright and filled with excitement. Agatha lifted a hand, running a few fingers through Stevie's damp hair as she formed her answer.

"Yes! And we can use my fan that I have for softball!" she exclaimed, releasing Agatha to take off in search of it. 

With a gentle laugh, Agatha started to head out but made a brief detour, pressing the bathroom door open to poke her head in as Rio shut off the water. 

"Did your friend text you back?" she called, the steam rolling into her the moment she had peered inside.

"Yeah, it's Regan. She said we're more than welcome to come over and that they were having a small shindig anyway," Rio informed her, poking her own head around the door of the shower, having pushed it open a bit. "And she said that she and Preston would be more than happy to go with us if we head to the commons."

Regan was one of those friends for Rio that would have bent over backwards to make life easier for not only just Rio, but the three of them as a whole. Rio had met her when she transferred in from Miami Dade and they had immediately bonded over having spent time in the city. It had been nice to watch Rio find a kinship with someone like that and very quickly, Agatha had grown to like Regan and the friendship she had to provide. They were even slated to attend her wedding later in the year, something that Rio was so very thrilled to be a part of.

For a fleeting moment, Agatha had the thought that if Rio had mentioned who it was sooner, she might have been a little quicker to agree, but she let such a thought go the moment it rolled in. It truly was neither here nor there in the grand scheme of things and she was already caving anyway, no help needed.

"Yeah, yeah, we'll see," Agatha returned, though with the glances they exchanged and the smile Rio bore, they both knew how their day was going to go.

After meeting Stevie in the kitchen -- who had already pulled out several bottles of water and a handful of packages of fruit snacks and granola bars -- Agatha shoved everything into a knapsack and hung it on the handle of the front door so they wouldn't forget it on their way out. Upon turning around, she caught the sight of Rio coming down the stairs, something that caused a fire to spark low in her belly.

It wasn't unheard of for Rio to wear cut-off shirts (this one a dark grey with a gold printed The Lovers tarot card that contained two skeletal women in an embrace) that had open sides and revealed the dark navy sports bra she had on, or for her to wear loose and breezy black and grey basketball shorts. To combine them and add the black Bruins cap to top it all off? Agatha was reminded both of how much she loved her wife and also how absolutely and undeniably attracted to her she was, too.

"You're an a-- "

"Ah, ah!" Rio tutted, raising a finger to wave back and forth in warning, though she was wearing a daring grin and was completely aware of what she had done. "You already owe like six dollars to the swear jar."

"Fine," Agatha huffed, lip jutting in a faux pout, "but I know you did that on purpose."

Rio shrugged and glanced down at something Agatha suddenly realized she was holding in her hand. "I found these. You don't have to have one, but I thought Stevie might like a couple," she voiced, holding up the small unopened package of press-on tattoos of small rainbows and little pride flags.

"Oh, just wait till you see what outfit she picked out," Agatha informed her, nodding her head toward the kitchen as Stevie came bounding out of it, having pulled her own hair up into a high ponytail.

"Oh ho ho, already in the spirit I see!" Rio chimed as she turned in place to greet Stevie as she bounced into place, planting her feet firmly on the ground despite the small bit she rocked forward. "I have some little tattoos, if you'd want them on your cheeks." She held them up, Stevie's grey eyes surveying for only a second before they filled with light.

"Are you gonna have some?!" she asked, her eyes lifting to Rio's face, a grin beginning to blossom on her lips.

"I thought I'd look pretty great with some flags on my cheeks. They're... a little old, so we'll see if they actually work."

Even though Agatha knew it was coming, there was still the slightest catch in her breath as Stevie's gaze lifted to her. "What about you, momma? Do you want some tattoos?"

Rio did not turn around, did not provide an additional set of eyes on Agatha in that moment and honestly, Agatha was thankful. It was a small gesture, but it spoke volumes. They both knew, though, that she was never going to tell Stevie no, not on something of that nature. It was clear that the request was nothing but pure in its motivations. 

"I think I'd love some."

After a brief detour to the downstairs bathroom and about twenty minutes, what had started as them each having small flags on their cheeks had turned into Stevie and Agatha having a small flag on each cheek. Rio did too, but every single other tattoo on the sheet had been imprinted on both of her bared arms. 

Stevie had been nothing but a box of giggles since the moment they finished, even throughout the trip to Regan's. She had posed a question when they were almost there, one that caused both Agatha and Rio to glance toward each other before grinning.

"Aren't you afraid you look silly, mama?" 

"Not at all," Rio answered as her eyes turned back to the road so that they could make their approach down the alley behind Regan's building. "You know why? Because at the end of the day, I'm showing up with the only people I wanna leave with. And if you and mom think I look silly, then I'm okay with that 'cause it means you are happy and entertained."

"You don't care if people make fun of you?" her question was curious, but both Agatha and Rio knew that there was a learning opportunity to be had right then. 

Stevie had dealt with quite a bit of bullying the previous year in school and it had almost reached a point where she was toeing the line of expulsion. After Agatha had marched in and shared a few choice words with the principal -- which included pointing out the pattern that it had all been boys and they had all antagonized Stevie until she hit them back -- the teachers seemed a little more apt at heading any issues off when they were around. 

"I sure don't. Because... Who are they? I don't know them and they don't know us. If they think I look silly, that seems to be their issue, not mine. I think I look very snazzy and very proud!" she chimed, taking one last turn into the underground garage.

"Snazzy, huh? Did you rip that one straight out of the mid nineties?" Agatha teased, reaching over to give Rio's thigh a light squeeze. 

Rio rolled her eyes, chuckling softly. "Listen, I've got to keep hip with the dad lingo, right?"

Stevie burst into giggles in the back seat, covering her face to somehow stifle the sound, but it didn't actually do much aside from triggering the same reaction out of both Agatha and Rio in the front. 

The sound had hardly faded as Rio placed the car in park and glanced up to the mirror to watch as Stevie unfastened her seatbelt. "Is Ronin going to be here?" she asked, scooting toward the edge of the seat so that she could lean forward between the two of them.

"No, this is one of those things that he has trouble with. The noises can really get to him, even if he wants to try. But it's okay, there will be a couple of other kids to make friends with," Rio informed her, leaning over enough to smush a playful kiss to the side of her daughter's head, pushing it toward Agatha. In the next moment, Agatha copied the motion, placing a kiss to the side of Stevie's head with enough force to push her back toward Rio who started to keep it going, but Stevie was too quick and pulled herself back as the laughter overtook her again.

"Alright, everybody out! Rally around the back!" Rio ordered, though the giggles were abundant as they all complied. For the time being, they didn't need the bag or much of anything else and so once gathered, they headed through the garage and took the elevator up to their intended destination.

As usual with her mega-watt smile and bright green eyes, Regan greeted each of them with a warm hug of welcome and instructed them to make themselves at home until it was time to go outside. There were a few other people there, one of them being someone Rio recognized as working in Neurology and his apparent husband, but she had not known that he was gay or that he had a teenage daughter.

"Learn something new every day," Rio murmured almost under her breath, though the amusement was still audible in her words. Well, if the words themselves were audible.

"What was that?" Agatha offered, her head turning toward her wife as if to show she would be listening better.

"Nothing, just thinking out loud," Rio answered, swift as she landed a quick peck to Agatha's cheek. "If you want to have a drink, you should," she encouraged, smile warm and bright.

"No, I'm okay. Plus, if we do end up walking around I do not want to be intoxicated in this heat. It's part of that 'being a responsible adult' thing you keep trying to get me to subscribe to." Agatha's tone was light in its teasing, but the scrunch of her nose was what really sold it, causing Rio to roll her eyes.

"Oh, it's so awful, I know."

They had mingled with the two other pairs of adults there until just before three when the eight of them lined the balcony to watch as the parade would pass below them. 

From a good ways down the road came a low roar, almost a hum at first but it grew louder every few seconds. Agatha's eyes were cast down the street but couldn't quite see the source of the sound. Next to her, Rio had perked immediately as a grin swept cleanly over her face.

"You don't know what that is, do you?" Rio pressed. It almost seemed like she was fighting off delighted giggles, leaning on her hands on the railing of the balcony as she watched Agatha.

"I do not know what that is, my wife," Agatha offered back, her tone pitched and sing-song in delivery.

"That's Dykes on Bikes." 

For a moment, Agatha blinked at her. Duh. That should have been obvious.

"And you are nearly overwhelmingly giddy about that because...?" she questioned, her head tipping to the side in her sudden curiosity to peel back this layer of the woman she loved.

"Because I rode pillion with them two years in Columbus," she divulged.

Both of Agatha's brows hiked in her surprise, though she suddenly had to lasso in the several stray thoughts that popped up front and center. The most prominent one there was the idea of Rio on a motorcycle. The tiniest and most inappropriate shiver ran up Agatha's spine but she tried to shake it away, clearing her throat as if that would help or somehow cover her momentary lapse.

"Pillion, huh? You didn't have your own?"

Rio laughed, really laughed, as if she were privy to a joke Agatha had never heard before. Even Regan leaned forward to make sure she was okay, amused by the sight of Rio nearly doubling over in her amused trembling. She took but a moment to calm herself, righting enough to lean against the railing. 

Stevie was a little further down with her new friend -- Shay, who was thirteen -- and after a brief sweep to check on her, Agatha's attention was back on her wife who still seemed to be recovering from her bout of giggles.

"I failed the test twice the summer before med school. Decided it wasn't a good idea. Then I learned very quickly that the leading cause of traumatic brain injuries in the country is...?" Rio trailed, looking up at Agatha as if she should be able to finish the sentence.

"Hm," Agatha mused, unable to pass up the opportunity to tease Rio. "Let me guess... I don't think it's sportsball. Or drag racing. Maybe... Is it motorcycle accidents?!" 

Rio's expression had become blank about halfway through Agatha's taunting but when she was finished, Rio simply blinked.

"Yes. Yes, it is motorcycle accidents," she deadpanned, breathing a playfully annoyed sigh through her nose before her lips curled up in a smile that acknowledged the game that had been played and she respected it.

As the roaring got louder, Stevie came back toward them to get a better look, craning her neck as she tried her best to see. She was taller, but it was still a small task to get a truly good view. Once she did, her eyes widened and she was beaming. "Are those motorcycles?!"

"Yep," Rio confirmed, leaning forward so she could look over at Stevie, taking the moment for a quick lesson. "Every chapter leads the parade in their city. It's both a show of protection as well as it is a logistical placing. Motorcycles can't fluxuate in pace like cars and people on foot can, so they are always first contingent."

"You sure know a lot about this, mama," Stevie gushed, clearly smitten with the idea that Rio was telling her about something important to her. 

"I do. I went to a lot of these when I was learning to be a doctor. It always felt really good to be a part of something so big. Sometimes, over eight-hundred thousand people filled the city for that weekend, to have fun and find a little more community."

The majority of the parade went on like that, with Stevie asking questions and Rio answering them with complete ease and utter joy to be having those conversations with her daughter. They were laughing and pointing things out, squealing over extravagant floats or the men on stilts as they marched down the street.

Every single moment of it, Agatha was locked in. Maybe she'd had her own reserves, but they had all but disappeared at the display that wore on before her. Rio was tickled pink to be revisiting an aspect of her life that she hadn't explored in an incredibly long time and Stevie was over the moon to not only see such a display but to hear Rio explain the things they were seeing. It was a bonding experience that touched something deep within Agatha, something that wanted to square up with the past her that had tried to deprive them of those moments.

After the tail end of the parade passed by, everyone retreated inside of eat a few slices of pizza. Over their quick snack, the conclusion had been reached that they would all be venturing down to the Commons.

The walk from the apartment to the park was a short one and while it was rather warm, the heat was not unbearable. Stevie's eyes were so focused as they snapped around, her hand clutching tightly at Agatha's as they walked. She was getting older, maybe, but with something like this, Agatha was insistent that she keep hold on at least one of them at all times. More than that, it was also a way for Agatha to gauge Stevie's nerves. 

There were a few times throughout the afternoon when she would start to grip a little harder, a call to Agatha that was reiterated when Agatha would look down and blue eyes fell into slightly panicked grey ones. Each time, they would depart from the pack and get a little space and air. Almost every instance, Rio joined them a moment later and would sit on the grass in front of Stevie while they all three took a few moments to just settle and talk. It was effective in offering small charges to Stevie's emotional battery, but Agatha had been adamant that if it got to be too much, they could head back to the car no questions asked.

Stevie pressed on, ever so persistent that they 'feel the love,' as she had taken to saying throughout the afternoon. 

They had gotten food from a couple of the trucks that had been lined up and sat with everyone else beneath a tree as they ate and watched the sun sink a little lower in the sky. When they finished, both Regan and her fiance as well as the other parents -- who Agatha learned were named Dennis and Santiago -- announced that they were going to head back and wrap it up for the day. They departed with hugs and the promises that they would need to find another occasion to all gather again, something Agatha actually meant when she agreed.

With a little light left, Rio had indicated that she wanted to walk around just a bit longer, especially since it had cooled off considerably. They had decided to make it to the far end before they would turn back around and head for the car so they could go home for the evening. Agatha was not actually sure if Rio had known what would be at the far end of the park, but the moment Stevie saw the display of motorcycles, she inflated with excitement, surging forward enough that it caused her to tug on Agatha's hand.

"Can we go look at them?!" Stevie questioned, her tone rushed as she tugged on Agatha's hand again as if to lend to her beguiling.  

What Agatha had not expected was for Rio's voice to sound on the other side of her.

"Yeah, can we?!"

Agatha's head snapped toward her wife, eyes narrowing for just a moment, but she was unable to keep her lips from parting in a grin. She rolled her eyes and gave a dramatic couple of nods. "Yes, girls, we can go see the big bikes."

The squeals and guffaws that sounded from the two of them left Agatha feeling like she was so close to simply vibrating out of her skin. She was happy she'd said yes, she was happy she had agreed and caved further to allow them the day on the green, so much laughter and so many memories to be had. It seemed that there were a few yet to be made. 

Rio was quick to make introductions and exchange handshakes before offering a little bit of context to her own personal investment and why their daughter was so excited to get an up-close look at the motorcycles. Agatha would chime in when she felt she could, but it was the most fascinating thing to listen to Rio recant the summers she spent living in the light, having the time of her life. 

One of the women turned to Stevie who, while observing closely, had kept her hands to herself the entire time out of respect for someone else's things. It was a rule she had been taught young and one she tried very hard to abide by. 

"Do you want to sit on it? Your moms could get a picture, if you want?" she offered with a gentle curl of her lips.

Stevie's eyes lifted and immediately filled with the brightest light Agatha had seen there in some time. "Really?!"

The woman nodded and glanced over to Rio who understood and stepped forward, lifting Stevie up and fitting her directly over the seat of the Harley. Stevie was wearing a grin that was all teeth and no eyes, completely blinding, clearly thrilled to be granted such an opportunity. 

Agatha, phone in hand, didn't even need to request a 'cheese' with how broadly Stevie was smiling as she snapped several pictures, moving around a little for better angles. Before she was ready to have herself removed, Stevie requested to see the photos to make sure Agatha didn't need to take any more. Once satisfied, Rio lifted her off of the seat and set her on her feet so that she could run to Agatha who had stepped a few feet away.

"Mom! That was so cool! You got real good pictures!" she gushed, that grin still plastered to her face. "I can't believe I was on a motorcycle! I'm only eleven!"

The corners of Agatha's eyes wrinkled with her laughter as she raised a hand to smooth over her daughter's hair, simply drinking every little bit of happiness that was overfilling her. "That you did, sweet pea, and that you are. And we have the pictures to prove it!"

"Yeah we do! My friends won't believe me without them!"

Those few feet away, Rio was still chatting with the owner of the Harley who offered another opportunity for Agatha to hear.

"What about you? You said it's been a while, but... Feel free," she said, indicating the bike with a tip of her head. 

Agatha could sense the blatantly sheepish grin that crossed Rio's features before she even turned around to meet Agatha's gaze. It wasn't so much of an ask as it was an acknowledgement that she was about to indulge a side of her that she might have thought long forgotten and Agatha gave an eager nod of encouragement, but perhaps with a few of her own reasons behind it.

Before Rio had even swung her leg over to plant her foot on the opposite side of the bike, Agatha had her phone back out, adjusting the settings again to get optimal photos. She took almost just as many of Rio as she had of Stevie, but those were going to be mostly for her. She might send Rio one if she was insistent enough about it. 

Truthfully, the longer Agatha had the opportunity to behold such a sight, the more she wished the danger level wasn't quite so high and it was something Rio might find herself interested in again. She knew it would never happen given Rio's profession, but the mere sight of her on the bike, both in the way she held the handlebars and in the way she leaned back with her arms across her middle was enough to turn something molten in the Agatha's middle.

There was never a day that Agatha forgot how handsome, how gorgeous, how breathtaking, how captivating her wife was, but right then?

Right then, Agatha was glad she was able to maintain some modicum of self control despite the sudden pulsing she felt between her legs. 

Rio would always be those softer descriptors so long as she lived.

In those moments, she was undeniably fucking sexy.

Rio dismounted the bike and offered her hand to the owner once more, giving it a firm shake of thanks. Stevie and Agatha both waved their goodbyes as well, turning as Rio slid up to Agatha, looping her arm around the small of Agatha's back to pull her close. 

"You good, my love?" Rio nearly mumbled, clearly having seen the flush on Agatha's chest and neck and had perhaps caught a glance of her expression when she had been taking the photos.

"Mmmmm," Agatha hummed lowly as they began to walk, Stevie's hand clutching the one that wasn't wrapped around Rio's waist. "M'good. Just might need a towel for the seat on the way home," she suggested slyly and while she was immediately able to withdraw from the game to return to the task of getting back to the car, Rio balked at her side. She sputtered for just a moment before she cleared her throat and pressed on, though she couldn't quite hide that ridiculous grin on her face.

On the way home, something beautiful happened. 

Stevie was not shy around them and never really had been, but Stevie was also not normally an at-length talker. She knew what she wanted to say, she said it, and that was that. On that ride home, though, she hardly took a breath as she recounted every moment of the day she could remember that she had enjoyed and why she enjoyed it. She talked about the kids she talked to, about the bracelets they had bought her and the sunglasses. She talked about the floats and the men on the stilts.

The closer they got to the house, the more even her pacing became and even bordered on slow as they were pulling into the driveway. The thrill had done its job and now, the exhaustion had started to set in. 

The three of them shuffled into the house and shed their shoes so that they could get ready to rest for the remainder of the night. It was half past nine and as Rio scrolled through her phone, she cursed under her breath, but Stevie still clocked it.

"That's a dollar," she chastised and Rio grumbled her agreement.

"Rio? Everything okay?" Agatha asked, leaning toward her a bit. 

"Yeah, it's just that my email deferred the notice from the pharmacy that Stevie's meds are ready. Tonight's her last dose and they're not open tomorrow. But... I can make it there before they close if I leave right now." Her lips turned down as she met Agatha's gaze, but she found nothing but agreement.

"Well, go on then. Maybe grab some more Eggos for breakfast. I think we're almost out and I forgot this morning," Agatha urged, leaning forward for a quick kiss, though Stevie was quick to pipe up to ensure her breakfast routine would not be disturbed.

"Do we have enough strawberry jelly?!"

"Yes, baby. That I did get this morning," Agatha assured her over her shoulder. She turned back to Rio, brows lifting to press her onto the task. "Be quick but be safe. I love you."

Rio leaned in for her own kiss, voice sweet and warm when she returned the sentiment. "I love you too." She stepped back and turned slightly, holding her arm out for Stevie. "I have a feeling you will be asleep by the time I get back, so goodnight and I love you."

Stevie had run to Rio's side, hugging her around the middle tightly. "Goodnight, mama. I'll see you 'morrow."

"See you 'morrow, baby." Rio leaned down and pressed a kiss to Stevie's forehead before offering one more 'I'll be right back,' and then departed.

Agatha tended to getting Stevie situated in the spare room on the other side of the house, the space she had been occupying since they had started work the evening before on the mural. She was changed and washed up within a few minutes and called for Agatha so that she could be tucked in.

As almost every single night before it, Agatha placed herself on the edge of the bed, looking down at her daughter who looked both exhausted but still somehow elated.

"Mom, that was so much fun," Stevie spilled, clearly still hung up on everything they had experienced that afternoon.

"I am very glad you had a good time. I did too. And I know mama did as well. She liked being able to teach you a bunch of new stuff," Agatha explained, lifting a hand so that she could drag a barely-there fingertip down the length of Stevie's nose.

"I like when mama tells me stuff she knows. It's really cool. Especially when it's about motorcycles. Did you know that she knew so much about them?" Stevie inquired, her tired eyes still so bright.

"I actually did not, so I was just as surprised as you. Seems like we learn new things every day." Agatha couldn't have known the irony of making such a statement, given that she had missed Rio's use of the phrase, but the universe had willed it as such.

"Can we do it again?" Stevie asked just before being overtaken by a large yawn.

Agatha chuckled softly before providing a sufficient answer. "We can go again next year. And the year after that. It can be our summer thing, yeah?"

Stevie nodded, this time raising her hand to rub at her eye in an obvious attempt to stave off sleep. "I would like that a lot."

Agatha leaned forward, pressing her lips to her daughter's forehead gently. "Me too, kid. Me too," she whispered softly just before pulling away. "Get some sleep, baby girl. I love you."

"Goodnight, mom. I love you too."

Agatha pushed herself to her feet and crossed the room, leaving the door cracked a good bit for Stevie's comfort. It took only a moment to cross the entire length of the hallway to their bedroom which she breezed into easily. At the same time, she had pulled her phone out of her pocket and unlocked it, leaving the screen open on her photo gallery... And all of those delectable photos of her wife. 

Her feet stilled a few paces into the room and she considered for a moment. Her steely blue gaze was locked on that line of photos for the longest moment and then flickered up, landing on the 75" television mounted to the wall across from the bed. Then, she turned around and shut the bedroom door, the one Rio had spent hours one random Sunday afternoon sound-proofing for their benefit.

If she timed it right, she could be finished and have the door back open as if nothing were amiss by the time Rio got back.

Even though she was alone, Agatha was grinning like the world's biggest idiot. She'd never had such an idea before and was almost disappointed in herself for it as she hopped onto the bed and swiped down on the screen, finding the casting option so that the image on her phone then became projected on that ridiculously large television. There, in all its glory, was her camera roll.

What the fuck had happened to her that morning?

"Stevie," Agatha said again, her voice a little more firm. "I am trying not to jump to conclusions about what you did to that boy, but you're going to have to give up some answers at some point. You are already too aware that... that kind of violence is absolutely unacceptable." Agatha paused as she pulled into the driveway, holding it until she put the car in park. 

"But I also know you, and I know that whatever happened today really, really upset you for you to hurt him like that. So... Like I said, we're gonna go inside and you're gonna go upstairs. You may watch a movie, but no Switch. I'll bring you some lunch and we'll check in again before mama comes home, okay?" Her tone was sweet, tender in a way that she could recognize there were bigger things at play here, things Stevie simply didn't have the right words for.

Somewhere in the middle of Agatha's speech, Stevie had already started to unfasten her seatbelt and grab her bookbag.

"Stephanie," Agatha voiced, this time demanding some form of acknowledgement. She could see, as she studied her daughter, the tension that immediately snapped her form tight. Slowly, Stevie's head began to turn and those guilt-ridden eyes landed right into Agatha's. 

Agatha's face fell a tiniest bit, fighting the emotion that had suddenly hit her with full force in the chest. Stevie looked devastated. She knew what she had done was wrong, but something in Agatha just knew she still felt justified.

After a slow breath, Agatha had decided on what she thought Stevie needed to hear.

"I love you, okay? And I'm not angry about this... I am just very confused and the only way I am going to know the correct way to feel is if you explain to me what happened. And... I get that you're not ready to do it right now, but it does have to be done at some point today. But whatever you tell me... I need you to know that it does not change my love for you." Agatha could see, the longer she went on, as Stevie's eyes began to develop a shiny film of tears, ones she was so clearly fighting to not let spill over.

"Okay." It was only a single word, but it was more than Agatha had gotten out of her most of the trip home, so she knew to take it as a small victory. 

With a cautious hand, Agatha reached up to cup Stevie's cheek in her palm, brushing over it with the pad of her thumb in a gesture filled with nothing but love and patience. 

"You are my daughter and I am always going to love you, even when you make not great choices and do things you know you shouldn't. You know that, right?" Agatha asked her, lips pressing in a tight smile.

"Yes, mom, I know that," Stevie finally admitted, though she still looked like she was on the verge of tears.

"And the same goes for mama, 'cause she's not here to speak for herself. We love you, Stevie, and we just want to help you. So... Let us do that. When you're ready of course."

Stevie gave a gentle nod and Agatha removed her touch so they could head inside. Stevie shed her shoes and hung her bag on the handle of the closet door before she soundlessly made her climb up the stairs to retreat to her room.

Finding some normalcy might have helped in any other situation, but as Agatha went about preparing Stevie a small lunch of bagel bites and grapes, something deep within her bones felt filled with unease. While the bagels were in the air fryer, Agatha produced her phone and typed out a brief but informative message to her wife.

"Picked her up and we're home now. She's not really hurt, but her hand looks a little bruised. Judging by the other kid, he didn't stand a chance. But... She's not talking to me yet. Gonna make her some lunch and give her some alone time. She seems really upset, but in that mildly terrifying way where she's not really saying anything. Whatever he said to her really pissed her the fuck off. I'm gonna work on her throughout the day and see if I can find out what went on. We love you and we'll see you when you come home."

Already aware that a timely response was unlikely, Agatha discarded the phone to the kitchen countertop and continued about the task of preparing her daughter something to eat. Although there was a 'no soda til dinner' rule, Agatha could not help but to swipe up a root beer from the mud room. It wasn't a reward, necessarily, but Agatha looked at that can of root beer and saw an olive branch.

Stevie had probably convinced herself that Agatha and Rio were going to be upset with her for a very long time over this. She had also convinced herself, at least somewhat, that she was going to be in trouble for an indefinite amount of time. The truth was, while punishment would be necessary, Agatha had yet to determine what that course was actually going to look like, simply because she did not know the whole story yet.

There was something else there, something that Stevie was wrestling with in a manner that Agatha had never really seen in her before. She was a good kid. She was actually an incredible kid, but the other kids saw her as a threat. Her grades were impeccable, she participated in sports year round, and she had garnered favor from a great deal of her grade because she stood up for those who would not stand up for themselves. 

Truthfully, she was any parent's dream kid outside of the fact that she knew the right times to defend herself and was not afraid to do so. Even then, Agatha was proud of that fact. It was what made this particular set of circumstances so vexing. This was being sold to her as an unprovoked act of violence, but that was not who Stevie was.

It was those thoughts that plagued her as the air fryer sounded its alert that it was finished and Agatha plated up Stevie's lunch. She could have called her down, could have made her sit uncomfortably at the dining room table while she picked at her food, pressured to eat so she could return back upstairs to wait out both her feelings and her punishment. That didn't feel like the play. Instead, Agatha ascended the stairs, tapping Stevie's door softly with her ankle.

When Stevie looked away from her movie, Agatha was smiling softly with the plate of mini pizzas and grapes in one hand and the can of root beer in the other.

"I brought you lunch. You can eat up here as long as you make sure to throw your trash away in the kitchen," she disclosed, pacing forward so that she could make the hand-off. 

"Thank you," Stevie told her, though her voice was still so small, so quiet. 

"We still working on it?" Agatha asked, knowing full well that she did not need to define what 'it' was so blatantly.

"Still working on it," Stevie agreed as she picked up a grape and slowly tucked it into her mouth, keeping eyes diverted to her plate.

It was killing Agatha to see her daughter so upset, so impossibly dejected. This whole thing felt insane, but only because Agatha knew she was in the dark and would be until Stevie made the decision to let a little light in.

"Okay," Agatha affirmed. "Keep working and we'll check back in here in a bit, hm?"

Stevie did not offer a vocal answer and chose a light nod of her head instead. Agatha bent at the waist, placing a soft kiss to the top of Stevie's hair, a statement made without a word spoken and turned to exit the room. Just as she was about to pass through the doorway, she heard Stevie's voice behind her.

"Mom?" 

With a hand on the frame of the door, Agatha turned around to face her daughter. "Yeah, baby?"

Stevie was looking at her this time, though her thin lips rubbed and worried over one another before she spoke again.

"I love you."

For some strange reason, given the context of what had unfolded that day, those three words and the way they sounded fired through Agatha like a lance, piercing cleanly through with no catch. She could feel her eyes burning but she blinked the feeling away after a couple of tries.

"I love you too, sweet girl. I'll be back up in a little while. Maybe try to rest for a bit." Agatha offered another smile rooted in comfort and turned to depart. 

Surely, she could find ways to keep herself occupied until either Stevie was ready to talk or Rio arrived home from work. That had been the idea, but after about twenty minutes, Agatha had climbed the stairs once more to simply crawl into bed and relax, soaking in still moments she would not have otherwise had without the earlier incident.

While she had mindlessly turned on some show about house flipping, she had tried to find a sense focus that fell away from Stevie in the poems on her phone. That seemed to provide enough comfort to allow Agatha to doze off, a nap suddenly on her agenda.

When she stirred a little while later, she was acutely aware of the pressure across her middle and on her chest. For a fleeting moment, Agatha was left wondering how long she had slept that Rio had since come home and crawled in bed with her. When she opened her eyes and glanced down, the dark brown hair she saw was shades lighter than her wife's and attached to a slightly smaller head.

"Sweet pea?" Agatha murmured softly, her hand lifting so she could run her fingertips through Stevie's hair soothingly.

What she realized as she came more into herself was that Stevie was trembling softly against her.

She was crying.

"Hey, hey, baby girl," Agatha rushed in a whisper, trying to find a way to encourage Stevie to look at her without actually adding any other physical stimuli that might agitate her or upset her further. "Stevie, baby..."

Stevie sniffled and lifted her hand off of Agatha's stomach so that she could wipe at her exposed cheek, the other pressed to a damp spot on Agatha's shirt. "I need one more minute," she explained brokenly, very plainly not having been in a state where she thought Agatha might wake up.

"Take your time, sweet pea," Agatha soothed, still providing the lightest contact by raking her fingers gingerly through Stevie's hair.

There were a few more moments of silence and while Stevie did not speak right away, she did move around enough so that she could pull herself up to a sitting position and turned to face her mother, crossing her legs in front of her. With one more wipe of her cheeks with both hands, she took in a steadying breath and her face set, her expression determined.

"I am ready to tell you..." she began, her voice just a bit stronger than it had been to that point. "But... You can't tell mama."

Agatha's expression pinched and she too was shifting, pushing herself up so that she could sit with her back against the pillows. Her eyes were trained on her little girl as she asked something of her she knew Agatha could never abide by.

"Stevie... You know I don't lie to mama about anything," Agatha told her, stating it as plainly as she could so that Stevie could truly understand what she was asking.

"Then don't lie," she tried to argue. The look in her eyes was telling Agatha something she wouldn't say: I need you to do this one thing for me. "Just... Don't tell her the whole truth."

Agatha softened slightly, lips twisting around one another in her contemplation. "How about you tell me what that whole truth is and we will go from there?" she offered in return, a bartering that would show Stevie it was worth consideration under the right circumstances.

Despite that, though, Agatha was a little tripped up by the idea that something had happened at school, something that had lead to Stevie kicking the shit out of a fellow classmate, that somehow could have involved Rio or would somehow upset her.

Stevie's lips puckered to one side as she chewed on the inside corner of them, her nerves clearly getting the best of her. 

Sitting up slightly, Agatha reached out and took hold of her little girl's hand, giving it a soft squeeze in support. "It's okay, Stevie. I'm not going to be angry with you."

Her bottom lip dropped and then quivered, that look in her eyes so unsure.

"You might be," she countered, but Agatha was having none of it as she immediately shook her head.

"I won't be. I just want to know why you were that upset. And I know it's hard to try to talk about, but once you do, we can make a plan from there. But... I have to know first." Agatha's voice was calm, it was comforting, and it offered Stevie the knowledge that she meant every word she was saying.

"I... We..." Agatha could see it as Stevie tried to start, the way her breath caught and her jaw tensed. There was a soft crimson that was beginning to creep up her neck, a sign that she was beginning to feel the anger that had impelled her to react violently toward another person. "We were in the library for study hall. And that stupid fucker --" Stevie's eyes snapped up in panic but all Agatha could do was smile, giving a light shake of her head.

"Seems to be fitting for the situation. No addition to the jar needed," she informed her, giving a light tip of her head to indicate that Stevie could continue.

"That fucker Luke Arrick," she stated, seeming a little more liberated that she could freely call it like it was, "I guess he saw mama at the pep rally in her scrubs and he... He said something really awful about her..." Her gaze dropped again to her hand wrapped so snugly in Agatha's.

"And what did he say about mama?" Agatha probed in hushed tones, fingers gripping a little tighter at Stevie's.

"He... He said that if he ever got hurt, he wouldn't want... He... He wouldn't want..." Stevie was clearly struggling to repeat whatever it was that this asshole kid had said to her and it broke something in Agatha. Stevie was not a shy kid, did not mince words. She got to the point and said exactly what she meant. For her to be so hung up on just repeating something this kid had said? It unnerved Agatha in the worst way.

"Take your time, baby," Agatha soothed, bringing her other hand up to wrap around Stevie's that she was already holding onto.

Although her chin was tucked toward her chest, Agatha could still see the very moment Stevie pulled her bottom lip between her teeth and bit down hard, likely an attempt to keep herself from crying over this any more than she might have already.

"He said he wouldn't want 'Doctor Dyke' to be the one to save his life!" she nearly wailed, her face crumpling in her anger as the furious tears began to spill down her cheeks again. "And I... Mom, I got so fucking angry. I know I have been mad before but... It didn't make sense. I heard him say it, I got mad, and then the next thing I knew, Evvie and Colby were pulling me back and he was laying on the ground bleeding." She reached up and was once more trying to clear her face of the dampness, knowing this time it was nothing more than sheer rage that was filling her.

It was immediately obvious why Stevie had asked her not to tell Rio. It was very plain to see that she wanted nothing more than to save Rio's feelings when it pertained to literal high school bullying. It was nowhere near the first time someone had called Rio a dyke from a hateful place, as Agatha had learned throughout the course of their nine year marriage, and it likely was not going to be the last.

It was the first time that someone had said it to her daughter.

Rio might have been passive, might have dismissed it or wrote it off.

Not Stevie. Stevie was going to defend her mother's honor at any cost.

"Stevie," Agatha said calmly, sitting up even more so that she could reach up to cradle Stevie's face in her palm. "I am not angry with you," she told her, leaning toward her to press a soft kiss to her hot forehead, still flushed red with her anger.

"You... You mean that?" she asked, her voice so small and filled with worry.

"I do," Agatha affirmed, giving a gentle nod to make her point. "I probably should not be, but I am... very proud of you. I know we tell you that physical violence is not the answer, and you will absolutely still be grounded for at least one week with no phone or Switch, but... You did the right thing. That being said," Agatha added, tipping her head forward so that she could pin Stevie with her bright blue gaze. "Do not do it again. I know that it's something we're going to bring up in therapy next week, but you know  it's never going to solve anything."

"I... I just..." Stevie attempted, a sure sign that there was a little bit more to this. "I had heard a rumor about his dad... He's some asshat on city council... And a couple of the kids at school have said that he's trying to rally support for a state bull that bars gay couples from adopting kids."

Ah, there it was.

Agatha had heard the stir at a much higher level, but there were very few people in the city that were giving the man any consideration. It had been enough to stoke a flame in her little girl, the little girl that was only hers because they had been able to adopt her from a shitty life that had been nothing but pain and struggle for the first five years she had been living it.

"And so... When he said that today... I knew it was true and I just... lost myself, I guess," she explained a little quieter, having found a way to sort through the emotions that had taken over her moments before.

Still cradling Stevie's cheek, Agatha simply smiled at her.

It was a calm reaction, a measured one, but it was also a very thick mask that was hiding what was going on in Agatha's head. Maybe violence wasn't the answer, and that was something she would have to keep telling her daughter over and over again. Agatha could do that by leading by example.

Agatha didn't have to throw hands to wound, though.

Having a homophobic little shit for a son was one thing. That homophobic little shit coming from a bigger homophobic shit who was publicly making it his mission to ensure that people like Stevie were staring at a much smaller pool of loving people who wanted to care for and love them? Maybe it had been something that had felt out of Agatha's control before, but now things were different.

Now, Stevie was suffering because of this kind of ideology. Now, Stevie was sacrificing her impeccable academic successes because she would not tolerate mindless and baseless hate, especially when it came to her parents. 

Agatha and Rio had been told by their daughter many a time how thankful she was for them, how much they had changed her life, and just how much she loved them.

Seeing Stevie distraught over issues that should not have been stowed in the minds of children because the hatred of their parents was pushing Agatha to action with each and every passing second. 

"Can you do me a favor?" Agatha asked her sweetly, that smile never really wavering.

"Maybe..." Stevie responded, her expression scrunching in confusion.

"If I let you have your phone back for a little while, do you think maybe you can find out his address from Evvie or Colby or one of your other friends?" The ask was inherently devious, but Agatha's tone remained light and airy, as if she were asking Stevie to find out what time the Bruins were playing on the weekend.

Stevie eyed her, the skepticism very clearly winding through her expression. "I mean... I probably can... But why?"

"Just wondering, I guess," Agatha said with a shrug but Stevie saw right through her.

"What are you going to do?" she asked, but even as she did, Agatha could tell by the look in her eyes that she knew her mother was not going to tell her the truth.

Agatha's lips pursed for a moment, her nose scrunching slightly. "Maybe mail him a box full of glitter dicks. Or something equally as gay and inconvenient that I just haven't thought of yet."

Although Stevie began to laugh, Agatha knew that she didn't buy it.

"Yes, I will find out councilman asshat's address so you can send him glitter dicks. Is my phone in the drawer downstairs?" she questioned, but Agatha shook her head, leaning over to open the drawer of her nightstand so that she could produce Stevie's phone. 

As she held it out and Stevie reached for it, Agatha pulled it back slightly. "One hour. No TikTok."

"One hour. No TikTok," Stevie confirmed, gingerly taking the phone from Agatha's grasp. "And I will let you know if someone can tell me where he lives."

"Thank you," Agatha returned softly, reaching around Stevie to pull her in for a hug, laying back against the pillows as she pulled her daughter with her. The speed and surprise of the motion caused Stevie to tumble into giggles as she settled against Agatha's chest, hugging her back the best she could.

"I love you so much, sweet pea," Agatha informed her, holding her just a little tighter. "And if we need to sign you up for Krav Maga or something, give the word," she added with a teasing chuckle.

"I love you too, mom." 

Stevie lifted herself up and leaned forward, pressing a loving kiss to Agatha's cheek before she climbed off the bed. She had almost reached the doorway by the time a thought struck Agatha.

"Hey, I know we're a little cavalier about it because of everything that happened, but... Maybe clean up that potty mouth a bit before mama gets home, yeah?" Agatha suggested, her lips curling upward in a knowing smile. "I gave you a bit of credit to spend, but she'll fine you up to the eyeballs."

Stevie giggled but gave an understanding nod. "I will," she affirmed before making her exit to return to her room.

When Agatha checked the time, she also realized that she had not looked at her phone since she had sent her earlier message to Rio. A response from about forty minutes prior to that moment was sitting in her notifications. She swiped down and opened it up, instantly warmed by her wife's response.

"Sorry, it's been a busy day and I just got the chance to check my phone. I am glad she's alright and I hope that she lets you in enough to figure out how we prevent this from happening again in the future. I know it's bad but... I'm just worried about her. On another note, I was asked to stay a couple of extra hours, so I should be home around 8:30 tonight. I tried to get out of it, but it's imperative. Johan is buying me dinner in thanks, so you both make sure to eat something and don't wait for me. I'll try to text when I can. I love you."

Her message back was succinct and to the point.

"You got it, chief. We'll somehow find a way to keep ourselves busy. Get home to us safe. We love you."

Rio was so in the dark and if Stevie got her way -- which, honestly, Agatha was a little inclined to give it to her -- she was going to stay that way, but she still just cared about Stevie. Rio had known, like Agatha, that something about this had been wrong. Maybe Agatha wasn't going to be able to delve fully into why, but she knew she'd figure out a way to communicate what needed to be shared and offer little more than that.

What was lending to her inclination to grant Stevie her request was that the more Agatha thought about that look on Stevie's face as she explained about the rumor she had heard (which wasn't a rumor at all), the angrier she got. Such blind hatred had always struck her as completely senseless, but making children feel so broken over such hateful rhetoric?

Making her child feel that way?

Maybe Councilman Dickhead's argument would be that 'children of straight people didn't go around beating up other kids,' and while that was an utter crock of shit, that wasn't where Agatha's fury was stemming from.

This man was not only spreading an agenda of discrimination and loathing by raising a child to have those same beliefs, he was actively being vocal about trying to instill a hurtful change in the very place the herself and Rio were raising a child they had adopted. That change impacted hundreds and while it was still in the beginning phases, enough that high schoolers still considered it to be a rumor, something had to be said.

Maybe it would be pointless, maybe it would yield no change, but Agatha's anger that had started as a simmer was getting closer and closer to reaching a rolling boil. 

A short while later, she had been washing her hands after using the restroom when she heard Stevie call to her from their bedroom. 

When she pulled the door to the bedroom open, Stevie was on the corner of the bed, looking down at her phone. When she saw Agatha, her head lifted and she held it up for Agatha to behold.

She reached up and gently took the phone from Stevie's palm, beholding the address that was displayed on the screen in a message from Colby. 

The moment Agatha read it, she began to laugh.

Entirely caught off guard, Stevie blinked up at her. Her confusion seemed paramount, but it took only a second for Agatha to collect herself so that she could explain.

"This is literally two minutes down the street from where I used to live before I met mama," Agatha informed her. She was still chuckling as she took a screenshot of the message and sent it to herself via text, alerted a moment later as her phone dinged in its place on her nightstand. She glanced at the time, noting that there was a little time left in the duration she had offered to Stevie.

"You have about twenty minutes left of phone time," Agatha informed her, her voice gentle as she held the phone out again. 

"Are you sure?" Stevie asked, her words quiet and uncertain.

"Yes. But you won't get it back again until tomorrow, and it'll be for an hour again. You're in trouble, but I don't believe in completely isolating you from the outside world, and I know mama would agree with me. Still no TikTok, though." 

"You got it," Stevie answered, standing as she took the phone back from Agatha to once more retreat to the comforts of her room. "I love you!"

"I love you too, kid," Agatha called after her. 

The moment Stevie was out of sight, Agatha was moving. She paced into the closet and rifled through her things, pulling out a black jacket and tank top before she relocated to her dresser to retrieve a pair of leggings. She did not have any actual intention of getting into a physical fight with this man, but she had a few choice words that she needed to say in his presence. If it escalated, though, she knew wearing something comfortable would not be the worst idea.

After changing her clothes, Agatha made her way to the vanity and stooped to look in the mirror as she removed her earrings -- better safe than sorry. Once that was accomplished, she snatched up a hair tie and pulled her wild mane into a ponytail a little higher up on her head. Perhaps it was her way of preparing for battle, for knowing that she had spent too long telling her daughter that fighting people was not the answer and yet still being ready to do what she needed to so that she could get her point across.

Deep down, she knew she would only prove this asshole's point by laying hands on him, but Agatha had come to adopt a new motto in the last decade: Be ready for anything.

With one last once-over, Agatha grabbed her phone and sailed off down the hallway, but Stevie did not miss her appearance as she tried to blow by her doorway.

"Hey! Where are you going?!"

Ah, the eternal question that got asked when one did not live alone.

Agatha halted and took a couple of steps back, appearing in the open space that led into Stevie's room.

"I'm going for a run," she lied easily, knowing that the clothing she was wearing might support it.

"No you're not," Stevie responded flatly, completely deadpan in her delivery. "You haven't been on a run in over a year. Not unless you were running from something. Like the neighbor's Malinois."

"That dog was a hellhound," Agatha voiced back, the disdain thick in her voice.

"That's not relevant," Stevie cut back, pinning Agatha with a knowing gaze that was almost a spitting fucking image of Rio when she delivered such a look. "Are you going to Luke's house?"

Agatha knew she couldn't be honest. But, she also knew she couldn't lie, not like she just had. Stevie had called her out on it; digging herself deeper into a hole with her daughter would provide no purpose.

"Yes," Agatha admitted. "I just... want to talk to his dad. Maybe smooth things over." Okay, she couldn't not lie, at least a little. She had maybe one minute intention of smoothing things over. Then again, she had half a mind to have him inform his son there was a round two on the way if he couldn't keep his mouth shut. But, she needed to at least try to be the bigger person.

"I'm coming with you," Stevie voiced, already climbing out of bed before Agatha could think to form some kind of protest.

"Stevie, no you are not," Agatha answered, but Stevie was already right in front of her, leaving Agatha's chin tipped back to catch her gaze. 

It was not the easiest thing in the world, being authoritative with a child that had a height advantage. 

"Mom, yes I am. If something happens, someone needs to be there to call the cops," she tried to reason.

"Stevie! There should be no reason for the cops to be called, even if you aren't there!" Agatha shot back, face set and eyes wide although she already knew she was going to lose this fight.

"I can stay in the car. I'm not letting you go alone." She was being firm, her arms folding over her middle as she shifted her weight to one foot defiantly. 

"You're not 'letting me' go alone? Miss ma'am, do we need a reminder of who the adult is, here?" Agatha posed, tipping her head forward in her interrogation.

"Mom, this isn't a 'I want to go to the grocery store and ask for random stuff we probably don't actually need' thing. This is a 'you're about to shred some homophobe and I need to make sure that he doesn't try some unhinged stuff and also, I am interested to see if you can make a grown man cry' thing. So... Please let me come with you?" Agatha would honestly give it to Stevie; she made a damn good argument. 

"Your mama will absolutely kill me," Agatha tried to offer, as if it would deter Stevie from wanting to be there as support.

"If she does, it's only because she knows how to bring you back. Plus... Isn't she supposed to be coming home soon? You don't think she'll find it a little sus to come home to an empty house?" Stevie's eyes were darting over Agatha's face, daring her to say that she would text a fib, but thankfully she didn't have to.

"She texted me that she's staying over a couple of hours tonight. So... If we get going, we can be back way before she gets home," Agatha explained. Maybe sneaking around in the name of personal justice wasn't the wisest move, but if it was the worst atrocity Agatha committed in her marriage? She was sure Rio would somehow find a way to forgive her.

"We?!" Stevie squealed back, clearly delighted that Agatha had given in. "Okay! Okay! Let's go!"

Agatha rolled her eyes, knowing one hundred percent that this was a terrible idea. She could possibly end up committing a crime in trespassing, at the very least, and now she was bringing a witness. She was an idiot, but she was an idiot that loved her daughter.

In a way, she thought it was only fair. Stevie had garnered herself a week long suspension because someone on spoken poorly of her mother. Agatha wasn't exactly hoping to catch a week in county lock-up, but she thought it reasonable that Stevie see with her own eyes that Agatha was willing to step up in a similar way to defend the sanctity of what family meant to them.

Rio was an incredible doctor.

Rio was such an incredible doctor that even if she knew what that child had said to their daughter, she would have still done her job with her personal bias aside and saved his life if he had needed it. 

Rio was Stevie's mother. 

Rio was so much of a mother to Stevie that their daughter had been willing to throw caution to the wind to lose herself in negative feelings that were produced at the insult to someone Stevie saw as a saint on earth.

Rio was Agatha's wife.

Rio was the only person in the world Agatha knew herself capable of loving so deeply and so wholly. Agatha's entire life had changed because of Rio's presence and now, the one she had was rich with the gold the lives the three of them were leading.

Rio was the forefront of their unit, the absolute best of them and both Stevie and Agatha would 'die on that hill' as Stevie had once said when trying to win an argument. 

A slight against Rio was defense worthy and while Stevie had used her fists, Agatha was ready to use her words.

They both loaded into the car and thankfully, for any sense of deniability, Agatha did not need to use the GPS to get them where they needed to go. She knew exactly where she was headed, no assistance needed. About three minutes into the drive, Stevie seemed to have noticed the incessant tapping Agatha had started on the steering wheel.

"Do you wanna listen to the Times New Roman song?" Stevie asked, reaching for Agatha's phone in the cupholder. 

"I know it's not your favorite because of the screaming," Agatha reasoned back, though she was still tapping her fingers on the leather.

"But it helps you when you're anxious," came her daughter's pointed observation.

"Alright, thank you," Agatha voiced, turning her head enough so that Stevie could hold her phone up to unlock it with the face ID, though her eyes never left the road.

As promised, the pitched guitar and heavy drums of 'And I Told Them I Invented Times New Roman' by Dance Gavin Dance sounded over the speakers, low at first but increasing volume as Stevie reached forward to turn it up. Agatha did not sing along, but she could feel the tension settle a little in her muscles. It wasn't like she was raring to fight, but the longer the day had processed and fell into its right places, the more restless Agatha had become. She had to say something. She couldn't keep going and not say something.

By the time the song was over, Stevie had made another selection, though she was keeping with the vibe by selecting something similar: 'Get Out' by Circa Survive. When she had started getting more into music that Agatha and Rio had listened to in their younger years, Rio had shown her Anthony Green and it had been over. Stevie said, the first time she heard him sing, that his voice felt like 'clouds in her ears' and that she quite liked the feeling.

The longer she continued to DJ through their drive, the calmer Agatha was feeling, offering a rational perspective to what she was doing. This could be a conversation instead of a confrontation.

That thought was laughable, but Agatha was going to at least try to abide by such an premise.

A few minutes later, she pulled up to the curb and cut the engine, turning off the headlights. Her head turned and cast toward the front door of the house, knowing in her heart of hearts that she should start the car again and drive off, not letting this asshole have the satisfaction of knowing that he and his stupid kid had impacting them so deeply.

Fuck it. 

Agatha was mad. Pissed, even. And she had something to say about it.

"Stay here. Lock the door when I get out. Do not unlock it for anyone that is not me. Got it?" she instructed, eyes dropping from the house to Stevie next to her. "And keep your phone up. I know I said there should be no reason to call the cops but... Better safe than sorry."

"Okay," Stevie agreed with a nod, pulling her phone out to have the dial screen open and ready. As Agatha opened the door, Stevie reached for her arm, giving it a gentle squeeze. "I love you."

Agatha's smile was warm despite herself, eyes wrinkling at the corners. "I love you too, Stevie. I'll be back in a few minutes."

She climbed out of the car and heard as it locked behind her. Her eyes fell one last time to the face of her daughter, her brave little warrior that was literally out there fist-fighting homophobia. It was all the confirmation Agatha needed and the final drops of fuel that propelled her up that front walk and caused her to rap roughly on the front door she found herself resolutely planted in front of.

The man that opened the door looked every bit the name Agatha chose to use for him; he was maybe an inch taller than Stevie, had that douchebag 'I look like I was in the military but was actually a draft dodger' haircut, a stupid pencil thin moustache and was wearing a stupidly colored pastel colored polo.

"Hi, Chad," Agatha sneered, causing confusion to paint his features.

"My name's not --" 

Agatha was not going to give him room to speak, even if it meant they would instantly be shouting over one another. Her hands were clasped in front of her, a show that she was attempting to be non-threatening, but one flew up to silence him.

"Don't care. It's come to my attention that my daughter beat the shit out of your son today," she indicated, her voice an octave higher than it normally in a sweet venom that she'd not used in some time. 

"That's your kid?" he leered, managing the question before she could bulldoze over him again.

"It is. My kid that I have raised for the last almost ten years with my wife after we adopted her from the shitty broken foster system you seem to love gobbling the nuts of," Agatha snapped back, her eyes flashing with her anger. "So, we can actually put aside the completely justified ass whooping sustained, if you'd like."

This seemed to catch the man off guard, as if he were stupid enough to think Agatha was actually offering any kind of truce. For as much of an idiot as she herself could sometimes be, this guy was an entire fucking imbecile.

"What we're gonna do instead is this: I can't make you stop your smear campaign. I can't make you stop spewing your hate for something you just don't care enough to try to understand. I can't make you raise your child to have sensible manners." The only reason she stopped speaking was because the man had started to step back, as if to close the door. "Oh, no, we aren't done!"

The hand that had been used to silence him launched toward the door, though she wasn't applying too much pressure to hold it open.

"You're insane. Who the fuck do you think you are coming --"

"Who the fuck do I think I am?!" she shrieked. "Before today, I was a mother who thought that the bullying her child was facing centered around normal high school bullshit like looks and weight. Right now, I'm a mother who cannot fucking believe that in the year 2033 we are STILL having to deal with children that are being raised to be hateful for WHAT?! What are you actually accomplishing?! Who the fuck are you to act that way?!"

"Enough!" the man shouted, moving to slam the door. Her hold on it was not enough to keep it from happening, but the foot she shoved into the open space stopped it from shutting all the way.

Agatha was also very aware that the moment her appendage was smashed between the door and the frame, it had broken somewhere, if not a couple of somewheres.

"You fucking dick!" Agatha howled, shoving the door back to release her foot, though she knew better than to try and lunge across the threshold to exact any form of revenge. "You can't handle seeing the truth that your hateful bullshit actually affects good fucking people and good fucking kids! You don't give a flying fuck about anyone but yourself! You--"

That time, when he slammed the door in her face, she didn't try to stop him.

"You're a goddamn coward! You hide in your fucking ivory tower thinking you're better than us because of who you fuck! And yes! I said fuck because scum like you isn't capable of love! And --"

"Mom! He's gonna call the cops, come on!" Stevie shouted through the window the had cracked.

Agatha knew she was right, but she was burning hotter than a bonfire in those moments, her anger surging only to detract from the sudden and throbbing pain in her left foot. "Fuck you, you cock monger!" she gave in one last shout of defiance before she turned to hobble her way back to the car.

"Mom!" Stevie trilled as Agatha slid into the car and shut the door, wasting no time in getting the engine running and throwing it into drive.

For a moment, Agatha's eyes were still wild as she drove, the sound of her heartbeat echoing in her ears. Stevie seemed to sense that she needed a moment to come down from the adrenaline that was surging through her veins. With a little over halfway crossed back toward home, Stevie finally broke the silence.

"Are you okay? I saw what he did to your foot," she voiced and while Agatha was focused on the road, she could almost feel that Stevie was looking at her in the dark of the car. 

"It was my own fault," Agatha dismissed, but Stevie was not as willing to let it go.

"Maybe, but you were limping pretty bad. Should we go to the hospital?" she asked.

Immediately, Agatha barked a dry laugh.

"I mean... We can. If you're okay with this entire thing unraveling and your mother sprinting through the hospital the moment she gets word that we're in the emergency room. But I would prefer to try my hand at an acting career, if you don't mind," she said, shifting in her seat enough so that she could find a new way to relax her left leg, one that wouldn't cause the throbbing in her foot to get worse.

"Yeah... You're right," Stevie decided, looking back out the windshield. "But mom?"

"Yes, baby?"

"You're the fucking coolest."

*****

That night when Rio came home, it was to find both her daughter and wife propped up in bed, watching a random movie that they were not paying attention to based on the giggles Rio heard in the hallway before she had come to behold such a sight.

"Well, hello my loves!" she chirped as she reached behind her to peel off her scrub top, leaving her in the soft grey tank top that she wore beneath it. She moved toward the bed, leaning over to press a soft kiss to Agatha's lips.

"Hi, beautiful," Agatha cooed, doing her best to slip into a cool and collected demeanor.

"Hi, mama," Stevie greeted, though her voice was a little softer, knowing this was the first encounter she was having with her mama since everything had transpired.

"Everything alright, then?" Rio posed as she slipped into the closet to grab a change of clothes for after the shower she took routinely after coming home.

"It is," Agatha answered. "Stevie and I had a very long talk about what happened today. I told her that she's grounded for the next couple of weeks. Movies allowed and one hour of phone time a day. No switch and no after school hang-outs until the sentence has been served."

"That seems pretty fair to me," Rio agreed, returning to the bedroom as her dark eyes fell to Stevie. "And how do you feel about that?"

"I think it's fair," Stevie affirmed. "And for what it's worth... I really am sorry. I made a very big mistake and I promise I'm gonna try really hard to not let it happen again."

Rio's expression softened. Stevie's words actually willed her to move, coming around her side of the bed so that she could kneel onto it long enough to place a kiss to the side of Stevie's head. "You're a good kid. Stop letting those dumb fucking boys get under your skin. And yeah, it was worth the dollar in the jar."

Rio removed herself from the bed again and declared she would return shortly before disappearing into the bathroom and closing the door behind her. 

Instantly, Stevie leaned into Agatha, resting her head on her shoulder. "Thank you," she murmured softly. 

Agatha turned her head enough to kiss Stevie's hairline. "Always, sweet pea."

The rest of the night had been calm and a little after ten, Stevie had departed to head to bed even though she technically did not have school the next day. She'd left with a kiss to each of their cheeks and a soft 'I love you.' The sound of her door shutting echoed down the hall and in the next instant, Rio was fitting herself under Agatha's arm to lean into her.

"So..." she began, turning her head so that the tip of her nose skimmed along Agatha's cheek. "How justified was it?"

Agatha breathed a light chuckle, her eyes fluttering shut. "It was justified. These boys really need to learn that she'd not going to take any of their shit. This might have been a good lesson in it, though."

Rio's lips pressed over the spot her nose had just graced, her whisper soft against Agatha's skin.

"Because we raised her right, hm?" Rio hummed.

"We sure did," Agatha agreed, though Rio could have never known just how much she meant it.

They started to settle in to sleep, but Agatha realized a very inconvenient fact. 

She had to pee.

She was going to have to walk to the bathroom.

Maybe Rio wouldn't look at her.

Agatha excused herself and was careful as she climbed out of bed, though she knew she couldn't restrain her gait or it would sound the bells of worry in Rio's head. She had thought that she did a good enough job on the way in, but the moment she crossed back into the bedroom, Rio was already staring at her, her question fired out before Agatha even registered that she was speaking.

"Agatha, how the fuck did you break your foot?"

"Break my foot?" Agatha shot back, scoffing in her absolutely faked incredulity. "I didn't break my foot." Yet, as the words were coming out of her mouth, she was limping her way back to bed.

"You say to a woman who has broken several bones in her foot. What did you do?" Rio pressed as Agatha slid back onto the bed beneath the duvet.

"I caught it in a door, but it'll be fine. I promise, it's really okay."
