Rio did not buy it, not for one second, but if Agatha wanted to be a big girl and suffer through, then that was her call. "When you're ready to let me look at it, let me know," she offered, her head whipping over to take in the sight of her wife, though she was wearing an ornery grin.

"Will do. But... The only thing I want you looking at tonight is me in the eyes when you tell me that you love me," Agatha suggested and while it was partially in jest, it was a underhanded request for exactly that.

Rio's hand raised, a fingertip catching just under Agatha's chin, their eyes locking in the space between them as Rio leaned forward to take a light kiss. As she pulled back, the gaze resumed and a small smile curled her lips.

"I love you, babe," Rio breathed at her.

"I love you too, Rio. I'm glad you're home."

Rio kissed her again then moved, settling in against the pillow, her weight against Agatha's side. There was quiet around them with only the TV droning on before them, Agatha's arm firmly around Rio's shoulders as the day wound down around them.

After a good ten minutes, Rio shifted, her right foot making contact with Agatha's left one, ripping a yelp right out of the deepest caverns of her lungs.

"Hey!" she whined loudly, brow furrowed as her head snapped over to glare at Rio. "You did that on purpose!"

"You're right, I did," Rio admitted, meeting her gaze evenly, though the grin she was wearing was completely dickish in nature. "So... You gonna let me look at it now?"

"Yes, Dr. Rio, you may now examine the patient."

Rio pouted for just a moment.

"I like it better when you say that when you're not actually hurt."

 

Chapter 31: One Shot - Igniting Dreams

"No! Agatha, don't!"

"Rio, I have to. She's called twice in a row, something could be wrong!"

On a Saturday night, it had felt safe to assume that Agatha Vidal could find herself hip-deep in her wife while the house was empty, their daughter having left for the night to sleep over at a friend's house. It was why, after an incredible dinner out and a couple of glasses of wine, they had come home to tangle in that too-familiar way. 

They had attempted to be idle for just a bit, trying to watch a movie, but it had not lasted very long. Agatha knew she had sobered up since they had left the restaurant in the back of a cab, and as it turned out, that was going to be a very good thing.

When Agatha's hips shifted back and the silicone appendage strapped to her body slid from inside of Rio's core, Rio released a groan so pathetic that it almost made Agatha laugh. That would have been a little too mean for the moment, she felt.

Before the phone could kick Stevie to voicemail again, Agatha managed to swipe up the device so that she could hastily answer the incoming call.

"Stevie? You okay, sweetheart?" she answered while trying not to sound as breathless as she felt, knowing there had to be a reason that her fifteen-year-old was spam calling her at ten-thirty at night.

She got her answer in the form of a soft sniffling, one that was followed by the saddest, most heartbreaking whine. Then, Stevie found a way to speak, but her voice was choked by her tears.

"Can you please come get me?" she questioned, her words so uneven as she forced them out. 

Immediately, any remnants of the lust and desire that had been lingering within Agatha evaporated right out of her, her stomach plummeting through the two floors beneath them. Stevie sound unbelievably upset and Agatha was not quite ready to delve into a round of twenty questions for a couple of reasons. The first was her given state of undress and the second was that any second wasted on a conversation that could be had later was a second longer that Stevie was upset and waiting to be rescued from whatever situation had her this unsettled.

"Of course, baby. You're still at Kaya's, right? You didn't go anywhere?" Agatha questioned, already moving off of the bed. She pinned the phone to her ear with her shoulder to free both hands in order to unfasten the straps on her hips. With a shimmy, it dropped to the ground and she stepped out of it, making her way for the closet.

"I'm out front on the swing. Do you think it'll take you long? Are you and mama at home?" Stevie asked, her voice small as if she thought she might be interrupting their night. She was, but she would never know that because Agatha never would have been upset about it, nor would Rio. Stevie was under duress and needed them. Agatha could and would turn up, time and time again.

"We are. I just have to put my shoes on and grab the keys and I'll be on the way. Are you... Are you safe?" Agatha decided to ask, knowing that asking if she was okay was probably a little stupid. She pulled on a pair of leggings and snatched a hoodie from its place on a hanger and paced back out into the bedroom, finding Rio propped against the headboard with a deep concern etched into her features.

"I'm safe," Stevie answered in a sniffle. "I just need to come home."

"Okay, baby. I'll text you when I'm in the car. I'll be there as soon as I can," Agatha told her, wishing more than anything she could simply fly there instead. Anything that would have gotten her there sooner would have been better at that point.

"I love you, mom."

Agatha stopped, halted at the foot of the bed, the weight of Stevie's words sinking into her. She sounded so upset and yet, she needed Agatha to know she loved her.

"I love you too, sweet pea. I'll be there in a jif. Bye, baby."

Agatha let Stevie whisper another goodbye and be the one to hang up before her attention settled on Rio, both pairs of lips mirroring in how they turned down at the corners.

"She didn't tell me much, but I need to go get her. I'll be back as soon as I can," she explained, though she had started to move again as she shuffled to Rio's side of the bed, leaning down to take a brief peck. They both had the understanding that she needed to get going and so with that chaste kiss, Agatha whispered a soft 'I love you' against Rio's lips. When she got one in return, she was on her way.

The force in Agatha's step as she barreled down those could have rattled the picture frames on the walls, her pace almost too quick for being almost fifty. She didn't care. Her little girl was hurting on a porch swing a couple of miles away and she needed to be there. She needed to see Stevie and assess her herself to know that everything would, in fact, be okay.

Agatha slipped her feet into a pair of Rio's slides (though they were a hair too big) and grabbed her keys from the hook, blowing out of the house to load herself into the car. As she had said she would, she fired off a text to Stevie and told her she'd be there in less than ten minutes.

Stevie wasn't aware enough yet to know that it was a fifteen minute drive. Agatha didn't care.

Her baby was sitting outside somewhere feeling upset and alone and there was no one there to help her. Agatha needed to be there.

It had taken her almost ten minutes exactly. Agatha had spotted Stevie from down the street in her approach. The porch light of the familiar house was on and Stevie was where she had said she would be, rocking back and forth on the bench swing to try and soothe the fact that she was very obviously in distress.

Her head lifted as Agatha got closer and she stood, swiping her backpack off of the ground as she fought to not sprint across the yard when Agatha arrived at the curb. Her walk was stiff and brisk and even though it was dark, Agatha could see that she was still crying. Stevie opened the door and threw herself into the seat. The door closed with force and Stevie was finished fastening her seatbelt before the overhead light even started to dim.

"Stevie..." Agatha started, though she tore her eyes away from her daughter to put the car in drive. She could sense that they needed to get as far away from that house as they could.

"Not yet," Stevie responded, her voice weak with anguish.

"Okay," Agatha returned in acknowledgement. She was quiet for a moment as she drove, but there was a force, one that compelled her to move. Her hand lifted and reached over, picking Stevie's up off of her lap. "I love you, sweet pea. And I know you're really upset right now, but it's okay. Whatever it is is going to be alright. We'll figure it out, okay?"

The only response she got, and the only sound that rang in the car for the next twelve minutes was the soft sound of Stevie sniffling or sucking in a stuttered breath that skipped through her nostrils.

Agatha watched for a moment when they arrived home as Stevie grabbed her backpack and unloaded from the car, making a beeline for the front door. Agatha just blinked, assessing the situation. This seemed... bad. Something had really gotten to Stevie and it was clear that she did not know how to appropriately process it. 

After another moment of pause, Agatha too got out of the car and returned to the house, not all that surprised to find that Rio had come downstairs to await their return. Also not surprising was the way she was sitting on the couch with Stevie in her arms. The sight would have been comical, given that Stevie was now a whole four inches taller than Rio, but Stevie was in too much pain for that to be the case.

Soft thuds sounded as Agatha kicked off Rio's slides and made her way to the couch to join them, placing herself on the other side of Stevie. Her hand fell to her daughter's back, smoothing over it in comfort for the next several minutes as she seemed to calm down. 

Finally, she leaned out of Rio's touch so that she could sit with her back to the cushions behind them,  both of her hands seeking out one of Agatha's and one of Rio's immediately.

Stevie gave another sniff, squeezing their fingers as she found her voice.

"I... There's something I need to tell you... And I... I don't know how," she admitted, her voice still quaky despite herself.

"Take your time, sweet girl. It's okay," Agatha soothed, leaning toward her to kiss the side of her head, though the anxiety was slowly creeping up her spine, wrapping around it like ivy.

What on earth could have Stevie so upset?

She was gripping their hands, but she was staring at her own knees, biting roughly into her lip. After drawing in a measured breath, Stevie started speaking again.

"I... It's just... I... I don't want to disappoint you," she attempted. Both Agatha and Rio went to argue this point, but Stevie pushed forward. "I think... I think I'm straight."

In sync, Agatha and Rio's heads dropped toward the couch and their eyes met around the back of Stevie's head. They were both fighting grins in equal measure, knowing it was not the appropriate time to be showing them.

But... This was wild in more ways than one.

Firstly, the idea that Stevie thought they would be upset made Agatha realize they still had a ways to go in getting Stevie to understand that there was very little she had ever done that had truly upset them.

Secondly, there was a tragic humor in the fact that Stevie felt the need to come out to them in a way that would have just been deemed normal by anyone else.

Thirdly, Agatha wasn't sure she had ever been so capable of loving her daughter any more than she did in that moment.

Somehow, neither of them laughed.

Instead, Agatha took an approach of discovery.

"And what makes you think that, sweetheart?" she questioned softly. She reached up and used her knuckles to collect some of the wetness off of Stevie's cheek from her tears.

Stevie sniffled again, still not looking at either of them, though Agatha could see her grip a little tighter at Rio's hand. 

"I... Kaya kissed me tonight," she admitted, her lip quivering as she fought not to start crying again. "And... And I thought I wanted her to. But when she did..." Stevie's words started to skip a bit as she tried to press on. She realized this and drew in a deep breath. "It didn't feel good like when Gianni kissed me after softball practice a couple of weeks ago..."

Well, shit. 

Stevie Vidal was out here macking. 

That meant another inevitable conversation, one they'd skimmed the surface of already. Unfortunately, this particular conversation was an indicator that a deeper dive was going to be needed.

"Can I ask you something?" Rio inquired gently, reaching up to tuck a couple of strands of hair behind Stevie's ear. Stevie did not answer verbally but gave a nod to still respond. Rio continued with such permission. "Why are you upset about it?"

It was a very pointed, very blunt question from Rio. Normally, there was a softness to her touch when handling emotional moments, but right then, she was reaching straight toward the root of Stevie's heightened emotions as it pertained to this instance.

Slowly, Stevie lifted her head and turned to meet Rio's gaze as she debated her answer.

"Because... I... Because I wanted what you guys have," she answered honestly. 

Again, Agatha leaned enough to kiss the back of Stevie's head, a show of her endless love and support.

"Baby, you can still have that. It doesn't have to be with another girl. It's the emotion that's important. You can still have the love, no matter where you find it," Agatha explained, lifting a hand to rub at Stevie's arm. 

"But... But I --" she tried to argue back, but deep down she knew Agatha was right. "I just... I wanted to be like you."

Agatha didn't need to look at Rio to know what was coming next. They both folded, wrapping their little girl in their arms as they embraced her from both sides. They knew what she meant and while endearing, there was also a weight to it.

So many children spent their lives thinking that being anything other than straight was an abomination, something to be ashamed of. Here sat their daughter, distraught over the fact that she thought she might never find something like what she had seen the last ten years of her life because she could not find herself to be attracted to girls. Something so many people never even questioned had Stevie knotted over herself. In a heartbreaking way, it was almost poetic.

"We love you no matter what, Stevie," Agatha murmured from where she had landed, head awkwardly resting on Stevie's collarbone.

"As long as you don't bring home a boy that listens to bluegrass. That's hindering on psychopathy," Rio decided to add, an attempt to pick the mood up a little that worked almost instantly. Both Stevie and Agatha tumbled into soft giggles, Stevie squeezing their arms a little tighter the best she could from the way they were both locked around her.

"Really, though," Rio added, loosening her grasp so she could lean back enough to look Stevie in the eyes. "We love you always and forever, no matter what. This isn't a bad choice you made, or something you did wrong. It's who you are, and we love that person until the end of time."

Stevie was quiet as she considered, but her voice was far stronger than it had been before when she found the right words.

"I don't know why I was so worried," she announced, voicing three thoughts at one time.

"We don't either," Agatha acknowledged in a way that Stevie could hear it and hear how much she meant it. Her hand raised to smooth over that long, dark hair. "I know it's all really confusing and honestly, we're pretty proud of you for knowing yourself well enough to tell us."

Stevie turned her head, those beautiful grey eyes finding Agatha's as the smallest smile tugged on the teenager's thin lips.

"Can we save the sex talk for another night? I would really like it if we could do a Stevie/mommas sandwich and watch a movie." 

Agatha had to fight her grin, trying to keep it subdued at the delight that tickled her from Stevie's keen awareness. She knew what needed to happen and while she knew that it would be inevitable, Stevie was also of sound enough mind to request that it happen at a time where she did not feel so paper thin in an emotional regard.

Instead, she was asking to crawl into bed with them -- which Agatha was sure Rio had already dutifully changed the sheets on -- and be the filling to a sandwich of cuddles and snuggles. 

The three of them had done just that. They climbed the stairs as a unit with Stevie breaking rank to go into her room so that she could change into her pajamas. When Agatha and Rio entered their bedroom, it smelled of strawberries and vanilla and nothing was out of place. The sheets had indeed been changed and Rio had made the bed again, the duvet pulled back as though she had known this moment was coming.

The three of them crawled inside, Stevie dropping down in the middle before Agatha sealed her between them. Quiet befell them before the television sprung to life with Rio's press of the power button on the remote. She handed it over to Stevie who was quick in her search, pulling up her ultimate comfort film.

And so, they laid there and watched Practical Magic with Rio and Agatha both cuddled to the sides of their daughter, heads brushing every so often from their places on Stevie's chest. They had both known about three quarters of the way into the movie that Stevie had fallen asleep from the way the thumping in her chest had slowed exponentially. Neither of them moved, laying in the stillness until the credits rolled.

Rio turned the television off and they both placed a kiss to the sides of Stevie's head before settling in to fall asleep, too.

The next morning, they all stirred around roughly the same time which was rather unusual, but not the worst thing. After lounging and reveling in the snuggles, Rio was the first to climb out of bed. When she did, there was a slight stumble in her step so when Stevie asked her question, Rio answered without knowing the real reason.

"Mama, are you alright?!" came Stevie's obvious concern.

"Yeah, of course. Stubbed my toe again."

Agatha had wanted to stop her, to keep her from saying those words, but only because she saw why Stevie was really asking that question. The cause for her worry actually stemmed from the purple bruise that seeped out from beneath the hem of Rio's shorts. It was an accident from the night before when they had stumbled into the bedroom and Agatha had aggressively backed her into the corner of the footboard on the bed.

Stevie's skepticism was like a ten ton anvil in her words. "You have a horrible bruise on the back of your leg because you -- oh my fucking GOD!" She launched up into a sitting position and Agatha was quick to follow suit.

Agatha felt like she had been dropped into a pit of lava without a moment's hesitation, burning from head to toe. She had known that the day would eventually come when they got caught up in that little white lie, but she had not expected it to be at eight in the morning on a Sunday.

"So this entire time you guys have been wobbling and limping around, it's not because you stubbed your toe?! You've been lying to me for ten whole years?!" she was shrieking in her incredulity, eyes wild as her head snapped back and forth between them. They were wearing matching grins that were painfully sheepish in appearance.

"In our defense," Rio tried to argue, though she was also trying not to laugh, "that's never a conversation to be having with a five year old. And once it started, it... Kinda got away from us a little."

"For ten years?!" she cried.

"Oh, come on. Like you would have wanted to have this conversation any sooner," Agatha goaded, poking a playful finger into Stevie's ribs.

"I mean..." Stevie began, but she slumped in defeat. "You're right but... Jesus Christ you two."

"Sorry?" Rio posed with her hands out, palms up, in a shrug.

"Yeah, yeah," came a grumble from their disgruntled teenager.

*****

It had been almost a week since Stevie's interrupted sleepover and while she had informed them that she and Kaya had smoothed things over, it had been obvious that it still sat in the back of her brain, a worry that she could lose a friend over something she could not help. It was so backwards and yet, that did not invalidate the way Stevie felt in the least.

What that night had also done was stir something in Agatha, something deeper than she knew how to vocalize. It was why she would sometimes zone out, staring off across the room while her mind ran laps over things she knew she could not control.

Stevie was getting older, but so were they. 

There had been a fleeting thought for Agatha, one that had happened a little more frequently over the last year or so. It was one that she dismissed every time, knowing the practicality of it was too far out of the realm of attainability. 

Sometimes, Agatha wished they had a bigger family.

It was silly and she knew it. They had Stevie and she was everything in more, but sometimes... Sometimes Agatha felt like between herself and Rio, all of the love they were capable of could have been caught when it spilled over from filling Stevie to the point of overflowing. 

There had been things they had done that had propelled the idea in Agatha's mind, keeping it afloat enough that it never truly went away. The main thing they had done in such regard was the bi-annual renewal of their fostering certifications. 

It wasn't like they were actively looking, but something in them had wanted to always be prepared if another set of circumstances occurred where they might need that credit. In ten years, it hadn't happened again, but they still benignly and routinely refiled every two years. In fact, Rio had submitted the paperwork earlier that year, giving them a fresh renewal.

Yet, edging closer and closer to her fiftieth birthday, Agatha was beginning to wonder if they had simply waited too long to decide to be active in adding to their numbers. Maybe they had been too idle over the years and now, they were getting too old to truly consider the idea. 

It had been nagging at her for a couple of days, but she had been doing her best to bury it and act like it didn't matter in the time she spent with Rio and Stevie. She shoved it into the darkness until she could pull it back out when Rio fell asleep at night. She knew stewing would not actually get her anyway, but they were feelings that had no 'off' button.

That Thursday night, Agatha found herself with her shoulder pressed to the doorframe of the game room, watching from behind Stevie as she ran through Lazy Lagoon with only three other people left in her game of Fortnite and the storm circle moving around the map. She wasn't quite cursing, but her grunts and repetitive 'ARE YOU SERIOUS?!'es were a showing of how invested she was.

Instead of warning her that Rio -- albeit a little late -- was on her way home, Agatha bathed in the amusement the display had to offer for as long as it took Stevie to clinch the win.

"Let's GOOOOOOOO!" she shouted, launching to her feet in her sense of accomplishment. 

"You kept your crown, I see," Agatha stated in observation, though her tone was laden with her subdued laughter.

"Six games in a row!" 

"Getting better and better," Agatha encouraged. 

Stevie glanced down at her watch, her brows pinching as she raised to meet Agatha's gaze. "Mama's late," she voiced, clearly confused.

"I know," Agatha responded softly. "She was held over at work a few minutes. She should be here pretty soon. But she did tell me that she needed to stop at the market because she was really craving cinnamon rolls, so I told her to pick up one of those take-n-bake pizzas for dinner."

"The kind with the garlic knot crust?!"

Agatha nodded in confirmation. "That's the one. She --"

Before the rest of the thought could produce itself, the sound of the front door opening carried down the hall and beckoned Stevie and Agatha into the living room to greet a spent and exhausted Rio who was clutching bags in one hand and a pizza box in the other. How she'd gotten the door open was a miracle in and of itself.

While Agatha made a direct approach, Stevie wound around her to eagerly unload the groceries from Rio's grasp, bouncing toward the kitchen with full hands to put things away and turn on the oven. It was a small and otherwise irrelevant moment where Agatha was simply reminded of just how much Stevie had grown and just how quickly life was moving on again.

For a split second, it made her sad.

And then, she kissed her wife to welcome her home and offered her the warmest smile she knew herself capable of. When she pulled back and truly got a look at Rio, she could see the weight of the day as it tugged on her, pulled her down in spots like her shoulders and the places beneath her eyes. 

Agatha did not offer a hello or offer in unnecessary pleasantries. She chose better and posed her inquiry in a gentle murmur, her fingertips raising to brush tenderly at Rio's cheek.

"What do you need, baby?" 

The moment the question registered, Rio looked like she was two seconds away from dissolving into a puddle of tears. Instead of saying anything, at least at first, she leaned in and kissed Agatha again, letting that one linger a little longer. Agatha could taste the remnants of a Red Bull on her lips with that more intimate kiss, a surefire sign that the day had been hard on her. Rio tried not to indulge in things like energy drinks, but they seemed to make those hard days a little easier to bear.

When Rio pulled away, her cheeks lifted just barely with her small smile. "I think I'm going to go soak in the bath for a little while until dinner is ready."

Agatha tucked her chin in a nod of understanding. Those fingertips on Rio's cheek pressed and slid, navigating around her ear to wind into her hair. Once they hooked into her scalp, Agatha pulled her forward and kissed her gently on the forehead.

"Go relax. Do you want some wine or bourbon to take with you?" she asked as she fully disentangled herself from her wife.

"A glass of bourbon would be great, actually," Rio conceded, her shoulders slumping a little further.

"You got it."

It took Agatha about as long as it took for Rio to shed her shoes and hang her backpack up in the closet to meet her at the base of the stairs, forking over the glass of bourbon with a smile and one last kiss before Rio departed up the steps.

When Agatha returned to the kitchen, Stevie was bent at the waist as she pushed the rack into the oven, the pizza placed perfectly centered on top of it, and shut the door. When she stood, her attention fell to Agatha and her expression seemed... worried?

"Are you guys okay?" Stevie asked bluntly, though Agatha could see a flicker of anxiety in her eyes.

Stunned for just a moment, Agatha took all of five blinks to come back into herself so that she could offer a question in return.

"What makes you ask that?" she returned, though her voice had taken on an intentional softness in her confusion.

"I..." Stevie stopped herself, her lips twisting nervously before she decided on what to say. "You don't really yell or fight... But this last week... I don't know, I guess it's just been... Different. You've been quiet and mama seems to be having a really hard time with work. So... I just wanted to ask."

Agatha could feel herself melting at the genuine worry her daughter seemed to have over them. At first, Agatha had started to think that she might be worried they were having relationship issues, but with her explanation, Agatha realized she was just relying on her observational skills and pointing out where things had strayed from the norm. At least, that was what it seemed like.

She crossed the space between them and pulled Stevie into a hug, though at this point Stevie was the one who was technically holding Agatha.

"Sweet pea, we're okay. This is just one of those times where life's a little harder than usual. I've just been spending too much time thinking about things that ultimately don't matter and mama is just..." Agatha paused and exhaled a soft sigh before she pulled back and looked up at Stevie, her lips turning down slightly. "This is one of those times where work is a little harder on her and really gets to her more than it usually does. Like always, we'll get her through it."

"Okay," Stevie returned, leaning down to place a kiss to Agatha's cheek. "I know it isn't my place... But I always just want to help. So... maybe we can go to Tides this weekend or something and look for shells on the beach. Just... to think about other things."

In ten years, Stevie had come miles from the terrified little girl she had been when they had met her. She grew more and more by the minute when it came to the art of being a human and truly, her heart was so big that Agatha had no clue how it could fit inside of her chest. She showed it more and more every day, but it was never as bold and apparent as it was when it came to her mothers.

"I think she might like that quite a bit. We'll put a pin in it for now and talk to her about it tomorrow. I think it might mean a little more if you bring it up," Agatha disclosed knowingly, her lips hitching up slightly.

"That's a good idea," Stevie agreed. She gave Agatha one more peck on the cheek and departed for the living room to turn on the television and wait for dinner to be finished cooking.

As if aligned by the universe, Rio came down the stairs at the same moment Agatha had finished slicing the pizza. Her hum of delight hit Agatha's ears right as she felt Rio's strong arm slide around the small of her back and her lips as they pressed to Agatha's warm cheek. 

"Thank you. I needed that," she murmured softly against Agatha's skin before ceasing the contact to fetch the three of them plates.

They opted to sit in the living room for their meal that evening, turning on a movie of Stevie's selection -- which, for some reason that Agatha nor Rio understood, was Baby Driver -- as they ate with very little conversation outside of the few times Stevie talked about her day or pointed out something cool about the movie. 

The night wound down and while Stevie played a couple more games of Fortnite, Rio had ended up laying across the couch, her head in Agatha's lap as Agatha's fingers raked gently through damp hair. They were simply listening to Stevie as she carried on through her headset, groaning and squealing every so often. Agatha found herself surprised when Rio spoke from below her.

"Can I ask you something?" Rio asked quietly, but Agatha's hand did not desist its movement.

"Always, my love," Agatha answered honestly.

"Are you okay?"

For some reason, even though Stevie had asked a similar question earlier, hearing Rio ask it felt like a Spartan kick right to the center of the chest. She had been able to play it off with Stevie as being dismissive and not delving into detail. Rio was not going to let it go so easily.

"Yes," Agatha answered in spite of that very fact.

"Okay so... Different question," Rio quipped in response. "And don't lie this time. What's wrong?"

Rio couldn't see her, and Agatha felt like that was a good thing mostly because of the sudden sheen that formed across her eyes. She didn't want to have this conversation. Not ever, if she could help it, but especially not right then. So, she tried to deflect.

"I could ask you the same thing. What happened at work today?" Agatha asked softly, tracing a fingertip along Rio's hairline behind her temple.

"Agatha no," Rio almost snapped in protest, though she made no immediate choice to sit up and stare directly into Agatha's soul that way she was so very good at doing. "Don't do that."

There would be no winning right then. If she kept lying, Rio was going to get more upset and her bad day was going to get worse. If she told the truth... Well, Agatha felt as though the truth was not going to accomplish anything outside of telling Rio, in a misleading way, that she was unhappy with their lives. It wasn't that at all, but she was not sure she was in a right-minded state enough to communicate that appropriately.

"It doesn't matter, Rio, I pr --"

"ARE YOU FFFFFFFF! OH MY GOD!"

Stevie's rage-filled shouting carried down the hall straight to them, causing them both to breathe a chuckle, but when she settled, Rio picked up the conversation again.

"It does matter because whatever it is has been bothering you for more than just a couple of days now. And it's not like you to not be honest about how you feel so just... Be honest with me, Agatha."

Agatha knew why Rio had not moved. Rio had stayed where she was because she did not want to be overbearing in a conversation where she was trying to get Agatha to speak on things she had been keeping to herself. That wasn't a typical move in the Agatha playbook and as such, Rio had picked up on it. Seemingly, she had even let it carry on to the point it had, with them arranged on the couch in a way that gave Agatha the tiniest upper hand in concealing her emotions, or at least the ones that would find their way into her expression.

"This weekend... And Stevie's coming out..." Agatha started, but they both stalled to snicker at that. "It's just..." she was catching, getting hung up on sharing something she knew deep down Rio was not going to judge her for. "It feels like we missed the mark on being able to... To do it again."

Agatha could feel Rio tense slightly in her lap, but she did not question it. Instead, Rio had a question of her own.

"Do... What again?"

"I... I just mean... We could have chosen any time in the last ten years that might have been reasonable to decide to give Stevie a sibling."

This time when Rio tensed, the only reason it 'went away,' so to speak, was because she sat straight up, looking directly into Agatha's eyes.

"You want to adopt another kid?" she asked, but it wasn't sharp or demanding. Instead, Agatha was confused over the fact that it sounded not only shocked but... Was that tone of voice Rio had just used... hopeful?

"I mean, not actively in the way that I considered it to be a bit past our prime, but... I have thought about it a lot these last few days. About not having done it sooner, I mean."

"Do you want me to tell you about my day?" Rio suddenly asked. The shift in gears caught Agatha off guard and her expression resembled that of a deer caught in a pair of headlights, stuck for a long moment.

"I mean, always," Agatha finally managed, not quite catching on to the fact that there was a tie-in there, something Rio needed to tell her to explain why her own mood had been rather somber.

Rio reached for Agatha's hand, pulling it into her lap before she began to recant what her day had looked like. "Last night, the unit received a new patient. He was born at about 6 last night and was immediately given up by his mother before she even gave him a name. He was born addicted to heroin and has a very long way to go in the next month of his life and now, he's alone in the NICU while things like social workers and case numbers are assigned to him."

Still not making the connection, Agatha was just watching Rio, listening to her. Agatha's silence compelled her to keep talking.

"The overnight nurse gave him a name so we would have something to call him by. She named him Phoenix, like from the ashes. Feels a little fitting," Rio divulged, her voice pained through how tender it sounded. "I spent the majority of the day assigned to his care. When I spoke to the woman with the State, she said that they'd likely send a social worker to talk with myself or Johan on Monday. These are always... tricky cases."

"So... He just... Is an immediate ward of the state? Because he was surrendered?" Agatha questioned, though the way her brow knit showed Rio that she was still working to connect all the dots in her mind. 

"He is," Rio confirmed with a gentle nod. 

At the same time, she gave Agatha's hand a tight squeeze. It caused Agatha to look at their hands before her eyes swept back up to her wife and that bleedingly earnest look on her face. It was at that very moment that the pieces of the slide puzzle moved into the exact right places in Agatha's mind.

"Rio..." Agatha breathed, her fingers tightening around Rio's hand as they rested in Rio's lap.

"We just renewed. And... And maybe, for some reason, it could not be the right fit but... What if we followed roughly the same steps? I mean, obviously there won't be the visits this time outside of an inspection, but we could... I'm not saying we have to... I just..." Rio was fumbling, struggling to find the right thing to say here that would quell them both. 

Rio's other hand moved to sandwich Agatha's between them, her thumb brushing over the back of it as she searched for more meaning and better articulation. 

"I find there to be something a bit... serendipitous about the fact that you have been feeling this way for a few days and then today, my day unfolded the way it did. So..." Rio paused, her lips worrying against one another for a moment before she pressed on. "It's there for consideration. No big decisions need to be made right this instant, of course, but should you decide that we should talk about this more, all you have to do it say something."

"Just to be clear," Agatha returned, her throat bobbing slightly in her pause as she tried to push the next words out. "You are saying that you'd consider the idea of adopting a newborn, right?"

For the first time since she had come home, a genuine and warm smile pulled up at Rio's lips and those dark honey eyes bore a shimmering of hope that Agatha immediately wanted to cling to.

"Yes, that is what I am saying," Rio answered, her voice quiet but firm in delivery. "Obviously there is a lot of leg work to be done. But... If you are not too hung up on the idea that we have passed opportunity by because of our age, there is one right here in front of us."

The hand that was not encased in Rio's lifted and cupped her cheek, thumb running carefully and intently along the shape of the bone there beneath her skin.

"We can do it again?" Agatha whispered, fighting the sting that began to occur at the backs of her eyes.

"If you want to," Rio affirmed, leaning toward Agatha to kiss her softly. "So. Just give it some thought. We can talk about it again over the weekend."

Agatha started to respond, but before the words could leave her lips to confirm that she would indeed think on it, Stevie breezed out of the game room and into the kitchen. She didn't say anything as she pulled a bottle of water from the refrigerator and tossed some of it back. Once she had replaced the cap, she turned her head to see both Rio and Agatha watching her from the couch, though Agatha's chin was nearly tucked over her shoulder in her effort.

"What?" she asked, blinking at them as though she thought she should be in trouble for something.

Agatha turned back to look at Rio, the silent question hanging between them. It was going to be best to just ask Stevie her opinions and thoughts before they tried to move forward in their own contemplation. This was her life, too, and she was three years away from graduating high school and going to college. That was three years that their time and attention could possibly be split between her and another child. She deserved to have a say.

Agatha gave a gentle nod, the silent conversation closing out as Rio raised a hand to flex her fingers, beckoning Stevie over. "Come here, kid."

Stevie paced over and sat on the edge of the coffee table so she could see both of them directly. "Is everything okay? You're not getting a divorce, right? Because I asked mom earlier if everything was okay and --"

"Stevie, baby, calm down," Rio soothed, reaching that hand over to land on Stevie's knee. "We are not getting a divorce. But there is something we would like to get your feelings on."

"Okay..." she ventured, her eyes shifting from Rio to Agatha who immediately offered a warm smile. She, too, reached out to touch Stevie's other knee in comfort, thumb brushing over her skin affectionately.

"Mama and I have been talking... About why I've been so quiet and about why she had a hard day today," Agatha informed her, not looking away from those gorgeous grey irises for a moment. "And those two things sort of overlapped. So... What we want to ask you is how you would feel if..." Agatha paused, her lips pressing for a moment as she tried to parse the best way to float it. "How would it make you feel if mama and I were to adopt another child? A baby?"

Stevie looked like she'd stuck her finger into an electrical socket for a solid ten seconds, the nervous tension settling over the two mothers like a wet blanket.

And then, Stevie grinned.

"You guys want to adopt a baby?!" She asked, leaning over her knees to look at them closer, as if this might be some weeks late April Fool's joke.

"There's nothing in stone, yet," Rio responded calmly, though she sat up a bit as she removed her hand from Stevie's knee. "But... There's a situation that could make it possible. And if we do choose to do it, we knew that we needed to know how you felt about it first."

Agatha had almost expected her to gush, to pressure them into it immediately. Instead, everything in Stevie's physicality softened completely as she leaned back. Agatha saw an air of maturity and understanding swirl around her for just a moment before she spoke.

"It makes me feel luckier than normal that you're my parents," she answered in earnest, a tight but sincere smile pushing up her cheeks slightly. The confusion that filled Agatha's face also filled Rio's but Stevie kept going. "You care enough about me to ask me how I would feel about you wanting to pour the love you've poured into me into another kid. You care enough about my feelings on something you know helped me when it comes to another child. I couldn't be luckier, honestly."

That pesky stinging had returned to prick at the backs of Agatha's eyes, but it was Rio's tears that spilled first, only made obvious by the way she reached up to wipe them away immediately.

"So, to answer you straightforward, I would love to have a sibling. A baby one, at that." 

There she sat, poised on that coffee table with the kindest tone and the brightest eyes as she delivered an impossibly mature response to a very weighted suggestion: Their little girl. Their little girl who was not so little anymore, both in size and in worldview.

Agatha scooted back, her hand lifting only to take hold of Stevie's slightly smaller one so that she could tug her toward the couch, requesting her to fill the space between them. She obliged, plopping into the spot between the two of them to be met with instant embraces and kisses peppered to her hair by Agatha and to her face by Rio, both of them squeezing her tightly.

"You say you're lucky, but I think we're the luckiest ones because we have you," Agatha informed her as she pulled back to look at that beautiful, gentle face. "I love you, Stevie."

She leaned forward, placing a quick peck to Agatha's cheek before she turned to do the same to Rio.

"I love you both. So... Now that this has been settled and you can consider objectively, I'm going to go play one last game before bed." She gave each of their knees a gentle pat and got to her feet. Swiping her bottle off the table, she strode right back to the game room to do as she had promised. 

After a moment of watching her in utter awe, both Agatha and Rio turned their heads back to face one another, a matching look of astonished bewilderment written on their expressions.

"That..." Rio indicated, waving a hand around in a small circle, "that just happened, right? Like... It was that easy?"

Agatha's grin was wide and bright, her head bobbing in a still-shocked nod.

"I think it was."

As promised, once Stevie had won yet another round, she had emerged and informed them that she was going to bed so that she could be up in time to catch the bus. Routinely, she made her way to them and offered head kisses and light hugs with soft 'I love you's before turning in.

"And one of you is going to remember to enroll me in driver's ed for July tomorrow, right?" she called over her shoulder as she headed up the stairs.

"Of course, sweet pea," Agatha answered with a laugh. 

She and Rio also decided it was time to tuck in as well, closing out the chapter of a less than exceptional day. They had left the door open and once Agatha had changed into clothing more suitable for sleep, they curled up in bed with the television humming idly in the background. 

It had been safe to say that the mood that night had been far too heavy to be conducive to sex, but that did not prevent the smallest acts of intimacy that were exchanged between them. It could be found in the way Agatha had convinced Rio to roll on her side to face away from her so that she could rub her shoulders, lightly scratch her back. It was in the twenty minutes they laid tangled in one another just kissing, whispering the sweetest sentiments that spilled down the other's throat. It was in the way Agatha turned to face away from Rio and Rio haphazardly braided her hair just for the sake of playing with it.

Rio had been the first to fall asleep, flat on her back with Agatha curled comfortably into her side. For a while, Agatha just stayed there, listening to the soft sounds of Rio's heartbeat. It was a song of what her life had come to be, a melody she could listen to until she went deaf. It was the reason for the rhythm of the steps she took when striding through life, the only beat she could ever march to perfectly.

It had not taken her mind long to skip the tracks, careening recklessly toward their conversation earlier in the evening. And then, it looped there, circling one thing and one thing only: baby Phoenix.

It was a grand total of a day and a half old and already, his life had been nothing but struggle. His birth mother's choices were now his struggles. He had been abandoned, given up as though he didn't matter. He was alone in that incubator the majority of the time. He had likely never known what it was to be held yet. All of that just seemed... so fucking unfair.

Agatha then thought about their capabilities. They could do it, no questions asked, but this was a new venture. This was something that they had not, actually done before. Stevie had been five when she had come into their lives. This was starting from the very beginning. This, Agatha knew, was sleepless nights and endless pots of coffee that she, too, would inevitably end up drinking. This was a lot of worry and concern and fretting over a child who was going to need a lot of special attention, especially in the early stages of his life.

Wide awake blue eyes lifted to the clock on Rio's nightstand to see that it was 2am. She was not going to find sleep any time soon. Knowing this, she pulled herself from bed and quietly made her way down the stairs to the kitchen where she turned on the kettle but did not go far, not wanting it to actually whistle in the dead of night.

Those same thoughts began to spin again as she watched the water begin to boil through the blue light in the kettle, the only light on in the kitchen. From muscle memory, she pulled down a mug, the exact tea she was looking for -- lemon chamomile -- and found an infuser in the drawer, though she didn't care which it was.

Once her tea had steeped long enough, she collected the mug and climbed the stairs again, though she did not immediately get back into bed upon returning to the bedroom. Instead, she paced over to the far window on the other side of the desk and pulled the blinds up so she had an unobstructed view of the small sliver of city outside the window.

The streets were orange from the well-placed street lamps and there were buildings here and there with a light still on in a window. Agatha's eyes fell to the street outside the house and like a freight train at full speed, a memory smacked straight into her.

It was a memory of the very first night she had stepped foot in that massive house. It was a memory that she had actually thought long lost to the disorientation the alcohol she had consumed that night.

It was the memory of Rio clutching her in the middle of the street while someone honked at them. It blurred around the edges the further she tried to take it, but just that snippet was enough to thump Agatha with a decent jab of emotion right in her heart. She blew at her tea for a moment before she took a sip, though as she lowered her mug she had heard absolutely no sound that would have alerted her to the feeling of an arm wrapping around her middle or the sensation of Rio's breath on her neck just before she turned her face to nuzzle into Agatha's hair.

She almost jumped, but knowing who it was instantly and that she was safe, she somehow stilled herself and lowered her mug to the desk. The newly empty hand lifted to rest on Rio's arm where it had landed around Agatha's middle.

"It's 3:30 in the morning, my love. What's keeping you awake?" Rio hummed in question, kissing at Agatha's neck, though the only thing she found purchase on was infinite strands of hair.

Agatha took a moment to feel this out. She knew the decision was already made for her, but she also knew it needed to be a full conversation between them. Her words still leapt from her lips, so quiet and nervous, not worried about the possibility of meeting a quick end in the form of a no.

"I want to see him."

Rio's grip around her tightened and she hooked her chin over Agatha's shoulder, tipping her head to rest against her wife's.

"You're sure?" she asked back softly, though no bit of her hold loosened.

"I know you work today... But if you think I can come by at some point, even if it's after you're off... I'l like to see him."

This time, Rio did let her go, but only to reach for her hips to turn her around. She didn't agree, didn't offer a time, at least right away. Instead, she just looked at Agatha in the dark shadows of the middle of the night with the most intense look of utter reverence on her face. Both hands lifted with a measured pace and cupped her jaw on both sides so that Rio could pull her forward, sealing any space between them out with a kiss that Agatha could feel was brimming with love and respect and so much more than Rio ever felt she could verbalize.

When she pulled away, her dark eyes almost black in their exhaustion, she nodded gently as if to answer Agatha's request, but she did decide to follow it up.

"Why don't you come by around 3 tomorrow afternoon?  Stevie will be fine here for a couple of hours once she gets home from school." She stole another kiss before Agatha answered.

"I can do that. It's Friday so only a morning lecture for me."

"Good," Rio returned with a sleepy smile. "So now that we've settled that, can you please come sleep?"

When Rio released her hips, Agatha picked up her hand and raised it to kiss at her knuckles before securing it firmly in her own, tugging her back to the bed. Her tea had been abandoned in her quest for sleep after her acquisition of answers to questions she hadn't been sure she could ask, but had found the courage to anyway.

It was a little easier, that time, to fall asleep with Rio pressed everywhere she could be to Agatha's back, her arm strong around Agatha's middle. 

By the time alarms began to sound, Agatha felt a little more rested than she had thought she would after only three hours of sleep. Somehow, that feeling didn't fade as the three Vidal women went about their morning routine that ended with Stevie getting on the bus, Rio kissing Agatha before climbing into her Acura to depart for work, and Agatha taking off in their SUV as well.

The lecture had gone as smoothly as most before it and by the time Agatha had arrived home around one in the afternoon, she had made herself a grilled cheese and decided on a shower before heading to the hospital to be there at 3pm as Rio had instructed her. She'd shot her wife a text message that she was leaving the house and yet, she was still the slightest bit surprised to find Rio waiting at the edge of the parking lot when she arrived.

She pulled into a spot and cut the engine, though she left the accessories so that the radio provided gentle background noise, sensing that Rio had met her for a reason. That was confirmed a moment later when Rio opened the door and slid into the passenger's seat. Without hesitation, she leaned over the console as the door shut so that she could deliver a soft kiss.

"Hi, my love," Agatha greeted softly. "Is everything alright?"

"Yeah, of course, of course," Rio assured her, reaching over to hold her hand as she turned in the seat so that she could face Agatha better. "I just wanted to give you a brief rundown. Johan got a call that they're actually sending a social worker around 4:30 today, just for a quick conversation, so I'll have to tend to that. But otherwise..." Rio's grip tightened, her teeth digging into her lower lip for a moment. 

"I wanted to give you some warning, before I take you in to see him. I know your history and what you went through with Nicky..." It had been years since hearing his name had made Agatha flinch, and while she still did not visibly react, she could still feel her heart squeeze in her chest. "So you're going to see him on a ventilator, because he was a little too early, and there are a few other lines and wires that are helping us take care of him, like the Methadone that's helping combat the Neonatal Abstinince Syndrome. We don't want him to seize or slip into withdrawal when he's still so little."

Agatha watched her wife for the longest moment and that purely empathetic look on her face. It was bleeding her understanding, oozing with her compassion. She knew what it was like the last time Agatha had seen a child so severely hooked up to machines and Rio also knew the end result of that and how, even thirty years later, it still rode around in the deepest crevices of Agatha's mind. 

"I'm really thankful that you met me out here to have this conversation," Agatha told her sincerely, giving her hand an affirming squeeze. "Because... I needed it. I mean... I had my own ideas, sure, but I don't know that I had the image I needed to in mind. I really appreciate it. And you, my love."

"Of course," Rio told her leaning to kiss her once more. "I just didn't want you to be blindsided when you see him. You will have to wear a gown and gloves, at least for the next few weeks if this becomes a more frequent occurrence."

While Rio had been kind enough to cater to Agatha, there was something else Agatha wanted to know.

"How are you feeling about all of this, Rio?" she asked softly, their gazes meeting again.

"In my heart, I know that it's going to be an easier go if we choose to move forward. And that makes it even more tempting to want to just hit the gas. But, you should at least meet him first before I go full-throttle."

That was honesty. That was Rio's bleeding heart honesty as it poured directly from her lips and landed in Agatha's ears, as if it would have ever been anything but.

"Well then," Agatha declared, bringing her other hand up to squeeze Rio's fingers her complete hold. "Shall we, my dear?"

With a bright grin and one last stolen peck, Rio retracted her hand and climbed out of the car, meeting Agatha around the front so they could enter the hospital, hand in hand.

Johan had greeted them up on entry, offering Agatha a gentle hug before they departed to suit up. Rio had helped Agatha tie the gown at the back of her neck before Agatha returned the favor. Once they had both slipped their hands into nylon gloves, Rio took her by the hand and led her exactly where she needed to go.

When they entered the NICU, seeing the incubators was already enough to cause an ache to wrap around her heart, but as they wandered further and approached one that drew her attention senselessly, it almost shattered.

"Agatha," Rio voiced in hushed tones. "This is Phoenix."

As Agatha approached one side of the incubator, Rio shifted to the other side so that they could both gaze down upon him with ease.

He looked exactly as Rio had told her he would. He was so very small and so very hooked to too many wires and machines. It was more heartbreaking than Agatha had convinced herself it might be. Two days old. That was what life looked like when it held doom upon entry. Phoenix needed hope. 

She and Rio, they could be that hope, couldn't they?

She needed to, at the very least, get through this before any large decisions were made. 

"He's beautiful," Agatha whispered. She loved his head full of dark hair, the littlest creases in his forehead. 

Agatha knew as well as the next person that all babies were ugly, but looking at him felt so impossibly similar to how it had felt to look at Nicky for the very first time. He was a newborn, yes, but to her, he was beautiful. His little arms shifted the tiniest bits and his legs would occasionally kick out. It was clear that he was fighting, obvious that he wanted nothing more than to keep going, even threaded and given no choice but to keep breathing.

"This is the calmest he's been all day. Fussy little bugger, but who can blame him?"  Rio informed her. 

While Agatha had not once torn her eyes from the baby inside that protective shell, Rio hadn't chanced looking away from Agatha in the event that she might miss something important. That changed when, for a fraction of a second, her gaze dropped to the opening that was about abdominal level in the case. Once more, they were trained on Agatha, but this time Rio made a suggestion and was locked in as she awaited the response.

"Because you're wearing the gloves, you can reach in and touch him, if you want," Rio told her.

Immediately, Agatha felt herself wanting to crumple. Rio shouldn't have given her that permission. Why? Because of course she was going to take it. There was no other choice than to take it. 

Agatha shifted over enough that she could comfortably reach inside. One of Phoenix's little fists was in the air and very carefully, she graced the back of it with the spot on her finger that would have been covered with her fingernail. He did not jerk away, did not startle. Instead, she could have sworn that she felt him press back against the contact the most minute amount. That or she could have been losing her mind, but the former was actually the one that seemed more plausible in the moment.

"He's so small," she observed in a whisper as his little hand began to swing in the most miniscule circles, occasionally bumping into her finger. Her eyes lifted to Rio, though she was still hunched over the incubator.

"Surprisingly, he was born at four pounds and two ounces. He's gained half a pound in two days, so he's doing a little better than we were anticipating." Agatha could hear in Rio's voice as she was wavering between her roles of doctor and parent. While she was not Phoenix's parent, she still knew what progress like that meant and Phoenix did not have a parent that could be proud over something like that.

Rio had started speaking again, but Agatha's attention was immediately pulled elsewhere as she felt another collision with her finger. This one did not move after impact. In fact, it grew. Her startled gaze went wide and dropped in an instant, taking in the side of that tiny hand wrapped around her purple gloved finger, clutching at it with all the might his little body could muster.

Before she could stop them, the tears formed and spilled down her cheeks. She should have known it could happen, but feeling it and then seeing it, in that order? Her heart was beating wildly in her chest, galloping away from her as that tiny little baby simply held onto her out of nothing more than reflex. 

"Agatha..." Rio murmured, watching her like a hawk. "Are you okay?"

"I am," Agatha answered with a nod. She turned her head, tucking it into her free shoulder so that she could attempt to wipe the tears away. "It just caught me off guard."

Rio glanced over her shoulder before she turned back to Agatha, offering a little direction. "I'm going to go grab us those chairs over there and we can hang out for a little bit. I --" She was meant to continue, but her pager sounded from her hip and she glanced down at it as she silenced it. "They just need me at the front desk really quickly. The social worker might be here a little early. I'll be right back, okay?" She turned around and snagged one of the chairs, bringing it back so that Agatha sit while keeping contact with Phoenix.

Agatha simply sat there, enchanted by the sight of the infant before her, even when he let go of her finger to start swinging his hand around again. She shifted a little, scooting forward so that she could reach in a little further to run a fingertip along his cheek. His head could not move due to the ventilator, but the way his fists moved a little more frantically indicated that he sensed it. 

She almost wanted to talk to him but for once, she wasn't sure what to say. She couldn't make promises that he would be loved and taken care of because those decisions had not been etched into granite just yet. There was a lot to consider, a lot to truly think about when it came to choosing that responsibility.

Agatha knew that it was likely going to take them time without some undeniable sign or act of divine intervention.

As it turned out, 'ask and ye shall receive' was an adage Agatha could live by that day.

The door to the NICU opened again and Rio appeared in the doorway, practically grinning from ear to ear as Agatha gingerly retracted her hand to look back over her shoulder. 

"It was the social worker," Rio informed her. "She just wants to see him for a visual assessment really quickly," Rio informed Agatha, but it was clear that something about this situation had filled her with an intense giddiness that was begging to break her apart.

When she stepped forward and the social worker appeared in the doorway in her wake, Agatha felt like she could have passed out on the spot.

Her blonde hair had garnered a considerable amount of grey in the last ten years and, like Agatha and Rio, the lines of life had etched into her face. Her hazel eyes were still bright and her smile was still as pacifying and calming as ever.

"Nicole?!" Agatha nearly gasped, but before she could leap to her feet, they were both making their way over.

"Hi, Agatha. It's so good to see you again."

Agatha stood, but just to offer a warm hug to the social worker before she placed herself back in the chair, dutiful in the position she had taken up next to the incubator.

"What are the odds?" Agatha mused, leaning back to look up at the two other occupants. 

"That's exactly what I said," Rio voiced with a chuckle. 

"I'll be quick. I've already got the diagnostic sheet from the other doctor, but I just need a quick peek at him." Nicole had always offered an aura of comfort and warmth, but it seemed so impossibly prominent right then. Agatha had started to scoot the chair back, but Nicole dismissed her quickly. "No need for that, I can go around," she assured her and did just that.

Both Agatha and Rio watched with a forming vested interest as Nicole looked him over. "And you said the low dose of the Methadone seems to be helping?" she posed, scribbling something in her small notebook.

"Yeah, he seems to be handling it well enough. No withdrawal symptoms yet, so we're hoping to keep him on that track." Rio was right back into doctor mode, talking facts and symptoms and being as informative as she could be.

"Good, good," Nicole offered back, taking one last sweep over him before righting herself. "Well, that was all I needed for today, but I'll probably be back again on Monday for a follow-up."

"I'm here until 5 on Monday," Rio offered with a light smile that Nicole acknowledge with a nod, but her gaze quickly fell upon Agatha. "Do you think I might see you as well?"

Agatha knew what she was asking and she knew what it was going to mean if she said yes. Her nervous blue gaze cut to Rio who looked as patient and serene as ever with a look in her eyes that said 'You are a grown woman and you make your own choices,' despite knowing it was a joint decision to be made. Perhaps that was Rio's answer in and of itself right then and there.

Slowly, Agatha's attention turned back to Nicole and she gave a light nod of her head. "Most likely, yeah."

"Good. Rio updated me a bit on Stevie but we will definitely have to catch up more. Please do tell her I said hello," Nicole offered as she began to move, heading back toward the door.

"We will!" Rio called after her.

"Always a pleasure, Nicole!" Agatha followed up.

When the door to the NICU shut behind the social worker, Rio was moving quick enough to grab the other chair and place herself next to Agatha. Her hand was back inside the hole, this time with her finger curled around Phoenix's wrist.

They were both absorbed in a silent reverence as they watched him, those tiny movements growing fewer and further between as he dozed off. He had been asleep for a good ten minutes before Rio decided to shatter the still and almost eerie quiet around them.

"We're going to do it, aren't we?" she asked, hope gracing her tone. Agatha wouldn't have told her no in any reality, but the way she asked that question would have made it impossible if she had tried.

"I wasn't sure," Agatha admitted, turning her head so that she could look to her wife, her lips twisting for a moment before she found her voice again. "And then I thought, what if there was a sign? What if something just... told me this had to happen? And then in you walk with Nicole."

Rio chuckled softly at her side. "Yeah, that felt like a pretty big shock to the system when she was the one standing there."

"So... Yes, my love, we are going to do it."

*****

The following three weeks had been busy ones for the Vidal women. When they weren't working or at school or visiting Phoenix, or Nix as they had taken to calling him -- which Stevie asked with frequency that they do after the first time she had been permitted to meet him and had gained fifty stars in her eyes -- it was all hands on deck getting the room down the hall from Stevie's converted into a nursery. 

Jungle animals had been the theme and between the olive green walls, the mobile with tigers and lions and panthers, the dark patterned rocking chair in the corner, and blankets that matched the mobile, it had come together perfectly in the time they had taken to get it put together.  Stevie had been a tremendous help in putting things together, apparently having paid attention all the time Rio showed her how to work with tools.

She was also a phenomenal hand when it came to reaching into high spaces. That was always going to come in handy.

Toward the end of the three weeks, several things were set to happen.

Nix would be ready to be released from the hospital.

Because they already had their certifications, he was going to be released directly into their care. 

With the way Nicole had laid things out for them, the timeline would be notably shorter than it had been with Stevie by a good three months. They had to foster him for six months and then, the legal adoption could happen. Rio seemed to understand a bit more of the nuance to it than Agatha did, but she had broken it down for her once they had gone home that night. 

Agatha and Stevie had been allowed to be present when they had taken him off the ventilator and while Agatha had managed to keep those emotional tears from breaking free, both Rio and Stevie had not. That had almost done it for Agatha, but she had still managed to shove the urge down, too overcome by the need to be the rock for her family.

Her family that was going to grow by one within days.

The reports had been an every day thing, but the seemed to get better and better each day, more and more enthusiasm showing in Rio with each update.

Nicole had come by a couple of days before Nix was set to be discharged to do the inspection. She had voiced how impressive the work they had done on such short notice had turned out. Before they had headed back downstairs, though, she asked to see the greenhouse for old time's sake. Still just as amazed as she had been ten years ago, she was grinning from ear to ear when Rio offered her to choose a flower to take home with her. 

"The violets are my favorite," Stevie had informed her brightly and it seemed to be all she had needed to hear to make her decision.

"You've got good taste," Nicole had assured her as the four of them migrated down to the entryway so that she could be on her way.

"Well, we will see you on discharge day?" Rio posed, her voice rich with how eager she was to step into a new facet of their lives.

"Yep!" Nicole chirped back. "Everything looks good, as it always has, so I will be there that morning to sign off on everything."

"Thank you again, Nicole. I don't know how we got so lucky twice, but I have learned to not question any miracles," Agatha voiced, stepping forward to offer her a hug. Before Rio could copy the action, it was Stevie who stepped in first.

"It's really nice seeing you," Stevie told her as she let her go to step back.

"You have no idea how good it is to see you, Stevie," Nicole informed her with a warm smile before she turned to hug Rio, too. 

They shared one last round of goodbyes and the three of them were left in a home now meant for four.

It had been easy to exist that way, knowing what was coming. Those last few days passed and finally, they had reached a save point on their race to the finish line. 

They had all arrived at the hospital that morning, with Rio having scheduled to have the day off. Stevie had agreed to wait in the car, ready to help fasten in the car seat the moment they returned with Phoenix. She had clearly wanted to reduce the amount of chaos that was going to be threaded into the art of getting him from point a to point b, and it had been appreciated.

The moment they emerged, though, the car seat secured in the crook of Agatha's elbow, Stevie all but leapt out of the car, running around so that she could help fasten him in. While she hadn't been able to contribute a great deal to the overall effort, this was one thing she could have when it came to helping out.

Agatha carefully placed the car seat inside, rear facing, and stepped back to allow Stevie to execute the knowledge she had gleaned from watching countless YouTube videos on how to safely and securely fasten in a carseat. Although Agatha was confident in her abilities, she could not help but to give it a gentle pull to check, satisfied with Stevie's work.

"Good job, sweet pea," Agatha commended, grinning up at her daughter as she shut the car door.

"I can't believe we're really bringing him home," Stevie gushed, surging forward to give Agatha a tight hug around the middle. 

"Me either, baby girl. Now go on, your side!" Agatha instructed, turning to climb into the driver's seat herself. Rio was already secured into her spot in the passenger's seat, though the grin she had been wearing all morning hadn't faded in the least.

The majority of the day had been devoted into getting Nix settled in and making any minor adjustments that needed to be made. For the time being, he would be sleeping in the bassinet that had been placed in their bedroom, but the nursery being done was still something that had opened up a handy space for them to have. The bassinet was light and could be moved with ease, so it would be no issue to relocate if needed. For the time being, having him close seemed like the best option.

Stevie had been the one to make dinner that night, serving up a delicious batch of stir fried vegetables over fried rice. They had opted to eat in the living room, as it was more manageable with Nix in his carrier. 

When they had finished, Stevie had placed herself at the edge of her chair, her eyes dropping to where the carrier was resting on the table.

"Can I... Can I hold him?" she asked, her tone quiet and bordering on timid.

"Of course. Do you remember when you held Ronin's little sister for the first time a few years ago? It's kinda like that," Rio told her, scooting forward so that she could remove Nix from the carrier, cradling him in his arms in the form of an example. "You want to make sure you support his head at all times, okay?"

"Got it," Stevie affirmed, holding her arms out to receive the gift that was her new little brother. Rio was gentle in her delivery, letting him settle carefully into Stevie's arms. Once he was secure and Rio felt comfortable, she scooted back to relax a little, her expression lighting up when she got the chance to fully take him in.

"Hi, handsome little guy," she cooed at him, running a featherlight fingertip down his small nose. "I'm your big sister. And I feel like we have some wild times ahead of us."

From her place on the couch, Agatha was absolutely locked in without any chance of distraction. She was watching as their lives started to bloom all over again, fixated on the image of their fifteen-year-old daughter as she cradled her month old little brother in her arms, completely smitten with him.

She was so locked in that when Rio placed a hand on her knee, she nearly jumped out of her skin, cutting to her wife for just a moment only to realize that Rio had established the contact without looking away from Stevie. She squeezed softly and Agatha was quick to cover Rio's fingers with her palm, offering a squeeze of her own. 

"Have you thought about what middle name you'll give him when you officially adopt him?" Stevie questioned, actually startling them both that time.

They glanced to one another for a moment and in sync, shook their heads.

Stevie's answer was almost so immediate that it actually sent sparks over Agatha's skin.

"I think it should be Nicholas."

Agatha's lips pressed tightly and then pulled back into a smile, however pained and touched it was.

"I think that's an amazing idea, Stevie," Agatha responded.

"I do too," Rio added softly, a warm smile finding her own features.

They'd spent most of the evening convened in the living room doting over the new addition, but the sun had set and the moon had ascended to its throne in the night sky, a sign for the occupants of the Vidal household to turn in. 

Agatha had been holding Nix to her chest as Stevie stopped outside of her doorway, her eyes dropping to the baby in her mother's arms in a way that asked her to still in her stride for just one moment. When she did, Stevie leaned down and pressed a soft kiss to the top of his head.

"Goodnight, little brother," she breathed before she stood to place a kiss to Agatha's cheek, and then Rio's. "Goodnight, moms. I love you."

"We love you."
"We love you."

It was a harmony for the ages, one they did not know Stevie would never tire of hearing.

The two of them paced down the hall to their room and Agatha headed straight for the bassinet, deliberate in her intentionally careful movements as she lowered Nix to the padded top. Surprisingly, he did not stir, not even as Rio approached her side and draped the baby blanket they had gotten him over his little body.

Her hand had landed on the small of Agatha's back as they both peered down at a very new and very beautiful chapter of their lives.

Stevie was their daughter and always would be.

Phoenix was their son, starting that day, and lasting forever all the same as his sister.

"We did it," Rio whispered from her place beside her wife.

"That we did. All over again. Feels pretty... cyclical in the best way, doesn't it?" Agatha murmured. Finally, she tore her eyes from the sleeping baby and looked to Rio, blue eyes filled with every ounce of emotion she had been harboring over this second round of choosing a child.

"It's a cycle I never want to end, so long as you're the one I'm doing it with," Rio answered as she turned to meet Agatha head-on.

"That's something you can depend on always."

"As you always have been, my love."

 

Chapter 32: One Shot - Yeah, I Think I Love You For It

It was 2am. 

On a Tuesday morning.

It had been at least three weeks since Agatha or Rio had gotten more than a few hours of sleep of sleep. It had been two months since they had brought Nix home from the hospital and while Agatha had been of sound enough mind to know what they were getting themselves into, she had not been braced for just how taxing raising a newborn actually was.

It wasn't that she didn't remember; those first few months of Nicky's life were as fresh in her mind as ever, but Nix came with special conditions. He had to be given medicine that made him miserable, even if they were weaning him off of it the longer they went. His body needed to be kept around a specific temperature which meant bundling him well enough to prevent it from dropping. 

More than that, unfortunately, was his most recent bout of sickness. The cough he had developed had put Rio, of all people, on edge and that was concerning enough in its own right. Rio had spent the better part of her life as a doctor and while she was well equipped at knowing the more medical side of things, seeing her worried had been the most unsettling experience that Agatha could recall enduring.

Dealing with the way Nicky had been sick was one thing; he had been older, more cognizant and able to understand that something was wrong. With Nix, he couldn't speak or tell them how they could help him. All he could do was cry.

And cry.

And cry even more at 2am.

Rio had taken the day before off -- after having taken the previous Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday off -- but they were both set to go to work that Tuesday, leaving him with the well-vetted daycare they had settled on. That was not going to be an option. Sleeping a few hours was one thing, and it could be helped with caffeine, but that night they had yet to even lay down.

Agatha was pacing back and forth between the closet and the end of the bed, bouncing Nix gently in her arms as he screamed and she hummed some made-up tune simply because nothing she sang was actually working. He likely couldn't even hear it over the sounds of his own frustration and pain.

"I'm going to have to call off again," Rio voiced with a soft sigh, pressing her fingers to her forehead to try and soothe the ache that was being induced by the lack of sleep coupled with their son's wailing.

"No, it's okay. I'll take the hit on this one," Agatha voiced back, trying not to speak too loudly but finding it impossible to not raise her voice to be heard over Nix's dissatisfaction. "I can just email for a sub and --"

"Or," came a third voice from the doorway, a tired-looking Stevie leaning against the frame. "We can just all call off and I can handle him for the day while you both get some much needed sleep."

Agatha's head had whipped up as she stationed herself near the foot of the bed, but she had not stopped bouncing the unhappy infant in her arms. Her brow pinched tight; an immediate dismissal was on the tip of her tongue, but before she could offer it, she felt Rio reach up from where she was sitting at the edge of the mattress and touch her arm lightly.

Her exhausted blue gaze hesitated on Stevie; this was not her responsibility and the idea of letting her skip school to make it her duty did not immediately settle well with Agatha. Her protest was interrupted and she looked down to her wife, a bit put-off to the idea before it was even discussed.

"Is it the worst idea?" Rio asked her, sagging in defeat. 

Agatha got it; they'd had maybe 20 hours of sleep in the last week, and neither of them had even attempted to close their eyes that night. But the idea of Stevie staving off her education to handle a very grown up task felt like they were asking too much of her. It felt unfair.
