This was something she and Rio had decided to do and while Stevie was always an amazing help, Agatha had to wonder if there was a line that shouldn't be crossed.

"She's a kid, she didn't choose this," Agatha countered, and while she was trying to be on the quieter side, Stevie had still heard her.

"You're right. But I encouraged you both to make the choice. I have almost perfect attendance except for the kidney stone right before Christmas break and that was obviously excused." She had started into the room, having no desire to shout over the sound of her brother crying. "You're not asking me to do this, I am volunteering because you're both going to collapse if you don't at least try to get eight hours of sleep. Your bodies need rest."

Stevie dropped her grey gaze to Rio, her brows raising in emphasis. "You of all people know I'm right. You're both mentally and emotionally and physically exhausted. So let me help."

"But you obviously haven't slept tonight, either," Agatha tried to argue, but Stevie's gaze snapped up to her and narrowed slightly. It was apparent that she did not understand why Agatha was fighting her so hard.

"I got a few hours, I'll be okay," came Stevie's easy dismissal. She was observing, watching the two of them as they held a silent exchange between them. After giving it long enough, she held her hands up in soundless request that her mother hand over the fussy baby.

Agatha's attention turned to Stevie and her lips pressed hard in her contemplation. She didn't like it. It didn't feel like the best decision, but she knew that Stevie was right, no matter how much they hated it. Yes, this was something they had agreed to do. Yes, they were doing everything they could to make it work. Yes, they had friends and loved ones and people they could call that could help out, but it felt like their responsibility and no one else's, not even Stevie's.

Yet, there Stevie stood with her arms outstretched offering them reprieve when they had been trying for so long to struggle on their own. 

"Mom," she requested, her voice a little harder. She didn't need to keep going, didn't need to elaborate. 

The very second Agatha felt Rio's fingertips on her arm again, she knew there was no more holding out. With a sigh that only indicated the disappointment she felt in herself, Agatha handed Nix over, settling him easily in Stevie's cradled hold.

"I'm gonna take him to the nursery and shut the door. You can shut yours, too, and get some sleep. Please. Seriously, you both need it."

For just a moment, there was a slight ripple of indignance that washed through Agatha's being as she considered the situation at hand: Stevie was absolutely being the parent in this instance and it didn't feel fair. She knew that trying to argue such a point wasn't going to accomplish anything and so, Agatha gave a gentle nod of acknowledgement. 

With a tired but accomplished smile, Stevie stepped forward and angled her body so that she could duck down enough to kiss Agatha on the cheek before leaning to kiss the side of Rio's head.

"I love you guys. Please get some sleep," she managed loud enough to be heard before she disappeared through the doorway and pulled the door closed behind her.

Agatha was still staring at it, as if she could see through it as Stevie wandered down the hallway to the nursery to try and quell her agitated sibling. She was plucked straight from those thoughts when she felt Rio take hold of her hand, causing her attention to shift and land on her wife.

"I know you're upset," Rio voiced quietly, her thumb brushing over Agatha's knuckles lovingly. "But she just wants to help. And... She's old enough that I think it's okay to let her."

Agatha considered this for a beat; Rio wasn't wrong but it didn't feel right either. It felt like shirking their duty of care onto their other child, as if it was the only option. It wasn't, but as it turned out, the Vidal women were not the best at asking for outside assistance. They could as in, they were capable, but between the three of them, there was a developed stubbornness that was unrivaled.

With a light tug to Agatha's hand, a new tenderness filled Rio's eyes. "Lay down with me, my love," she beseeched in the quietest whisper. 

Carefully and without haste, Agatha slipped from Rio's hold and raised her palm to cradle her wife's cheek, her thumb caressing the slight curve of her cheekbone. Before she heeded such a call, Agatha bent at the waist and pressed her lips softly to Rio's, her final white flag in the matter. Concession was -- and had always been -- hard for Agatha, and while she'd made progress throughout the last ten years, this had felt different.

This was watching Stevie grow up, and Agatha realizing that she had to let her.

When the kiss separated, they were both moving at the same time with Rio scooting back and Agatha slowly dragging her feet toward her own side. She took the couple of minutes to email in for a substitute for herself as well as call Stevie off from school while Rio tended to notifying the hospital of her absence as well.

There was a heaviness Agatha felt, even as she crawled in and curled up behind Rio, like her marrow had solidified and turned to lead. It was exhaustion in its rawest form and it had become the bane of their attempts at soldiering on. They had been valiant, but it took little time for both of them to doze off into a peaceful, much needed slumber.

______________

"Shhhhhh, hey. Phoenix, buddy, you're okay, I promise."

It was the softest soothing, an intentional promise that left Stevie's lips as she placed herself in the rocking chair that was tucked within the walls of the nursery. She was well aware that her parents would have preferred him asleep in the bassinet in their room, but that was proving to be more of a hinderance to their mental wellbeing than all else.

Truthfully, even as she eased the pacifier between Nix's lips in an attempt to somehow offer him any form of respite, Stevie wasn't upset. She wasn't disgruntled that she had woken up to the sound of him crying. She wasn't annoyed that she was going to miss school to help care for the people she loved.

Stevie knew of the two of them, Agatha was likely the more skeptical one. She was the one who clearly had more to say about the fact that Stevie seemed all too eager to jump into the fray on what Agatha was deeming to be a very adult matter. 

She was sixteen, now, and only two short years away from graduating high school. They hadn't discussed it much, as she felt that both her moms did not want to put undue pressure on her, but Stevie already knew what it was she wanted to do with her life.

Stevie wanted to be just like her mama. She wanted to heal the sick and comfort the distressed. She wanted to take care of people in the same way Rio did, the very way in which they had met. She had not decided on specifics, yet, but there would be time for those considerations still. All Stevie knew was that she had a life ahead of her where she had the freedom to make those choices because two women who loved her impossibly so have given it to her.

Now, they wanted Phoenix to have the same thing.

Little Phoenix, who's coughing only upset himself further. Little baby Phoenix who didn't know yet that he had three people on his side, family that just wanted to see him happy and healthy.

His cries still echoed off the walls of the nursery, but as Stevie garnered more success with the pacifier, he began to soothe after what felt like hours of his unrelenting wailing. She knew he was a baby and did not fault him for it; he was sick and he had no other way to let them know that it was making him miserable.

Rio had rattled off the actual explanation of what he was dealing with -- Croup? Was that what she had called it? -- and mentioned that the medicines they were trying to get him off of were likely not helping. It had been easy to understand in Layman's terms: he was experiencing life as it happened and they just had to help him through it.

Finally, what had once been bone chilling shrieks had since warped and shrank into the softest warbles of a whine as the binky finally came to settle comfortably in Nix's mouth and his eyes began to flutter, like he had finally worn himself out. His little chest shook and he let out the smallest cough, but he did not immediately start screaming again and for that, Stevie was thankful.

"See?" Stevie breathed at him, lifting the gentle pressure on the pacifier so that she could run a light fingertip down his forehead and nose. "You just needed someone else's attention, huh? Well, I'll tell you, if you're tired of them smothering you in love already, you're just going to have to get used to it."

In no reality was Stevie Vidal a stupid kid; she knew he didn't know what she was saying, but he could hear the tranquility that she worked into her voice. He could hear how calm she was being despite his unhappiness and it was working.

All he'd needed was his big sister.

It had taken a little while longer, but with the consistent back and forth of the rocker and her whispered melodies of songs that rolled through her mind, Stevie had somehow finally managed to coax Phoenix into getting a little bit of sleep for the time being. She had debated keeping him where he was, not keen on the idea of rousing him, but she managed to find her way to her feet and deposit him into the spare bassinet. 

As she pulled the small blanket over his chest, she dropped a hand to his forehead to both smooth his hair and gauge his temperature. Upon feeling his skin, she figured that another dose of the medicine that was helping with the cough could wait a little longer, or at least until he woke up in a few hours.

It took her just a moment, but she popped out of the room and into her own to retrieve her phone before she slipped back into the nursery without a sound. The rocking chair called to her once more, but before she took her place, she swiped one of the fleece blankets her parents kept stashed for themselves when they spent late nights in Phoenix's room and in that very rocker.

Getting comfortable took little time, especially once Stevie pulled the foot rest over. As she leaned back and pulled up her phone, she sorted through the few books she had purchased on her reader app trying to settle on something to occupy her mind. Deciding upon 'We Deserve Monuments' by Jas Hammonds, her shoulder shook a little as she sank deeper into the chair and began to read.

Twenty pages in, Stevie fell asleep.

It must have been a few hours later when she awoke to the soft sounds of Nix's coughing and whimpering, only confirmed by the amount of light that had started to pour through the windows. 

It was time to put up or shut up.

Stevie had knowingly made the offer. Now, it was time for her to prove that she could tackle the responsibility, that she could be a helping hand when things weren't always so easy. 

Once she had stowed her phone in the sports bra she was wearing beneath her t-shirt, she climbed to her feet and paced to the bassinet,  peering down inside at the infant inside. He was swinging his little fists and feet as he whimpered and whined, clearly seeking attention. 

Stevie grinned down at him, reaching to pull him up and secure him in her hold. After the typical motions of getting his diaper changed and fitted into a new snug and comfortable onesie, they were on their way down the stairs to begin their day. While the formula was warming, Stevie caught sight of the Keurig on the counter and held an internal debate.

It was... 7:38, judging by the time indicated on the stove. She technically didn't need coffee, but the idea of a little caffeinated nudge did not sound too terrible. With a skill she had no reason to possess, she managed to use one hand to start herself a cup of coffee at the same time the microwave dinged.

For as young as she was, and how she only knew how to handle a baby through the way her moms had taught her and what she had witnessed as she watched idly, there was a definite finesse to the way she floated around the kitchen and grabbed the bottle. As she had seen over and over, she flipped the bottle and squeezed a couple of droplets onto her skin, making sure it wasn't too hot. 

Satisfied, she removed the pacifier and left it on the counter, pacing circles around the kitchen as she fed him. With her coffee finished, Stevie suddenly found herself in a predicament: she did not have enough hands to hold Nix, feed him, and carry her coffee to the living room. If she tried to remove the bottle before he was ready, she was almost certain the screaming was imminent. With a sigh, Stevie resigned herself to a cup of cold and/or wasted coffee.

The majority of the morning was spent in the living room; Stevie flipped through different shows and movies, taking almost a half an hour to settle on something that she watched for ten minutes and then grew bored of. She kept up on making sure Nix was tended to, clean, and fed, and while there had been one major meltdown a little after 10am, things had calmed and he was still cranky but not unmanageable. 

He had been content enough in his little bouncer seat after she had given him the appropriate meds. She had fixed herself a quick lunch of grilled cheese with him in that bouncer a little ways away so that she could keep an eye on him. That time, she got a hot cup of coffee out of it too.

It was a little after 2:30pm by the time the first signs of life were shown from the couple upstairs. Stevie heard the stairs as they creaked in all the places she knew they would as one of her moms made her way down them. 

Unsurprisingly, she lifted her head to see Rio swing around the last bend for the remaining seven steps.

"Hey mama," Stevie called from her place on the couch, Nix sound asleep in her arms.

"Good morning, cupcake," Rio returned with a laugh. She shuffled behind the couch, leaning over enough to place a kiss atop Stevie's head before reaching up to ruffle her hair. "How's it been going?"

Stevie tipped her head back, bright grey eyes landing on her mama as a gentle smile tugged on the corners of her lips. "It's been okay. We had about a ten minute full-fledged meltdown earlier, but... I think he's okay for now. I've fed him twice and he's been changed. I also gave him the medicines you told me about to keep him on schedule."

The more she watched her mama as she listed everything off, she could see a shiny film as it coated her dark amber eyes.

"Mama? What's wrong?" Stevie questioned, her head snapping forward as she shifted sideways on the couch to look at Rio a little better

"Nothing, nothing," Rio assured her, reaching up with a hand to press away the glassiness. "I'm just... Really proud of you. And I know mom would be, too, if she heard you talking like that. You're really helping us out and I don't think there's a way for us to say how much we appreciate it."

It was nice to hear those things; Stevie knew that she was smart, that she was likeable even if the boys were mostly assholes, and she knew that she was overall a decent teenager. They still had their moments where they would all butt heads, but Stevie usually realized in retrospect why she had been wrong and used it to learn and grow instead. But... To hear her mama acknowledge that even though they were hesitant to let her help, it meant something? It felt good.

"I know she's uneasy about it," Stevie offered, looking down at Nix in her arms. "And it's not something I'd press for a lot, but... You guys really needed it. I got him calmed down and we both slept a little bit. He's been alright so far."

"Have you eaten?" Rio questioned, though she made no immediate move for the kitchen.

"I made myself a grilled cheese. I was going to eat the leftover stir-fry, but I figured you might want it." It might have seemed like a selfless answer, but the truth was that Stevie just wanted to make life easier for the people she loved. Sure, she was still just a teenager, but all of the love that had been poured into her for the last decade needed somewhere to go.

"Or," Stevie offered, an option brewing. "If you wanna trade me places for a few, I can make you and mom some grilled cheeses, too. And some soup, maybe?"

Rio's expression melted as she beheld her daughter, reaching forward to lightly brush at her cheek.

"I can make us some sandwiches. Unless you need a break?" Rio returned, her eyes dropping to Nix, who seemed as though he was beginning to rouse from his nap.

Stevie shook her head without missing a beat. "Actually, since you're down here. Before you go back up, do you think maybe you could help me wrap him up like mom helps you so we can go for a walk?"

As if Rio had not been soft enough, Stevie could have sworn that she could have collapsed right then and there with how the request had landed with her.

"You want to body wrap him?" she asked back as if she did not understand the request, but Stevie knew she was simply caught off guard.

"I figured it would be the easiest way to take him out. The stroller on my own just seems like a little much." Stevie offered a gentle shrug as she glanced down, Nix's eyes finally opening to peer up at his big sister. He let out a tiny grunt as an open hand swing and latched on a good handful of Stevie's long brown hair. Even as he gave it a hefty tug, all Stevie did was laugh.

"Any harder and you might go bald," Rio teased, leaning over the back of the couch to kiss Stevie's forehead. As she pulled away with the intent of making something for herself and Agatha to eat before they inevitably went back to sleep, Stevie looked up at her with the most kind-hearted smile, as if she could see the complete adoration scribed into Rio's sleepy expression.

"Worse things could happen," Stevie mused, tipping her chin toward the kitchen. "Go on, you need to eat," she urged. "We're just fine, aren't we little dude?" 

Surely, Stevie had not been a expecting any kind of response, much the same way Rio had not. So when Nix let out the sweetest sound that bordered so closely to a giggle, they both snapped their attention to him, wearing grins of equal measure.

"I think he was agreeing with you," Rio teased. 

"Or maybe he was telling you to go be a chef," Stevie returned with a laugh.

Rio waved her off and departed to the kitchen, busying herself with her task of concocting some form of sustenance for herself and Agatha. Stevie was right; they could sleep almost all day, but food was still a vital necessity.

From her place in the living room, Stevie set out on another search for something to watch. She had rearranged Nix so that he was on his stomach along her torso, those little fingers grabbing and pulling at the fabric of her shirt in his fascination. It was peaceful, simply holding him close and letting him do his thing, so long as the screaming didn't start.

The medicine did seem to be helping but truth be told, Stevie wondered what exactly it was about her that had him so tamed and subdued considering the previous six days he had done little more than scream in his pain.

She had no idea that several feet away, standing at the stove in a tank top and pair of shorts, her mama was wondering the exact same thing.

By the time Rio had finished the sandwiches, giving Stevie enough warning so she could appropriately dress Nix, they were ready to set out on a small adventure -- almost. 

Stevie watched as Rio set the plates down on the table and headed to the closet to retrieve the dark green wrap so that she could assist Stevie before she retreated upstairs. 

Setting him down in the bouncer seat for just a moment, Stevie stepped up and held her arms up with a giggle so that Rio could start the process. She worked quickly but explained every step as she went, from the way she wrapped Stevie's shoulders and swung around the waist.

"And when you do it like this, make sure you tighten it as much as you're comfortable with," Rio informed her, cinching it firmly around Stevie's middle. "And make sure the label is over your center, that way his weight will be balanced and supported."

Stevie was listening, paying very close attention so that perhaps she might not need Rio's help the next time she wanted to take him out, even if they just hung out in the backyard. Admittedly, it would be nice to have free use of both of her arms sometimes and could probably even prove useful around the house, too.

"Wrap around one more time, then we tie it right here," Rio indicated, forming the knot at Stevie's hip. With one more tug, Rio seemed satisfied with her handiwork and stepped aside to collect Phoenix from the seat. 

With soft giggles and a small bit of finagling, the two of them managed to fit the infant inside of the wrap. Rio offered small adjustments to ensure they were both comfortable before she stepped back to take one last look at her children.

This one, Stevie realized, was not to make sure she had done a good enough job with the wrap.

No, the look that Rio gave her in those moments as she took in the sight of her oldest wearing her youngest comfortably on her chest was filled with nothing but the undying love and affection she had for them both. It was pride, it was adoration, it was joy and it was relief. If Stevie had guessed, her parents had spent a fair amount of time worried over how she might adjust with someone else in the picture taking up the attention.

Right then, Stevie could see the ease that filled her knowing that it couldn't have been any better.

Stevie loved Phoenix already; he had captured her the first time he had been laid in her arms and not a day would go by in her life where she wouldn't fight tooth and nail to make sure he had everything he needed in life, just as their parents had always done for her.

Her parents had spent ten incredible years giving her all she needed, even if it wasn't always what she wanted. In the process, they had been teaching her how to do the same for someone else. Then, as the universe would have it, they'd given her exactly the right person to do it for and she could not have been happier.

"Well, that's us off, then!" Stevie announced with a grin, breaking Rio out of her appreciative trance.

"You know I normally don't care, but please share your Snapchat location with me or mom just so we know where you are. I know you're not going far, but... Better safe than sorry, you know?" 

Still wearing her smile, Stevie gave a nod and fished her phone out of her back pocket so that she could comply with her mama's request, holding the phone up as proof once she was finished. 

"I think we're just gonna walk to the park, stay for a little bit, then come back. It shouldn't be more than an hour and when we get back, I'll do his feeding." There was a new sense of authority to Stevie's voice, one that even Stevie herself did not know she was capable of, but it clearly landed somewhere in Rio's chest.

While she'd been wearing that smitten look on her face since the moment she'd taken a step back, it was the first thing that compelled her to move again, stepping around Stevie's side so that she could offer a hug that wouldn't disturb Nix. 

"I know you know this isn't a normal thing," Rio informed her, laying her head on Stevie's shoulder for a moment as she peered down at her son. "But mom and I really appreciate it. I know I keep saying it, but it's true. It's a little crazy to see you do adult things because, as cheesy as it is... You're still our little girl."

Although she did tip her head to rest against her mama's, Stevie couldn't stifle the soft chuckle that left her.

"Yeah, almost four inches taller than you and all," she mused, giving Rio's shoulders a firm squeeze. 

"With our luck, this one's going to be six and a half feet tall by the time he's your age," Rio returned with a laugh of her own, releasing the hold she had around Stevie's waist. She leaned up, pressing a kiss to her daughter's cheek and stepped away, giving one last gentle pat to her back. 

"Have fun, enjoy the fresh air. Anything happens, you call one of us right away, yeah?"

"Of course mama. Go eat your grilled cheeses and tell mom I love her." 

With another soft sound of delight fluttering from her lips, Rio nodded and did just that, waiting for Stevie to pull the front door shut behind her before she retreated to the bedroom with her bounty.

The moment Stevie felt the sun on her skin, all she could do was grin. It wasn't that she didn't ever go outside, just that it had been a long few days and the mild temperatures and brightness of the uninhibited sun felt rejuvenating in the best way.

"I know you're still not feeling great, lil dude, but I'm glad you're not mad about the fresh air," Stevie murmured at him as she reached up to run a couple of fingertips over his hair. With a glance around, off they went to enjoy the sun and the sounds of birds and kids laughing that had already been cut free from school.

It was rather uneventful, but Stevie enjoyed it all the same. It hadn't taken her long to get to the park where she had taken a Snap that she had sent straight to both her moms to keep their streaks going. It was silly, and neither of them had any other contacts on their accounts other than each other and Stevie, but it was just a simple little thing that kept them connected.

Perched on a bench, Stevie had simply been watching the squirming baby against her chest. His movements turned a little erratic, though, and she could sense what was coming before it even started happening. 

Her hand flew down to the carabiner on her hip and unclipped the binky she had stashed there before they left and held it up, gently easing it into Nix's mouth to staunch the screaming before it truly got going.

The way he calmed almost immediately had Stevie slouching slightly in her relief. She knew the risks she had been taking when she had decided to bring a recovering infant on walk, but so had Rio and she had not declared it a bad idea. He was at the tail end of it -- as Stevie had surmised with her investigative googling that her mama would surely shun her for -- and while he'd clearly been suffering, his symptoms had been lessening.

They stayed just a bit longer before Stevie was on her feet and headed toward home. The walk back had been almost as uneventful as the one there -- but not quite.

She was home, or at least as close as she could be without actually being there, as she started to cross the sidewalk that passed in front of the house next door. 

Stevie had seen the guy before -- he was one of those total military-wannabe dickbags that had a buzz cut and slapped a Punisher sticker on the back of his shitty pickup truck -- but she kept to herself, even when his stupid dog was barking until one in the morning and everyone in the neighborhood could hear it. He was outside checking his mail, but she must have drawn his attention. His head lifted, but she chose to ignore him and keep walking.

And then he had to go and fucking speak.

The moment Stevie heard the sound of his voice, her hand flew to her back pocket and grabbed her phone, unlocking it with the pin before she'd even looked at the screen.

She glanced down at it, tapping twice to bring up Agatha's contact, though she was trying to give him the benefit of the doubt as she listened.

"Deviants raising deviants," he muttered. 

Stevie kept walking.

"Maybe you need a real dad to teach you how not to be a slut."

He got five words in before Stevie sent out the call to Agatha's phone. Before he was even finished speaking, Stevie had spun on her heel and started to yell.

____________________

When Rio had woken her up earlier in the day to try and choke down a grilled cheese, Agatha had fought to stay awake long enough to appreciate the quiet cuddles and kisses she got to have with her wife. It had been a true effort, but it had lasted no more than twenty minutes before she drifted off once more, Rio not far behind her.

The next time she woke, it was because her phone was ringing on her nightstand. And it was Stevie's ringtone. Agatha was awake enough to be aware of the fact that Stevie had taken Nix out and that if she was calling her, it's because she still was not home.

Alert, Agatha grabbed her phone and swiped open the call.

What she heard made her fly into an upright position.

Stevie was screaming.

"I don't know who the fuck you think you are! We mind our own fucking business and we do not ever fucking bother you! Who the fuck are you to say any goddamn thing about me OR my family? I --"

"STEVIE!" Agatha shouted into the phone, but Agatha could tell by the sound of her daughter's yelling that she did not have the phone close enough to hear her.

Agatha began to panic.

Where could she be? Who was she yelling at? How the fuck was Agatha supposed to help when she knew nothing other than the fact that she could hear her daughter screaming at some unidentified person.

And then he spoke.

Agatha couldn't make out what he was saying clearly, but she recognized his voice. She'd had a couple of disagreements with the neighbor next door -- primarily because of that infernal mutt he owned -- but it was enough to recognize the sound of his voice. 

Like a whip of wind, Agatha was flying out of the bed and tearing down the stairs, leaving a blinking and confused Rio in her wake, still trying to rouse and put the pieces together of what it was she had woken up to.

Agatha took no time at all to bound down the stairs, flying out the front door in her sleepwear and without shoes as she saw Stevie holding her phone out by her side as she yelled in the man's face.

The funniest part about it was that she was about an inch taller than he was.

However, Agatha did not have a bone in her body at that moment that could have ever been amused. 

She was in momma bear mode in an instant, shooting down to wedge herself between the two of them, raising her hands to indicate that she would absolutely shove him away if he did not choose to back up. 

He was smart and took a step back.

"Now say to her what you fucking said to me!" Stevie shouted over her shoulder, hand clasped over Nix's ears. The baby had started to cry, but he wasn't screaming -- yet.

In the entranceway to the house, Rio had appeared to seek out what had Agatha tearing out of bed the way she had. She was standing there, quiet, and not one of the three of them had noticed her. She was simply watching, figuring that Agatha could handle herself, but knowing she should be present just in case.

Agatha's brows shot up expectantly in demand. "Well?" she clipped sharply, eyes narrowing as she inched forward. When he did not speak, she spoke for him. "What is it that you can say to a child that you can't say to me?"

Stevie was hovering behind her, completely seething despite the fact that her whole body was bouncing in some attempt to keep Nix calm throughout the situation, though his crying had started to get louder. She was trying to give him the chance to be a 'man' as he so deemed himself to be and when he did not speak, Stevie had had enough.

"THAT IM A SLUT BECAUSE YOU AND MAMA ARE GAY! WASN'T THAT IT?" Stevie nearly screamed in her anger. No one had realized it, but her face had deepened about six shades of red and there were furious tears streaming down her face.

Agatha's fists balled at her sides and she had even gotten as far as bending her elbow, but before she could draw back for a full swing, she felt jostled out of her place between Stevie and the man. When her head snapped up, her scowl vicious, she saw Rio. She had her back to the man -- who had yet to retreat, annoyingly enough -- and was looking at both her and Stevie, back and forth.

"Both of you," Rio said calmly, her eyes dropping to the crying baby in the body wrap. Her hands were out, palms up in that she was there to intervene on their behalf, but could not do it with them present. "Inside. Now."

Both Agatha and Stevie wore matching expressions of scorn and disdain for the pathetic excuse of a man that was on the other side of Rio, but thankfully, they both listened. Agatha placed one hand on Stevie's back and one atop Nix's head, somehow trying to soothe them both as they retreated toward the house.

Agatha could still hear Rio, though.

Rio had turned and stepped closer to him and while her voice was low, Agatha still caught it.

"You might know, having lived next door for some time, that I am a doctor," she began, sizing him up, as if she were looking to put him on a market of the black variety. By trade, I know quite a bit about the human body. And..." Her eyes flickered to his home before they landed on him again. "I know where you live."

The man swallowed down the nerves Rio was inducing with a loud 'gulp.' 

"If you have a problem, or even a suggestion, it would be wise of you to bring them directly to me. I am sure, after this, you won't want to speak with my wife, and I would be more than happy to assist you." Rio's words were almost kind, but that sharpened edge could have shaved a slice of paper into two layers. "Otherwise, you do not speak on my wife or BOTH of OUR children. Am I clear?"

The man, wide-eyed and pale, gave a nod as he swallowed again. "Y-yes s-sir -- I... Fuck, yes ma'am."

Agatha, who was now standing at the top of the steps as Stevie had retreated inside, could almost feel how badly Rio wanted to smirk at that, but she kept her steely demeanor until the man turned and slithered back to his own home.

Agatha wanted to smirk, too, but her anger was winning out for those remaining few moments. Rio stood on the sidewalk, just watching as he went inside. She turned to head back up the steps, but was startled to see that Agatha had not gone into the house. "My love, I told you to go inside."

"Oh, I know," Agatha returned smoothly, holding her hand out. The heat in her face had started to dull, even more so when Rio met the request for contact. "But I am so glad I didn't."

"Stop it, you," Rio chastised, leaning in to place a kiss to the corner of Agatha's mouth. "Let's go calm our kids down."

There was something about Rio that just... induced peace. Agatha had felt it as she had watched Rio speak to that asswipe, and she could tell that Stevie felt it as Rio helped her unwrap after Agatha had snatched Phoenix to tend to his diaper and making him a bottle for his early evening feeding. 

"I'm proud of you."

"You did the right thing by calling mama."

"It wasn't safe for you to confront him like that, especially with your brother, but I understand why you did. I just need you to be a little more mindful next time, okay?"

As she folded the wrap, Rio's head tilted up and she met those beautiful grey eyes that she and Agatha had fallen in love with all those years ago.

"You are the best sister, and the best daughter, that anyone could ever ask for, and I hope you know that."

The way Rio pulled her down and kissed her forehead had Agatha melting from her spot on the couch, gently smoothing a hand over Nix's belly with one hand as she fed him with the other. 

"Not my moment, but want to submit my agreement for consideration," she voiced softly, causing both Rio and Stevie to look at her, matching smiles finding their expressions despite no biological relation.

They had settled and discussed everything that had happened while Agatha had tucked Phoenix in his seat and kept it moving with her foot. He had fallen asleep not too long after, leaving the three of them still exhausted, but so solid as a unit.

When Stevie spoke, Agatha could feel everywhere all at once as she softened, her gaze casting to her little girl.

"I know that was a little wild, but I'm okay. And... I think you guys should go back upstairs and lay down. Try to sleep a little more. I'll wake him up in an hour and keep him up until bedtime that way we might get him to sleep through the night." There was that Big-Sister-Authority creeping in again.

"Stevie..."

"Mom, we're not gonna do this again. Go," she urged, eyes flicking toward the stairs in silent instruction.

The moment Rio's hand slid over Agatha's thigh and gave a soft squeeze, she knew there was no use in trying to resist. Stevie had more than proved her mettle that day; letting her handle him for a little while longer wasn't going to hurt anyone.

"Okay, fine," Agatha sighed, leaning forward to place a soft kiss to her daughters cheek. She and Rio got to their feet and offered their soft 'I love you's and 'holler if you need anything's before they made their retreat to the sanctuary of their bedroom. 

Shutting the door behind them, Agatha's attention fell to her wife as she made her way around to her side of the bed, crawling in with ease and familiarity. 

"You know," Agatha mused, her tone low but still tired. "If I wasn't ready to pass out again, I'd be between your legs right now for that show outside."

Even though the last week had run them absolutely ragged, the vibrant laugh that left Rio caused Agatha's stomach to flip delightfully in her middle.

"My love, I don't even think I can sit up long enough to ride your face. But," Rio mused, her head turning as Agatha climbed into bed next to her to lay down. "you can play with my nipples while you're the big spoon?"

"I can live with that," Agatha agreed, somehow stifling a yawn until she finished speaking. 

Almost in sync, they rolled to their sides and Agatha scooted forward, fasting her front to Rio's back as an arm draped over her waist and snaked beneath her shirt. As expected, Agatha's palm met the bare flesh of Rio's breast as she cupped it, giving a light squeeze.

Agatha kept idle work while concurrently placing a few kisses along the back of Rio's neck. A few hums left her wife those first few minutes. Shortly after, the hums turned to snores. The snores gave Agatha permission to fall back asleep, too.

 When she woke, it was to a sharp pain, something she realized quickly was Rio pinching her email. 

"Ow! Hey!" Agatha grumbled, blinking herself into consciousness.

"You have a vice grip on my boob, Agatha," Rio returned. 

Realizing she was right, Agatha's released her hold and dropped her hand to rest on the smooth skin of Rio's stomach. Although she closed her eyes again, it did not miss her that it was dark outside again.

"Mmm, no more crying?" she questioned, nuzzling a bit more into Rio's neck.

"Stevie the Phoenix Tamer seems to have it all under control. She texted me that he's asleep in the nursery and she's going to bed soon." It was a simple enough explanation, but Agatha also knew that it meant he needed to be brought into their room to sleep for the remainder of the night.

"I'll go get him in a few. But can I tell you a secret first?" Agatha's grogginess was thick in her tone, but her words still held a light playfulness to them.

"Do go on," Rio offered back, stifling a quiet chuckle.

"I am sort of in love with this life I never thought I would have. And I am definitely full of love for the three of you. Just thought you should know."

"Oh. my love," Rio returned, giving Agatha's arm a gentle squeeze. "I already knew that. You're so loud about it every day."

 

Chapter 33: One Shot - All Your Might and All Your Thirst

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Oh no.

This was bad.

This was very, very bad.

It was one in the morning on a Saturday and Stevie Vidal found herself completely and entirely surrounded by teenagers that were far more intoxicated than they should have ever been. Being only eighteen herself, she was well aware of the rules set by her parents, the ones she had no problem abiding by.

Even at the Senior Bonfire, Stevie had arrived with no intention to drink. Holding to that decision hadn’t been easy with the constant influx of peer pressure, but she knew who she was, and she knew that there were certain things she was not willing to waffle on.

The truth was, Stevie respected her parents far too much to go against their guidelines. She knew that they were fully aware that she had reached adulthood and that she was suddenly ‘capable of making her own decisions,’ but Rio had given her far too many lectures to count about the physiological effects that underage drinking could cause. It might have seemed overbearing to anyone else, but to Stevie, it was her mama caring enough to make sure she truly understood that her decisions could sometimes have consequences.

So, there she was, with five friends who needed rides home from the middle of nowhere and a car that could only hold four of them, and uncomfortably at that.

Maybe the sports car hadn’t been the best choice – and lord knew, she’d had to practically beg her mom to finally concede – because right then, she was starting to panic. She couldn’t just take a few of them at a time and expect the others to sit idly in the field and wait for her return, especially given how much they had been drinking that night.

And yet, somehow, Stevie was the responsible one, the sober one, the one who had tried to point out several times that night that no one had a way home. Right then, she was even more certain of that because she had three additional carabiners clipped to her belt loops so that no one else might try to be brave (the better word there being idiotic) and make their own way home.

There was no feasible way to make it work, not without shoving someone into the trunk, which… not feasible.

With a resigned sigh, Stevie surveyed the five of them as they slumped into one another on an overturned log, half of them having already thrown up.

Having run infinite laps in her own head, Stevie could think of only one way out of this that ensured everyone remained safe and so, she pulled out her phone.

For a moment, she stared at the wallpaper on the screen; it was from the Halloween after they adopted Nix and they were all dressed appropriately. From the black braided wig and white-collared black dress Stevie had procured to the silly little suit and drawn on moustache that Nix had sported, they were every bit the Wednesday and Pubert they intended to be. What made it even better? Suited up with hair slicked down and a silly little moustache of her own, Rio nearly embodied Gomez while Agatha, in a sleek and curve-hugging dress with a black wig of her own, screamed Morticia energy from miles away.

It was almost three years old at that point, but every so often, Stevie went back to it and set it as her lockscreen. It was a fond memory, something she treasured over time, and she liked to be reminded of just what her family meant to her in every wacky and zany form they might take.

With a quick swipe of the screen, Stevie was in a hot debate with herself on who to call.

Rio or Agatha?

Her lips pressed firm, teeth hooking in from the inside as she assessed the pros and cons of each.

Only one of them would be able to leave with a three year old still sleeping down the hall from them. Waking both of them up wasn’t necessary, but once one was up, the other was likely to follow.

Agatha hated being woken up unnecessarily. Accidents or sickness were obvious exceptions to that, but if she could continue sleeping while the world burned so long as her family was safe? She would.

And, well, Stevie was safe, but she was not entirely sold on the idea that her friends might be if she left them unattended for too long in the middle of nowhere.

Welp. Rio it was.

It took a matter of a few seconds to bring up her contact and send the call, but as the phone began to ring, Stevie’s nerves also started to twist in time. After only three rings, the call connected.

“Stevie?” came Rio’s groggy greeting, almost sounding as though she were still completely asleep.

“Hey, mama. I’m okay but… I need help.”

Stevie could have sworn she heard a gust of air as it hit the microphone when Rio launched to sit upright.

“What’s wrong?” Rio pressed , the urgency so undeniably thick in her tone. Stevie could hear the panic, and while she had tried to prevent it, she also accepted that from Rio’s perspective, she was getting a call in the middle of the night from her daughter, who was asking for help.

“Nothing’s wrong, really, mama. I’m fine, but… A few more of the crew drank than said they would. So… I have five people who need a ride home and I can only cram four of them in my car and keep it legal. I know it’s the middle of the night and I promised no shenanigans… But if you could help me get two of them home, I would thank you every single day for the rest of my life.”

Stevie was rambling, but only because she felt guilty. She knew this was a tall order and it was unfair to think that Rio would just bail her out of any situation where she got in over her head, but she also knew that if she attempted to handle it on her own and something bad happened? She could already hear both of her mothers in her head:

“You could have called us.”

Rio didn’t immediately say anything, but Stevie could hear that she was moving and pulling herself out of bed. Right as she started to apologize for the wake-up call, Stevie heard something on the other end of the line.

“Baby? What’s wrong?”

Agatha sounded even more asleep than Rio had when she had initially answered the phone, but Rio was quick to soothe her.

“Go back to sleep, my love. I’m gonna run and help Stevie with something, but we should both be back and in bed soon.” Rio was explaining it to Agatha, but she was also managing to answer Stevie at the same time.

As if there could have ever been any other response than ‘I’m on my way,’ even if it didn’t happen in those exact words.

“Is she okay?” Stevie heard her mom ask through a yawn. She couldn’t see it, but she could hear as Rio kissed some unidentified part of her face in answer.

“She’s fine, Agatha. Sleep now. Be back soon.”

Listening to the exchange between them, Stevie found herself grinning as she leaned against her car, eyes still fixed on the gaggle of her drunk friends as they giggled and murmured between the five of them.

Hearing her parents talk to each other so tenderly, so softly, it made Stevie ache for the day when she got woken up by her adult child, asking for help being a taxi service. It made her want the love that was audible when they spoke to each other, especially in those moments.

All Stevie had ever wanted since the day she’d met them was to be just like them. The meaning behind that had shifted some as she got older, but the sentiment was still the same at its core. Back then, Stevie had wanted to be kind, to be giving, to be caring. As a preteen, she wanted to be patient, to be understanding, to be compassionate. Now, looking ahead to years of college and learning and wanting to know everything Rio knew, Stevie had taken that desire and it was something far more than she ever thought it might be.

What she wanted now, that she saw in Agatha and Rio, was to love freely and without reserves. She wanted to let herself be loved like that, too. She wanted to be proud, to be resolute, to be firm in her place in the world, just like they were.

The thing Stevie wanted most in life was the ability to build a life for herself the way she had watched her moms do, and she had that ability, but it was all because they had given it to her.

What Stevie had was magic, solely because it had never come from obligation, but rather bloomed from a pool of nothing but pure and true love, the love they taught her to own for herself.

She had a mama who was pulling on shoes at one in the morning to help her and her friends.

She also had a mom who was probably not going to go back to sleep and instead would choose to lay there worrying until her girls were back under her roof.

“You’re still out at the Kovalcik farm?” Rio asked in hushed tones, the sounds of her movement but a whisper in the background.

“Yeah,” Stevie answered immediately. “We’re sitting kind of near the road. I can turn my headlights on for you. You think it’ll be about twenty minutes?”

Stevie knew where she was in relation to where they live, but she also knew that Rio was likely already considering just how much she could push the speed limit without flagging the attention of the police. So, instead of letting Rio answer that it would be closer to fifteen, Stevie offered something else first.

“Take your time. We’re all fine. I’m sober, and they’re all two minutes from falling asleep on each other. Don’t rush, get here safely.”

There was a soft laugh on the other end of the line, but it wasn’t quite dry enough for Stevie to think that Rio was upset or even annoyed. “Wanna know something?” Rio questioned softly, though Stevie could hear her shutting the front door as she did so.

“If it’s something you have to teach me, always,” she responded with a gentle laugh of her own.

“No lesson tonight. But an observation: You, Stevie Vidal, are going to make a great mom someday, if you decide that’s what you want. And you want to know how I know? Not only are you momming the everloving hell out of your friends, but you’re trying to mom me, too.” Rio’s voice was still low and soft, but Stevie could hear the pride there, even if it was mixed with a little bit of amusement, too.

“Yeah, well,” Stevie huffed back, though it was more out of feeling seen more than anything else. “Two really cool women have shown me great examples of how to do that, so it’s second nature at this point.”

“It’s almost 2am,” Rio deadpanned, “save the flattery for after breakfast and coffee.”

“Consider it pinned til morning,” Stevie returned sweetly.

“I’m getting in the car now, so I should be there shortly. Don’t let anyone wander into the road in the time it takes me to get there,” came Rio’s light advice, but Stevie could still hear the smile in her voice.

“Okay, mama. I love you. See you soon.”

“Love you too, pumpkin.”

Nope, Stevie wasn’t letting her get away with that one, even in the middle of the night.

“I.” Stevie’s correction was firm, but it was loving.

“Right, sorry. I love you too, pumpkin.” Again, that grin Rio was wearing carried through in the sound of her voice, offering an audible hug when Stevie really needed it. “Be there soon.”

With that, Rio hung up and Stevie was left with her gaggle of silly teenagers who had gotten in over their heads. Oh, the way they were probably going to hate themselves in the morning.

None of this was to say that at the ripe age of eighteen that Stevie had never had a drink before, but the seldom few had been on her birthday that year when she was permitted to have a couple of glasses of wine in celebration under the supervision of her parents. It hadn’t been much and admittedly, she’d barely gleaned a buzz, but it was the sentiment that was attached that had been the most important part.

As much as it might have pained them, her moms were acknowledging that she was growing, and that she could make her own choices. They were showing her that it was okay to bend the rules for the right circumstances, so long as those decisions were made responsibly. More than that, though, Stevie had simply never had any desire to get so drunk that she could not control herself. It wasn’t the half-assed lectures from Rio, or Agatha’s underhanded reminders of what things like drinking and driving could do to people and their families. No, it was actually a whole hell of a lot deeper than that.

Stevie still wasn’t ready to do anything that could disappoint the women who had raised her. She knew that she would always make mistakes, that she would make bad choices in her life and learn from them, but the ones she was conscious about? The ones she knew were wrong in the context of where she was in her life? Those were the ones she simply would not make, not if it meant letting down the people she loved most.

There was another piece to the puzzle, too: Phoenix.

Sure, he was three. He wasn’t going to remember anything Stevie might have done that could have been a bad example just yet, but there was a principle there that she wanted to maintain. She wanted to be a good role model for him, someone that he could look up to and turn to with the confidence that she would always do what she could to help him.

Maybe there would never come a day when Stevie would have to justify her sense of morality to anyone else, but having those resolute pillars of who she was planted firmly to support the life she wanted to live, it was important to her.

“I’m getting cold,” came a pitched whine from the end of the log. Surprisingly, it was from her friend Tomas, who was the biggest of the bunch with muscles that made little sense for his frame.

“Shouldn’t you be radiating the most heat?” the girl next to him, a thin brunette named Morgan griped in return.

“Alright kids, don’t start fighting,” Stevie admonished with a light chuckle as she paced around to the passenger’s side of the car and pulled the door open. “Three of you are coming with me. So… figure it out and once decided, climb in. By the time y’all get done bickering, my mama should be here for the other two of you.”

“Oh! Oh!” chimed another girl – Holly. “I’m going with Stevie’s mama! She’s hot!” Her speech was slurred and it was clearly not an admission she would have verbalized in front of Stevie sober, but it still caused Stevie to roll her eyes all the same.

“I can’t wait for the moment in seven years when your brain is fully developed and we reflect on this moment,” she mused in return, offering a soft snort that sounded far too much like her mom’s.

“Yeah, well,” Morgan managed, swaying slightly. She raised a finger at Stevie as if she was about to deliver some insanely sage wisdom but then blinked a couple of times and dropped her hand, brow furrowing as the thought seemed to escape her. “You know too much about medical stuff considering we haven’t even graduated high school yet.” It was a grumble, meant to sound like a problem, but Stevie just laughed. What was two more weeks of senior year at this point?

“It’s because her mama is a doctor, duh. And that makes her even hotter,” Holly snapped back, as if this were common knowledge. Which, it kind of was. The first part at least. Stevie would never be able to get on the ‘Stevie’s Moms Are Hot’ train, cause that was… fucking weird.

Alas, they were all growing and being dumb teenagers, and that apparently meant having crushes on older women for a few of them.

“Holly, please, I beg of you, try as hard as you can to not weird her out. I know it’s only like ten minutes to your house, but she’s in her fifties. You’re not even twenty. But you are an adult, so my mom might still try to fight you.” Okay, so the last part was a bit of an added embellishment to drive the point home, but it seemed to work. At least, it looked that way as Holly’s eyes went wide and her mouth snapped shut.

“Okay, yeah, she’s scary.” It was a quiet observation, but the dejected tone of voice Holly used almost caused Stevie to burst into laughter, no matter how awkward the situation was at its roots.

Before Stevie could form a retort, a flicker of headlights flashed over the inebriated troupe, causing alarm from the other boy, Jake, who cried out instantly. “The cops! The cops are here!”

It was not, in fact, the police. It was Rio in her swanky SUV that probably could have fit all of them if they squeezed in tight enough, but Stevie was not willing to abandon her car.

With a light greeting, the five teenagers took only a moment to assign vehicles and climbed into their respective choices with Tomas complaining again that he was cold, to which the two others told him to shut up and get in.

Once all five were in and fastened, Stevie paced to the open driver’s side window of Rio’s SUV to offer her gratitude for the assistance. What she found there was her mama wearing a look of utter reverence and awe.

“Why are you looking at me like that?” she questioned, scrunching her face as though she were disgusted by the softness, but Rio’s expression didn’t waver.

“Because you’re an insane kid in the sense that… You’re always on top of it, whatever ‘it’ happens to be. You’re graduating with honors in two weeks and while all of your friends are completely hammered, you’re the lone sober soldier making sure everyone gets home safe. We say it all the time, but we are so lucky that you are our daughter. And your friends are really lucky, too.”

Rio could get sappy sometimes, that was undeniable, but right then it hit Stevie a little harder toward the middle of her chest. She knew she wasn’t a perfect kid, and she knew that she had given them hell some days with little excuse, but seeing how relentlessly and unconditionally her moms loved her always meant so damn much. It just seemed to mean a little more at some ungodly hour of the morning when they were both exhausted but fighting on to do the right thing.

“Thank you, mama. For that, and for helping me out with this. Really.”

Reaching forward through the window, Rio took hold of Stevie’s head only enough to pull her forward so that she could kiss her forehead, not caring what drunken cajoling it might bring from her back seat – which it did in the form of two ‘awwwwwwwww’s from Stevie’s friends.

“Shut up, guys,” Stevie dismissed, leaning out. “Drink water before you sleep. Advil might not hurt, either.”

“I’d suggest Pedialyte over water, if you have it,” Rio added, turning her head to cast her voice over her shoulder. She already knew that the two teenagers were not listening, but it was useful advice nonetheless.

Rio’s attention found her daughter once more, her lips curling into a warm smile that said more than her words could right then.

“Get them home. Text me when you’re headed back to the house. I love you.”

“I love you too, mama. I hope they don’t give you too much trouble.” She leaned in again, grey gaze pinning her friends. “Behave. She’s being nice to you when she should be sleeping. Love you guys. Text me in the morning if you remember this.”

With that, Stevie placed a quick peck to the side of her mama’s head and departed for her own car, as well as the task of ferrying home the remaining three friends that had been warming up inside.

The ride was mostly quiet, save for a few groans of regret that rumbled in the back seat. They each thanked her as they climbed out, one by one, stop by stop, to fold into bed to sleep off the alcohol.

Tomas was the last member to exit, but before he shut the door, he leaned down and peered inside the car again. “Stevie?” he offered, his brown eyes glassy but soft in the light of the overhead.

“Yes, Tomas?” she returned, a small smile curling her lips as she turned to face him.

“You’re really fuckin’ cool. And your parents are too. My dad would be losing his mind if I asked him to come get me. So… thanks. And tell your mama thanks, too.” It was surprisingly sentimental given the hour and that he was still rather drunk, but she could tell that he was being sincere.

“Will do, friend. Go catch some z’s. Text me in the morning to let me know you’re alive.”

When he offered her a one-handed finger gun and clicked his tongue at her, her immediate response was to roll her eyes, but a genuine laugh followed only a moment later.

“Night night, Steve.”

With that, he shut the door and meandered up his front walk, though she didn’t even put the car in reverse until the front door shut safely behind him. Before she let off the brake, she fetched her phone from its holder on the windshield and typed a quick message to Rio.

“Last heathen deposited safely at home. Heading back to the house now. Holly and Jake were not terrible I hope?”

It did not take long for Rio to respond.

“Thankfully Jake waited until he got out of the car to throw up. Holly thanked me eight times. They’re good kids. I literally just pulled in at home. See you soon, pumpkin. I love you.”

With a grin that felt a little too wide for what time it was, Stevie typed in her response.

“You’re the best, mama. I love you too. Be there asap.”

It had not taken her long to venture back to her safe haven, finding the house dark aside from the phone screen that Rio was holding while she sat on the couch. As Stevie shut the door quietly behind her and kicked her shoes off, Rio’s head tipped back to take her in.

“It kills you not having me on the ‘track your kid’ app anymore, doesn’t it?” she teased in a quiet murmur as she leaned over the back of the couch, looking to her right to take in the sight of her mama, illuminated by the tiny glowing screen.

“No, because you always tell us where you’ll be. Mom on the other hand? She says she doesn’t care, but…”

“She worries.”

Their soft laughter did not carry far, but it was homely and warm as it was shared between them. Of the two, Agatha did worry more, but Stevie understood it. Every day that Agatha got to have with her children was a day she coveted even more than the one before it. They were the days she never got to have with Nicky.

So, if she wanted to worry a little extra because she did not know Stevie’s exact whereabouts, Stevie felt like she was entitled to it. She wasn’t going to let it feel suffocating or smothering, simply because she got it.

Agatha loved fiercely, and that was just something that would never change.

So long as Stevie was on the receiving end of that, she never wanted it to.

“You need to get some sleep,” Rio voiced, reaching over to ruffle her daughter’s hair. “I’ll make sure I get Nix down here for breakfast before he tries to break in and wake you up.”

The offer was sweet, but the truth was that Nix could break in and startle her awake every single day that she resided under that roof and she wouldn’t have cared. Maybe she might have been a little grumpy, but in the long run, it would always be something to look back on with fondness.

Her little brother, in their home, with their mothers.

As Stevie reached around to give Rio a light squeeze so she could set off for bed, she realized something.

Life would always – someway, somehow – be good if you were a Vidal.
